analyzed: niḥśeṣa vyavahāra aṅgam tad dvāreṇa bhavati atas
translated: It becomes a part of all practical activity through that.

analyzed: tattvasam pa
translated: Tattva-samgraha-pañjikā.

analyzed: iti yadi api dṛṣṭam eva anyat vikalpaḥ ca anyaḥ
translated: Although what is seen is one thing and the concept another,

analyzed: kṣaṇikam hi sarvam
translated: everything is momentary.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam svalakṣaṇam
translated: What is seen is the particular characteristic.

analyzed: vikalpaḥ ca sāmānya ātmā
translated: And the concept has the nature of a universal.

analyzed: tathā api dṛśya vikalpayoḥ ananyatā adhyavasāyāt bhavati pravṛttiḥ
translated: Nevertheless, activity occurs because of the conviction that what is seen and the concept are not different.

analyzed: tat yuktam sva avabhāsita artha adhyavasaya utpādana śaktimat tayā vyavahāra aṅga tvam
translated: It is appropriate that it is a part of practical activity by virtue of having the power to produce the conviction in the object that it illuminates itself.

analyzed: nanu sa vikalpasya api samyak jñāna tayā prāmāṇyam abhyupeyam na
translated: But even a conceptual cognition must be accepted as valid by being right knowledge. No.

analyzed: apūrva gocaram eva samyak jñānam pramāṇam
translated: Only that which has a new object is a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: sa vikalpakaḥ ca na apūrva gocaraḥ
translated: And a conceptual cognition does not have a new object.

analyzed: pratyakṣa gṛhītam eva hi gṛḥṇāti
translated: For it grasps only what has been apprehended by perception.

analyzed: ananya tayā eva tu grahaḥ
translated: But it grasps it as not different.

original: uktaṃ ca kamalaśīlena'pratyakṣaṃ kalpanāpoḍhamapi sajātīyavijātīyavyāvṛttamanalādikamarthaṃ tadākāranirbhāsotpattitaḥ parichindadurpadyate
analyzed: uktam ca kamalaśīlena pratyakṣam kalpanā apoḍham api sajātīya vijātīya vyāvṛttam anala ādikam artham tad ākāra nirbhāsa utpattitaḥ
translated: And it has been said by Kamalasila: 'Perception, even though free from conceptual construction, is ascertained as an object such as fire, which is excluded from things of the same and different kinds, by producing the appearance of that form.'

original: tacca niyatarūpavyavasthitavastugrāhitvād vijātīyavyāvṛttavastvākārānugatatvācca tatraiva vastuni vidhipratiṣedhāvāvirbhāvayatianalo'yaṃ nāsau kusumastabaka iti /
analyzed: tat ca niyata rūpa vyavasthita vastu grāhi tvāt vijātīya vyāvṛtta vastu ākāra anugata tvāt ca tatra eva vastuni vidhi pratiṣedhau āvirbhāvayati na asau kusuma stabakaḥ iti
translated: And that [perception], because it grasps objects that are established as having a determinate form, and because it conforms to the aspect of an object that is excluded from what is of a different kind, manifests affirmation and negation just in that very object, [saying] This is fire, not that is a cluster of flowers.

original: tayo śca vikalpayoḥ pāramparyeṇa vastuni pratibandhādavisaṃvāditve'pi na prāmāṇyamiṣṭam /
analyzed: tayoḥ ca vikalpayoḥ pāramparyeṇa vastuni pratibandhāt avisaṃvādi tve api na prāmāṇyam iṣṭam
translated: And although those two conceptual cognitions are non-deceptive because of their indirect connection with the object, they are not accepted as valid cognition.

analyzed: dṛśya vikalpayoḥ eka tva adhyavasāyena pravṛtteḥ anadhigata vastu rūpa adhigama abhāvāt iti
translated: Because activity is undertaken by the ascertainment that the seen and the conceptualized are one, and because there is no apprehension of an object that was not previously known.

analyzed: tattvasam pa
translated: Tattva-sam-

analyzed: nanu dṛṣṭāt adhyavasitāt ca anyat eva yat prāpyate
translated: But what is attained is something different from what is seen and ascertained.

analyzed: tat na sva avabhāsita artha prāpaka tvam pratyakṣasya iti katham asya prāmāṇyam iti ced na
translated: So how can perception be valid, since it does not cause the attainment of the object that it manifests? No, that is not so.

analyzed: santāna aikyāt tad upapatteḥ
translated: Because that is possible due to the unity of the continuum.

original: uktaṃ ca pārśvadevena 'prāpaṇīyaśca pratyakṣasya santāna eveati nyāyapraveśavṛttipañcikā
analyzed: uktam ca pārśvadevena prāpaṇīyaḥ ca pratyakṣasya santānaḥ nyāya praveśa vṛtti pañcikā
translated: And it has been said by Pārśvadeva: And what is to be attained is the continuum itself of perception. In the commentary on the Nyāyapraveśa, the Pañcikā

analyzed: pratyakṣam vibhajate itat caturvidham iti
translated: He divides perception as being of four kinds.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi indriya pañcaka āśrayeṇa iti
translated: Based on the five sense faculties such as the eye, etc.

analyzed: āśraya tā ca eṣām asādhāraṇa kāraṇa tayā
translated: And their being the basis is due to being the uncommon cause.

analyzed: rūpa viṣayam iti
translated: The object of form.

analyzed: rūpyate iti rūpam dṛśya mātram
translated: Form is that which is modified, i.e., mere visible object.

original: rūpādipratyakṣe vaṣasyāpi hetutayā viṣayāśrayamityapi vaktuṃ śakyetetyetāṃ śaṅkāṃ pariharannāhaindriyapratyakṣamiti vyapadeśasyeti /
analyzed: rūpa ādi pratyakṣe vaṣasya api hetu tayā viṣaya āśrayam iti api vaktum śakyeta iti etām śaṅkām pariharan āha aindriya pratyakṣam iti vyapadeśasya iti
translated: Since the object is also a cause of the perception of form etc., it can be said to be the basis of the object. To remove this doubt, he says the designation as sense perception etc.

original: uktaṃ ca 'asādhāraṇahetutvādakṣaistad vyapadiśyate' ti kalpanāpoḍhasyāsya cākṣuṣādervikalpotpādanadvāreṇaiva svāvabhāsite'rthe pramāṇatā /
analyzed: uktam ca asādhāraṇa hetu tvāt akṣaiḥ tat vyapadiśyate ti kalpanā apoḍhasya asya cākṣuṣa ādeḥ vikalpa utpādana dvāreṇa eva sva avabhāsita irthe pramāṇa tā
translated: And it is said It is designated by the senses because of being the uncommon cause. And this non-conceptual perception, such as visual perception, is a means of valid knowledge regarding the object illuminated by itself only through the production of conceptual thought.

analyzed: anutpanne tu vikalpe na prāmāṇyam
translated: But when conceptual thought has not arisen, it is not a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: na tāvatā kṣatiḥ
translated: But there is no harm in that.

analyzed: vyavahāra aṅga tayā hi pramāṇam nirūpyate
translated: For a means of valid knowledge is determined as a part of worldly usage.

original: vyapetasakalavāsanasya saṃbhavatyapi nirvikalpake pratyakṣe savikalpānutpādena na tamapekṣya pramāṇam /
analyzed: vyapeta sakala vāsanasya saṃbhavati api nirvikalpake pratyakṣe sa vikalpa anutpādena na tam apekṣya pramāṇam
translated: Even though non-conceptual perception is possible for one devoid of all impressions, it is not a means of valid knowledge in relation to that, because conceptual thought does not arise in dependence on it.

original: dvārānutpatteḥ na ca dvāreṇa dvāriṇo'nyathāsiddhirityabhiprāyeṇāhaidaṃ cetyādinā /
analyzed: dvāra anutpatteḥ na ca dvāreṇa dvāriṇaḥ anyathā siddhiḥ iti abhiprāyeṇa āha edam ca ityādinā
translated: Because the door has not arisen. And the idea is that the one inside is not established otherwise than by the door. With this in mind, he says this etc.

analyzed: atha mānasa pratyakṣam lakṣayati sva viṣaya iti
translated: Now he defines mental perception: with its own object etc.

analyzed: uktam ca idam lakṣaṇam nyāyabindau dharmakīrtinā
translated: And this definition has been stated in the Nyāyabindu by Dharmakīrti.

analyzed: lakṣaṇa vākyam vyācaṣṭe sva śabdena ityādinā
translated: He explains the definition statement beginning with by its own word and so on.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa ghaṭakasya sva śabdasya viśeṣya para tā hi yuktā  sahakāriṇā iti
translated: For it is proper that the word its own, which is a component of the qualification, should refer to the qualified.🔽Cooperating means.

analyzed: sahāri tvam ca asya eka kārya kāri tayā
translated: And its cooperation is by producing a single effect.
Sense perception.

original: tadviṣayasantānavartī tadanantarasamutpanno ghaṭādidvitīyakṣaṇaścetyubhayaṃ militvā mānasaṃ pratyakṣaṃ janayatīti yāvat /
analyzed: tad viṣaya santāna vartī tad anantara samutpannaḥ ghaṭa ādi dvitīya kṣaṇaḥ ca iti ubhayam militvā mānasam pratyakṣam janayati iti yāvat
translated: The second moment of the pot, etc., which occurs in the continuum of its object and arises immediately after it, and both together produce mental perception, that is the extent of it.

analyzed: samanantara pratyaya saṃjñakena iti
translated: By the one called the immediately preceding condition means.

analyzed: pratyayaḥ kāraṇam
translated: A condition is a cause.

original: uktaṃca'hetuḥ pratyayo nimittaṃ karaṇaxxmiti paryāyāḥ' iti /
analyzed: uktam ca hetuḥ pratyayaḥ nimittam paryāyāḥ iti
translated: And it has been said that cause, condition, reason, instrument - these are synonyms.

analyzed: samantaraḥ sam iti anena samāna tvam gamyate
translated: Immediately means equal by this.

analyzed: sāmyam ca jñāna tvena
translated: And equality is by being cognition.

analyzed: anantaraḥ avyavahitaḥ avyavahita pūrvaḥ
translated: Immediately preceding means unobstructed, preceding without obstruction.

original: uttaravijñāne hetubhūtasyaikasantānavartino jñānasya samanantara pratyaya ityeṣā saṃjñā /
analyzed: uttara vijñāne hetu bhūtasya eka santāna vartinaḥ jñānasya samanantara pratyayaḥ iti eṣā saṃjñā
translated: The cognition occurring in the same continuum that is the cause of the subsequent cognition is called the immediately preceding condition.

analyzed: vakṣyati ca sva santāna vartini upādāne jñāne rūḍhyā aprasiddhe iti
translated: And he will say, In the case of a cognition that is the material cause occurring in one's own continuum, it is well-known by convention.

original: uparate cakṣurvyāpāre anukṣaṇaṃ yadvijñānaṃ tena cakṣurvijñānena svaviṣayānantaraviṣayasahakṛtenotpādyate /
analyzed: uparate cakṣuḥ vyāpāre anukṣaṇam yat vijñānam tena cakṣuḥ vijñānena sva viṣaya anantara viṣaya sahakṛtena utpādyate
translated: And when the function of the eye has ceased, the cognition that arises in the next moment, produced by the eye-cognition together with its own object and the immediately preceding object,

analyzed: tat mānasa pratyakṣam iti paryavasitam iti
translated: that is the mental perception, is the conclusion.

analyzed: avyavahāri tvam punar asya iti
translated: Moreover, this is not subject to verbal usage.

original: asyoktalakṣaṇalakṣitasya mānasapratyakṣasya vyahārapathāgocaratvamityeṣa doṣo na bhavati /
analyzed: asya ukta lakṣaṇa lakṣitasya mānasa pratyakṣasya vyahāra patha agocara tvam iti eṣa doṣaḥ na bhavati
translated: This mental perception characterized by the stated definition, this fault does not occur that it is not the domain of verbal usage.

analyzed: na hi atiprasaṅga uprasaṅgaḥ vā lakṣaṇasya
translated: For there is no overextension or under-extension of the definition.

analyzed: satyām sāmagryām vyavahāra patha gocara tā
translated: When the requisite conditions are present, it is the domain of verbal usage.

original: asatyāṃ ca na /🔽tāvatā'sya ko'vaguṇa iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: asatyām ca na  tāvatā asya kovaguṇaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And when they are not present, it is not.🔽The idea is that what is the fault of this [mental perception]?

analyzed: vyavahāra agocaram vyavahāra anaṅga bhūtam kim iti iṣyate īti āśaṅkāyām āha āgama prasiddham iti
translated: Why is it accepted as not the domain of verbal usage, as not a component of verbal usage? To this he says: It is well-known from scripture.

analyzed: āgamaḥ eva tad sadbhāve pramānam iti yāvat
translated: The meaning is that scripture itself is the valid cognition regarding its existence.

analyzed: āgamam eva darśayati yathā uktam iti
translated: He shows the scripture itself, saying as stated.

original: nanu āgame vyavāhāre sarvathānupayuktasyāsyābhyupagamo nirarthaka ityāśayenāśaṅkatenanviti /
analyzed: nanu āgame vyavāhāre sarvathā anupayuktasya asya abhyupagamaḥ nirarthakaḥ iti āśayena āśaṅkate nanu iti
translated: But if it is not at all useful in verbal usage, its acceptance is pointless. With this idea in mind, he raises the doubt: But isn't it...

analyzed: pariharati īdṛś lakṣaṇā iti
translated: He replies: It has such a definition...

original: ayamāśayaḥ nahi lokavyavahāre'nupayuktatāmātreṇa vastu apahnotuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ nahi vastu apahnotum śakyate
translated: The idea is this: A thing cannot be denied merely because it is not useful in worldly affairs.

original: asti cedaṃ pratyakṣaṃ /🔽vastu vivecanīyaṃ tu lakṣaṇena /
analyzed: asti ca idam pratyakṣam  vastu vivecanīyam tu lakṣaṇena
translated: And this is perception.🔽But the thing must be distinguished by a definition.

original: uktena ca lakṣaṇena tat pratyakṣaṃ vivecitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: uktena ca lakṣaṇena tat pratyakṣam vivecitam bhavati
translated: And by the definition stated, that perception becomes distinguished.

original: tadanena vivecanena āgame pareṣāmaviśuddhyāśaṅkāpi nirastā bhavatīti /
analyzed: tat anena vivecanena āgame pareṣām aviśuddhi āśaṅkā api nirastā bhavati iti
translated: And by this distinction, the doubt of impurity in the scriptures of others is also removed.

analyzed: āha ca dharmottara ācāryaḥ etat ca siddhānta siddham mānasa pratyakṣam
translated: And the teacher Dharmatrāta says: 'And this mental perception is established by the established doctrine.

analyzed: na ca asya prasādhakam pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no proof to establish it.

original: evaṃjātīyakaṃ yadi syāt na kaścit doṣaḥ syāditi vaktuṃ lakṣaṇamākhyātamasyetī'ti /
analyzed: evaṃjātīyakam yadi syāt na kaścid doṣaḥ syāt iti vaktum lakṣaṇam ākhyātam asya iti iti
translated: If it were of this kind, there would be no fault at all. To say this, its definition is stated.'

analyzed: nyāyabi ṭīkā
translated: Nyāyabhāṣya

analyzed: atha sva saṃvedana pratyakṣam nirūpayati sarva citta caittānām ityādinā
translated: Now he describes the self-awareness perception, beginning with 'of all minds and mental factors'.

analyzed: yat citta caittānām ātma saṃvedanam bhavati tat eva sva saṃvedanam ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the self-awareness is said to be just that self-awareness of minds and mental factors.

analyzed: tat etat vyācaṣṭe cittam ityādinā
translated: He explains this with 'mind' and so on.

analyzed: vastu mātra grāhi iti nīla ādi bāhya vastu mātra grāhi pratyakṣam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the perception grasps only the external things like blue and so on.

analyzed: citte bhavāḥ caittāḥ na ete bāhyāḥ
translated: The mental states are those that exist in the mind. They are not external.

original: anya eva nīlādibhyo bāhyebhyaḥ sātādaya ābhyantarāḥ /
analyzed: anye eva nīla ādibhyaḥ bāhyebhyaḥ sāta ādayaḥ ābhyantarāḥ
translated: The internal are different from the external blue etc., such as pleasure etc.

original: dṛśyamānasya nīlādervastuno viśeṣāvasthāgrāhakā jñānaprabhedāḥ sukhaduḥkhopekṣālakṣaṇā nīlādivastuṣu sākṣātkriyamāṇeṣu jāyante /
analyzed: dṛśyamānasya nīla ādeḥ vastunaḥ viśeṣa avasthā grāhakāḥ jñāna prabhedāḥ sukha duḥkha upekṣā lakṣaṇāḥ nīla ādi vastuṣu sākṣātkriyamāṇeṣu jāyante
translated: The distinctions of cognition that grasp the specific states of the visible object blue etc., characterized by pleasure, pain, and indifference, arise when the objects blue etc. are directly perceived.

original: tānyetāni yena rūpeṇa saṃvedyante tat svasaṃvedanapratyakṣamucyate /
analyzed: tāni etāni yena rūpeṇa saṃvedyante tat sva saṃvedana pratyakṣam ucyate
translated: That by which these are cognized is called self-awareness perception.

analyzed: hi kalpanā apoḍham abhra antam ca
translated: For that too is free from conceptualization and non-erroneous.

original: idamabhihitaṃ bhavatinīlādibāhyavastusākṣātkārasamaye sa sākṣātkāro nānavabhāsamānastiṣṭhati nīlādivat /
analyzed: idam abhihitam bhavati nīla ādi bāhya vastu sākṣātkāra samaye sa sākṣātkāraḥ na anavabhāsamānaḥ tiṣṭhati nīla ādi vat
translated: This is what is meant: At the time of the direct perception of the external object blue etc., that direct perception does not remain unmanifested like blue etc.

analyzed: tathā sāta ādikam api
translated: Similarly, pleasure etc. also.

original: tadeṣāmavabhāsaḥ svenaivotpanna iti svasaṃvedanaṃ pratyakṣamucyate iti /
analyzed: tat eṣām avabhāsaḥ svena eva utpannaḥ iti sva saṃvedanam pratyakṣam ucyate iti
translated: That manifestation of theirs arises from itself alone, therefore it is called self-awareness perception.

analyzed: āha ca ācārya diṅnāgaḥ
translated: And the teacher Dignāga says:

analyzed: cittam api artha rāga ādi sva saṃvid nirvikalpakam iti
translated: The mind too, with attachment to objects etc., is self-awareness, non-conceptual.

analyzed: vṛttiḥ ca cittam api rūpa ādīn upalabdhvā yat anubhava ākāreṇa vartate
translated: And the commentary: The mind too, having perceived form etc., operates in the aspect of experience.

analyzed: tat nirvikalpakam eva
translated: That is non-conceptual alone.

original: icchākrodhamohasukhaduḥkhādikaṃ hi indriyamanapekṣya bhavatīti svasaṃvedanaṃ pratyakṣamiti /
analyzed: icchā krodha moha sukha duḥkha ādikam hi indriyam an apekṣya bhavati iti sva saṃvedanam pratyakṣam iti
translated: For desire, anger, delusion, pleasure, pain, etc. occur independently of the sense organs. Self-awareness is perception.

analyzed: pramāṇa samuccaya
translated: Compendium of Means of Valid Knowledge.

original: nanu svasaṃvedanamityanena svenaiva svayaṃ saṃvedyata ityuktaṃ bhavati nacaikasyāmeva kriyāyāmekasyaiva kartṛtvaṃ karmatvaṃ copapadyate ityāśayena śaṅkate atra kecidāhuriti /
analyzed: nanu sva saṃvedanam iti anena svena eva svayam saṃvedyate iti uktam bhavati na ca ekasyām eva kriyāyām ekasya eva kartṛ tvam karma tvam ca upapadyate iti āśayena śaṅkate atra kecid āhuḥ iti
translated: Now, by this self-awareness, it is said that it is to be known by itself alone. And it is not proper for one and the same action to have one and the same agent and object. With this idea, he raises the doubt Here some say.

analyzed: na avayava artha yogena ayam śabdaḥ utra pravartate
translated: This word does not operate here by the meaning of its parts,

analyzed: kintu prakāśaka antara nirapekṣa prakāśa svabhāva tām abhipretya sva saṃvedanam iti ucyate iti āśayena samādhatte atra ucyate ityādinā
translated: but rather with the idea of the nature of self-awareness, which is self-illumination independent of another illuminator, it is said self-awareness. With this idea, he resolves Here it is said and so on.

analyzed: vyavasthāpya vyavasthāpaka bhāvena iti
translated: By the relation of the determined and the determiner.

original: sarvameva vastu hetubalādutpadyamānaṃ bhinnabhinnasvabhāvamutpadyate iti vastūnāṃ svabhāvaviśeṣe vyavasthāpakastattaddhetureva /
analyzed: sarvam eva vastu hetu balāt utpadyamānam bhinna bhinna svabhāvam utpadyate iti vastūnām svabhāva viśeṣe vyavasthāpakaḥ tad tad hetuḥ eva
translated: Every existent thing, arising by the power of causes, arises with a different and different nature. Thus, the cause itself, which determines the particular nature of existents,

analyzed: tasmāt vastu svabhāva vyavasthāpakaḥ hetu viśeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the particular cause is the determiner of the nature of existents.

analyzed: tad vyavasthāpyaḥ ca vastu svabhāva viśeṣaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the nature of the object is to be determined.

analyzed: prakāśaka antara nirapekṣa prakāśa svabhāva tām upapādayati yathā ityādinā
translated: In order to establish the nature of self-luminous cognition, which is independent of any other illuminator, he says just as and so on.

analyzed: naiyāyika abhimatām jñānasya jaḍa rūpa tām pratikṣipati na ca ityādinā
translated: He rejects the Nyaya school's conception of cognition as having an inert nature by saying and it is not and so on.

original: jñānasya jñānāntara prakāśyatve kiṃ samakālavartinā jñānāntareṇa prakāśyate uta bhinnakālavartineti vikalpya kramād dūṣayatina tāvaditi /
analyzed: jñānasya jñāna antara prakāśya tve kim sama kāla vartinā jñāna antareṇa prakāśyate uta bhinna kāla vartinā iti vikalpya kramāt dūṣayati na tāvat iti
translated: If cognition is to be illuminated by another cognition, is it illuminated by a cognition existing simultaneously or by one existing at a different time? Having considered this, he refutes it in order, saying not first and so on.

analyzed: prakāśya prakāśaka bhāvaḥ hi upakārya upakāraka bhāva lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: For the relation of illuminator and illluminated is characterized by the relation of the benefited and the benefactor.

analyzed: sa ca sama kāla bhāvinoḥ na ghaṭate
translated: And that does not hold for things existing simultaneously.

original: na hi vāmadakṣiṇaviṣāṇayormitha upakāryopakārakabhāva iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na hi vāma dakṣiṇa viṣāṇayoḥ mithas upakārya upakāraka bhāvaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: For there is no relation of the benefited and the benefactor between the right and left horns. This is the idea.

analyzed: na api iti
translated: Nor is it and so on.

original: jñānaṃ svānantarotpannena jñānāntareṇa ahamidaṃ jānāmītyanuvyavasāyātmakenāvabhāsyate ityetannopapadyate /
analyzed: jñānam sva anantara utpannena jñāna antareṇa aham idam jānāmi iti anuvyavasāya ātmakena avabhāsyate iti etat na upapadyate
translated: It is not tenable that cognition is manifested by another cognition that arises immediately after it, in the form of the ascertainment I know this.

original: vastumātrasya kṣaṇikatvena dvitīyakṣaṇe tasya vināśāt kva prakāśāvasaraḥ /
analyzed: vastu mātrasya kṣaṇika tvena dvitīya kṣaṇe tasya vināśāt kva prakāśa avasaraḥ
translated: For, being merely an object, it is destroyed in the second moment due to its momentariness, so where is the opportunity for manifestation?

analyzed: atas jñāna mātram aprakāśa ātmakam syāt
translated: Therefore, cognition would be mere knowledge, not having the nature of manifestation.

analyzed: kāṇādāḥ hi jñānasya kṣaṇa dvaya avasthāyi tvam abhyupagacchantaḥ anuvyavasāya gocara tvam upapādayanti
translated: For the Kaṇādas, accepting that knowledge lasts for two moments, explain its being the object of subsequent cognition.

analyzed: vastu mātrasya kṣaṇa bhaṅga samarthanena na tad vādasya avakāśaḥ
translated: There is no scope for that doctrine by establishing that only an entity is momentary.

analyzed: iti tayoḥ aikarāśyam
translated: Thus, they form a unity.

original: samavāye tu na tadubhayamapīti tebhyo viṣeṣaḥ /🔽parābhimatā iti /
analyzed: samavāye tu na tat ubhayam api iti tebhyaḥ viṣeṣaḥ  para abhimatāḥ iti
translated: But in inherence, neither of these two exists, so it is different from them.🔽The others' means

analyzed: paraiḥ kāṇādaiḥ ākṣapādaiḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: the others, the Kaṇādas and Ākṣapādas.

analyzed: paraiḥ dvayam nitya anitya vibhāgena dvedhā iṣyate
translated: The others consider the two as twofold, divided into eternal and non-eternal.

original: tatra sarvasya vastunaḥ kṣaṇikatvasamarthanenaiva nityadravyanirāsāt tasya pratyakṣaviṣayatvaṃ nirastaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tatra sarvasya vastunaḥ kṣaṇika tva samarthanena eva nitya dravya nirāsāt tasya pratyakṣa viṣaya tvam nirastam bhavati
translated: Among them, by establishing the momentariness of all entities, the denial of eternal substances is made, so the fact that they are objects of perception is refuted.

original: atha yadavayavi dravyaṃ tasya pratyakṣaviṣayatvaṃ nirasyati tathāhi ghaṭādāvityādinā /
analyzed: atha yat avayavi dravyam tasya pratyakṣa viṣaya tvam nirasyati tathā hi ghaṭa ādau ityādinā
translated: Now, he refutes the idea that the composite substance is an object of perception. Thus, he says in the case of a pot, etc.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ dṛśyate nāma ghaṭa ādi sthūlam vastu
translated: The idea is this: indeed, a gross object like a pot is seen.

analyzed: na sthūlam iti etāvatā avayavi vastu antaram tat
translated: It is not that it is gross merely because it is an aggregate of atoms.

analyzed: ye nāma aṇavaḥ te eva saṃhatāḥ sthūla tayā avabhāsante
translated: Those that are indeed atomic appear as gross only when aggregated.

analyzed: na ca aṇavaḥ dṛśya svabhāvāḥ
translated: And atoms are not of the nature of the invisible.

original: paramāṇavo nityā adṛśyā iti ca yatsattatkṣaṇikamityato nirastam /
analyzed: paramāṇavaḥ nityāḥ adṛśyāḥ iti ca yat sat tat kṣaṇikam iti atas nirastam
translated: And what is said, that atoms are eternal and invisible, is refuted by the principle that whatever exists is momentary.

original: yadupalabhyate sthūlamiti tatra bhāgā eva aṃśā eva hi dṛśyante natvaṃśī kaścidavayavī /
analyzed: yat upalabhyate sthūlam iti tatra bhāgāḥ eva aṃśāḥ eva hi dṛśyante na tu aṃśī kaścid avayavī
translated: What is perceived as gross, there only the parts, only the portions are seen, but no whole, no composite entity at all.

original: pūrvāparādivibhāgeṣu yadā pūrvo bhāgo dṛśyate tadā tu nāparaḥ /
analyzed: pūrva apara ādi vibhāgeṣu yadā pūrvaḥ bhāgaḥ dṛśyate tadā tu na aparaḥ
translated: When the eastern part is seen in the divisions of east, west, etc., then not the western.

original: apare vibhāge tu cakṣuḥpathāgocare naiva bhavati nīlādyavadhāraṇam /
analyzed: apare vibhāge tu cakṣuḥ patha agocare nā eva bhavati nīla ādi avadhāraṇam
translated: But in the western division, which comes within the range of the eye, there is no determination of blue, etc.

original: kimaparo vibhāgo nīlo vā śukla iti saṃśaya eva /
analyzed: kim aparaḥ vibhāgaḥ nīlaḥ vā śuklaḥ iti saṃśayaḥ eva
translated: There is doubt itself as to whether the other division is blue or white.

analyzed: yadi avayavī dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: If the composite entity were seen.

analyzed: avadhārita anavadhārita bhāga bheda vyavasthā na upapadyet
translated: The determination and non-determination of the distinction of parts would not be possible.

original: tasmāt keśa eko nopalabhyate sa eva saṃhata upalabhyate /
analyzed: tasmāt keśaḥ ekaḥ na upalabhyate saḥ eva saṃhataḥ upalabhyate
translated: Therefore, a single hair is not perceived. It is perceived only when aggregated.

analyzed: evam ime ca aṇavaḥ bhāgāḥ saṃhatāḥ upalabhyante
translated: In the same way, these atomic parts are perceived when aggregated.

analyzed: bhāgebhyaḥ nyaḥ bhagī kaḥ upi avayavī syāt
translated: There would be some composite entity, different from the parts, which is the possessor of the parts.

analyzed: makṣikā ādinā aṃśataḥ tirohitaḥ yam avayavī tirohitaḥ eva iti na eva upalabhyeta
translated: The whole covered by a part, like a fly, would not be perceived at all.

original: ato yuktaṃ bhāgā eva bhāsanta iti /
analyzed: atas yuktam bhāgāḥ eva bhāsante iti
translated: Therefore it is right that only the parts appear.

analyzed: atra āpta saṃvādam darśayati yat āha nyāya parameśvaraḥ iti
translated: To show the agreement with the authoritative texts, he says what the Supreme Lord of Logic says.

analyzed: tathā tathā saṃniviṣṭāḥ pūrva apara ātmanā saṃniviṣṭāḥ
translated: Arranged in that way, arranged in the east-west direction.

original: grīvātmanā kambvātmanā saṃniviṣṭāḥ🔽ābhyo bhāgebhyo'nyastadvānbhāgavān vibhāgaḥavayavivibhāgo naiva dṛśyate /
analyzed: grīvā ātmanā kambu ātmanā saṃniviṣṭāḥ  ābhyaḥ bhāgebhyaḥ nyaḥ tadvān bhāgavān vibhāgaḥ avayavi vibhāgaḥ nā eva dṛśyate
translated: Arranged in the neck, arranged in the throat.🔽The whole, which possesses those parts, is not seen as separate from those parts.

original: na hi tantubhyo'nyaḥ pato nāmāvayavī dṛśyate /
analyzed: na hi tantubhyaḥ nyaḥ pataḥ nāma avayavī dṛśyate
translated: The whole called cloth is not seen as separate from the threads.

original: tathā tathā saṃniviṣṭāstantava eva tu dṛśyante /
analyzed: tathā tathā saṃniviṣṭāḥ tantavaḥ eva tu dṛśyante
translated: Only the threads arranged in that way are seen.

analyzed: evam eva tantuṣu api ūhyam
translated: The same should be applied to the threads as well.

analyzed: guṇa karma ādīnām ca dūṣaṇam pratyetavyam iti
translated: And the refutation of qualities, actions, etc. should be understood.

original: dūṣaṇaprakāraścāyaṃgṛhābyantarasthite ghaṭādau mahati kuñcikādisūkṣmavivaravartinā''lokena dṛśyamāne samupalabhyate nīlamaṃśataḥ /
analyzed: dūṣaṇa prakāraḥ ca ayaṃgṛha abyantara sthite ghaṭa ādau mahati kuñcikā ādi sūkṣma vivara vartinā ālokena dṛśyamāne samupalabhyate nīlam aṃśataḥ
translated: And the mode of refutation is perceived when a large pot, etc. inside a house is seen by light in a small hole like a keyhole. The blue part is seen.

analyzed: tat ca ekam avayavi samavetam anaṃśam abhyupagacchatām eka aṃśa upalambhaḥ na syāt
translated: And that which is accepted as one, inhering in the whole, partless, would not be perceived as one part.

analyzed: sarvatas eva upalabhyeta
translated: It would be perceived from all sides.

original: tathā āmraphale kasmiṃścidāsvādyamāne āsvādyamānāṃśe samupalabhyamāno madhurarasaḥ sarvāṃśenopalabhyeta /
analyzed: tathā āmra phale kasmiṃścid āsvādyamāne āsvādyamāna aṃśe samupalabhyamānaḥ madhura rasaḥ sarva aṃśena upalabhyeta
translated: Similarly, when the sweet taste is perceived in a part of a mango fruit that is being tasted, it would be perceived in all parts.

analyzed: na ca bhavati tathā
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: tat na rūpa rūpi vibhāgaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no distinction between form and the bearer of form.

original: aṃśā eva tūpalabhyanta iti tu susyitam /
analyzed: aṃśāḥ eva tu upalabhyante iti tu su syitam
translated: But it is well said that only the parts are perceived.

analyzed: evam guṇa antara nirasanam anvataḥ bodhyam
translated: In the same way, the refutation of other qualities should be understood.

original: kṣaṇavināśiṣu sarveṣu bhāveṣu kriyāyāḥ kaḥ prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: kṣaṇa vināśiṣu sarveṣu bhāveṣu kriyāyāḥ kaḥ prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In all momentary things, what is the connection with action?

analyzed: sāmānya ādi nirāsaḥ api anyatas bodhyaḥ
translated: The refutation of universals and so on should also be understood from elsewhere.

analyzed: atha pramāṇe phala vipratipattim nirasyan upakramate nanu pramiti rūpām ityādinā
translated: Now, refuting the disagreement about the result in the means of valid knowledge, he begins with But is not the form of valid knowledge... and so on.

analyzed: pramīyate enena iti pramāṇa pada vyutpatti anurodhāt
translated: Because of the derivation of the word means of valid knowledge as that by which one is measured,

original: pramitau yat karaṇaṃ tat pramāṇamiti siddhyati /
analyzed: pramitau yat karaṇam tat pramāṇam iti siddhi ati
translated: it is established that the instrument in valid knowledge is the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: pramāṇam ca jñānam iṣṭam
translated: And knowledge is accepted as the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: kā asau pramitiḥ
translated: What is that valid knowledge?

original: tatkaraṇaṃ ca tato'nyat pramāṇabhūtaṃ jñānaṃ kiṃ /
analyzed: tad karaṇam ca tatonyat pramāṇa bhūtam jñānam kim
translated: And is that instrument of it, which is a different means of valid knowledge, some other knowledge?

analyzed: bhedena hi tayoḥ phala phali bhāvaḥ nirūpaṇīyaḥ
translated: For the relation of effect and cause between them must be determined by their difference.

analyzed: pratyakṣa pramāṇa tayā bhavat abhimate pramāṇa tad phalayoḥ bhedaḥ durnirūpaḥ iti āśaṅkituḥ āśayaḥ
translated: The idea of the one who doubts is that the difference between the means of knowledge and its result, which is accepted by you as being a means of knowledge through perception, is difficult to determine.

analyzed: āśaṅkām pariharati ucyate ityādinā
translated: He answers the doubt with It is said and so on.

analyzed: nīla ādeḥ arthāt iti  nīla ādi bāhya artha avalambi yat vijñānam utpadyate
translated: From the object such as blue.

analyzed: tat dvi rūpam utpadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the consciousness that arises in dependence on the external object such as blue arises with two forms.

analyzed: dvairūpyam āha nīla ākāra nīla bodha svarūpam ca iti
translated: He states the two forms as the form of blue and the nature of the cognition of blue.

original: tadevamekasyaiva pratyakṣasya dvairūpyate sati tatra yāṃīlākāravyāvṛttilakṣaṇā nīlākāratā jñānasya /🔽tadeva prāmāṇyam /
analyzed: tat evam ekasya eva pratyakṣasya sati tatra yā nīla ākāra vyāvṛtti lakṣaṇā nīla ākāra tā jñānasya  tat eva prāmāṇyam
translated: Thus, when a single perception has two forms, the form of blue, which is characterized by the exclusion of the form of blue, is the validity of that cognition.

original: yā cānīlabodhavyāvṛttilakṣaṇā nīlabodhātmatā saiva tasya phalarūpatā /
analyzed: yā ca a nīla bodha vyāvṛtti lakṣaṇā nīla bodha ātma tā sā eva tasya phala rūpa tā
translated: And the nature of the cognition of blue, which is characterized by the exclusion of the cognition of non-blue, is its result-form.

analyzed: iti phala phali bhedaḥ iti āśayena āha tatra ityādinā  nirgalitam artham āha yathā uktam artha ityādinā  asya nīla ādi bāhya ālambanasya pratyakṣasya yathā uktam artha sārūpyam nīla ādi sārūpyam anīla ākāra vyāvṛtti lakṣaṇam
translated: With this idea that the means of knowledge and its result are different, he says There and so on.🔽He states the clear meaning with The conformity to the object as stated and so on.

analyzed: pramāṇam ucyate
translated: The conformity to the object as stated, that is, the conformity to blue, which is characterized by the exclusion of the form of non-blue, of this perception that has an external object such as blue as its basis, is said to be the means of knowledge.

analyzed: yathā uktā a nīla bodha vyāvṛtti lakṣaṇā nīla artha avagatiḥ phalam ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the cognition of the blue object, characterized by the exclusion of the cognition of the non-blue as stated, is said to be the result.

original: nanvekasminneva pratyakṣe phalaphalibhedaḥ kathaṃ /🔽sādhyasādhanabhāvanibandhano hi sa iti śaṅkāṃ vyudasyannāhaetaccetyanena /
analyzed: nanu ekasmin eva pratyakṣe phala phali bhedaḥ katham  sādhya sādhana bhāva nibandhanaḥ hi saḥ iti śaṅkām vyudasyan āha etat ca iti anena
translated: But how can there be a difference between the result and the instrument in the same perception?🔽To dispel this doubt, he says with this that it is not so.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ na sādhya sādhana bhāva niyataḥ phala phali bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is this: The relation of result and instrument is not necessarily based on the relation of the probandum and probans.

original: ekasyāpyākārabhedena sa hyupapadyate yadyapyatra nāsti paramārthato bhedo vastunaḥ /
analyzed: ekasya api ākāra bhedena sa hi upapadyate yadi api atra na asti paramārthataḥ bhedaḥ vastunaḥ
translated: That is possible even when there is difference in form of the same thing. Although there is no real difference in the object here,

analyzed: pratyakṣam tu vastutas ekam eva
translated: perception is indeed one in reality.

analyzed: atha api idam pramāṇam idam pramāṇa phalam iti ākāra bhedāt bhinnam vyavasthāpyate
translated: But even so, it is established as different by the difference in form, that this is the means of valid knowledge and this is the result of the means of valid knowledge.

original: iyaṃ ca phalaphalibhāvavyavasthā pratyakṣasamanantarasamutpannena savikalpakena vyavasthāpyata iti /
analyzed: iyam ca phala phali bhāva vyavasthā pratyakṣa samanantara samutpannena sa vikalpakena vyavasthāpyate iti
translated: And this establishment of the relation of result and instrument is established by the conceptual cognition that arises immediately after perception.

original: āha ca dharmottarācāryaḥ'tasmādasārūpyavyāvṛttyā sārūpyaṃ jñānasya vyavasthāpanahetuḥ anīlabodhavyāvṛttyā ca nīlabodharūpatvaṃ vyavasthāpyaṃ /
analyzed: āha ca dharmottara ācāryaḥ tasmāt asārūpya vyāvṛttyā sārūpyam jñānasya vyavasthāpana hetuḥ anīla bodha vyāvṛttyā ca nīla bodha rūpa tvam vyavasthāpyam
translated: The teacher Dharottara says: Therefore, by the exclusion of non-similarity, similarity is the cause of establishing the knowledge. And by the exclusion of the cognition of the non-blue, the form of the cognition of the blue is to be established.

analyzed: vyavasthāpakaḥ ca vikalpa pratyayaḥ pratyakṣa bala utpannaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ iti
translated: And the determinative conceptual cognition should be seen as arising from the power of perception.
Commentary on the Drop of Logic

analyzed: āha ca idam atra śāntarakṣitaḥ
translated: Śāntarakṣita says here:

analyzed: pramāṇa phalam iṣyate
translated: Here, the attainment of the object is accepted as the result of valid cognition.

analyzed: sva vittiḥ vā pramāṇam tu sārūpyam
translated: Or self-awareness is the valid cognition, or even similarity and fitness.

original: iti / vyākhyātaṃ caitat kamalaśīlena'bāhye'rthe prameye viṣayādhigamaḥ pramāṇaphalaṃ /
analyzed: iti vyākhyātam ca etat kamalaśīlena bāhya ṛthe prameye viṣaya adhigamaḥ pramāṇa phalam
translated: And this has been explained by Kamalaśīla: When the external object is the object of knowledge, the attainment of the object is the result of valid cognition.

analyzed: sārūpyam tu pramāṇam
translated: But similarity is the valid cognition.

analyzed: jñāna ātmani tu prameye sva saṃvittiḥ phalam
translated: When the cognition itself is the object of knowledge, self-awareness is the result.

original: yogyatā pramāṇam iti /🔽samanantaraślokavyākhyāne ca nīlāspadaṃ saṃvedanaṃ na pītasyeti viṣayādhigativyavasthāyā arthasārūpyameva nibandhanaṃ nānyaditi vyavasthāpyavyavasthāpakabhāvena
analyzed: yogyatā pramāṇam iti  samanantara śloka vyākhyāne ca nīla āspadam saṃvedanam na pītasya iti viṣaya adhigati vyavasthāyāḥ artha sārūpyam eva nibandhanam na anyat iti vyavasthāpya vyavasthāpaka bhāvena
translated: Fitness is the valid cognition.🔽And in the explanation of the immediately preceding verse, the cognition that has blue as its basis is not of yellow, so the determination of the attainment of the object is based only on similarity to the object, not on anything else. Thus, the determinable and the determiner🔽are established. Therefore, cognition with an image is the valid cognition, not the one without an image.

original: ' ' tasmāt sākārameva jñānaṃ pramāṇaṃ na nirākāraṃ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / vyavasthā ca tatpṛṣṭhalabdhena vikalpena veditavye'ti /
analyzed: tasmāt sa ākāram eva jñānam pramāṇam na nirākāram vyavasthā ca tad pṛṣṭha labdhena vikalpena veditavyā iti
translated: And the determination should be known through the conceptual cognition that arises subsequently.

analyzed: idam atra bodhyam nīla ādi bāhya viṣaya sārūpyam pramāṇam
translated: The Vaibhāṣikas say that the means of valid knowledge here is the conformity of cognition with external objects such as blue, etc.

analyzed: iti vaibhāṣikāḥ
translated: The result is the apprehension of objects such as blue, etc.

original: nīlādinā bāhyena jñāne āhitaḥ svākāraḥ pramāṇaṃ svasaṃvittiḥ phalaṃ /
analyzed: nīla ādinā bāhyena jñāne āhitaḥ sva ākāraḥ pramāṇam sva saṃvittiḥ phalam
translated: The Sautrāntikas say that the means of valid knowledge is the form of cognition produced by external objects such as blue, etc., and the result is the self-awareness of that cognition.

analyzed: na viṣaya avabhāsaḥ iti sautrāntikāḥ
translated: The appearance as an object is not [the means of valid knowledge].

analyzed: apratyakṣaḥ hi eṣām bāhyaḥ viṣayaḥ
translated: For them, the external object is not directly perceived.

analyzed: anumeya artha vādinaḥ hi ete
translated: For they are proponents of the theory that [objects] are to be inferred.

original: anādivāsanopaplāvito yo'yaṃ jñānasyaiva bahirvadavabhāsamāna ākāraḥ /🔽sa eva tu prameyaḥ /
analyzed: anādi vāsanā upaplāvitaḥ yaḥ yam jñānasya eva bahis vat avabhāsamānaḥ ākāraḥ  saḥ eva tu prameyaḥ
translated: The form of cognition that appears as if external, being influenced by beginningless predispositions, is indeed the object of knowledge.

analyzed: pramāṇam tu jñānasya sva ākāraḥ
translated: But the means of valid knowledge is the form of cognition itself.

analyzed: yā grāhaka tā yogya tā iti ca ucyate
translated: It is called the capacity to grasp.

analyzed: sva saṃvittiḥ phalam iti yoga ācārāḥ
translated: The Yogācārins say that the result is self-awareness.

analyzed: ete vijñāna mātra vādinaḥ
translated: These [Yogācārins] are proponents of the doctrine of consciousness only.

analyzed: imam matabhedaḥ manasi nidhāya ācārya diṅnāgaḥ idam āha
translated: Having placed this difference of opinion in mind, Ācārya Dignāga says this:

analyzed: sa vyāpāra pratīta tvāt pramāṇam phalam eva tat
translated: Because it is cognized as having an operation, that [cognition] is the means of valid knowledge and also the result.

analyzed: pramāṇa tva upacāraḥ tu nirvyāpāre na vidyate
translated: But the designation as a means of valid knowledge does not exist for what is without operation.

analyzed: viṣaya ākāraḥ eva asya pramāṇam tena mīyate
translated: The form of the object itself is its means of valid knowledge. By that, it is measured.

analyzed: sva saṃvittiḥ phalam vā atra tad rūpāt artha niścayāt
translated: Self-awareness or the result is the fruit here, because of the ascertainment of the object in that form.

analyzed: yad ābhāsam prameyam tat pramāṇam atha tad phalam
translated: When the object has that appearance, that is the means of valid knowledge, or that is its result.

analyzed: grāhaka ākāra saṃvittī trayam na atas pṛthakkṛtam
translated: The awareness of the form of the apprehender is threefold, not separate from that.

analyzed: pramāṇasaḥ ślo
translated: In the chapter on means of valid knowledge.

original: iti / pratyakṣe pramāṇatatphalayorvastubhedo nāstītyatra dharmakīrtavacanaṃ pramāṇayatiyathoktamiti /
analyzed: iti pratyakṣe pramāṇa tad phalayoḥ vastu bhedaḥ na asti iti atra dharmakīrta vacanam pramāṇayati yathā uktam iti
translated: Thus, in perception, there is no difference in reality between the means of valid knowledge and its result. Here, Dharmakīrti's statement is authoritative, as stated.

analyzed: nanu kim sārūpyam jñānasya arthena
translated: But what is the similarity of knowledge with the object?

analyzed: nirākāram tu jñānam iti āśaṅkām nirasyan āha yadi punar iti
translated: But knowledge is formless, thus dispelling the doubt, he says if again.

analyzed: iti pratyakṣa paricchedaḥ
translated: Thus ends the chapter on perception.
The chapter on inference

analyzed: atha anumānam vibhajate anumānam dvidhā iti
translated: Now, he divides inference, saying inference is of two kinds.

analyzed: nanu anirūpyānumāna sāmānya lakṣaṇam tad vibhajanam anucitam
translated: But it is not appropriate to divide it without first defining the general definition of inference.

original: lakṣaṇa eva hi prathamato jijñāsā samudeti /
analyzed: lakṣaṇe eva hi prathamatas jijñāsā samudeti
translated: For inquiry arises first of all in regard to the definition.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True,

original: sati samanugate lakṣaṇe prathamaṃ tadeva nirūpaṇiyam /
analyzed: sati samanugate lakṣaṇe prathamam tat eva
translated: if the definition is well-established, then that alone should be determined first.

analyzed: asati tu viśeṣayoḥ eva
translated: But if not, then of the particulars themselves.

analyzed: sva artham jñāna ātmakam para artham tu vacana ātmakam
translated: For one's own sake it is in the form of knowledge, but for the sake of others it is in the form of statements.

analyzed: tat enayoḥ visajātīyayoḥ na ekam lakṣaṇam ghaṭate
translated: Therefore, one characteristic is not possible for these two dissimilar [types of inference].

original: tat prathamaṃ vibhajyaiva tayorlakṣaṇaṃ vaktavyamiti yukto vibhāgaḥ /
analyzed: tat prathamam vibhajya eva tayoḥ lakṣaṇam vaktavyam iti yuktaḥ vibhāgaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is proper to divide them first and then state their characteristics.

analyzed: sva artham iti etat vyutpādayati svasmai yat tat sva artham iti
translated: He explains the word svārtha as that which is for oneself.

analyzed: parārtha anumānāt bhedam āha jñāna ātmakam iti
translated: He states the difference from inference for the sake of others by saying in the form of knowledge.

analyzed: svārthatām upapādayati parvata ādau ityādinā  para artham iti etat vyutpādayati parasmai yat tat para artha anumānam iti
translated: He explains the nature of being for one's own sake by saying in the case of a mountain, etc.🔽He explains the word parārtha as that which is for the sake of another.

analyzed: parārtha tām upapādayati trirūpa ityādinā
translated: He explains the nature of being for the sake of others by saying having three aspects, etc.

analyzed: jñāna viśeṣa bodhakasya anumāna śabdasya śabde pravṛttiḥ katham iti atas āha aupacārāt iti
translated: Since the word anumāna which indicates a particular kind of knowledge is used for verbal testimony, he says figuratively.

analyzed: nanu tri rūpa liṅga avabodhakam ekatra darśanam anyatra śabdaḥ
translated: In one case, the seeing which indicates the three-featured mark is direct perception, and in another case, it is verbal testimony.

analyzed: tāvatā katham anumāna dvaividhyam
translated: To that extent, how can there be a twofold division of inference?

analyzed: yadi evam cakṣuṣā api parārtha anumāna tvam prasajet
translated: If it is so, then even the eye would be an inference for the sake of others.

analyzed: mā evam  tri rūpa liṅga sūcakaḥ śabdaḥ
translated: No, that is not so.🔽The word which indicates the three-featured mark is inference.

analyzed: śabdaḥ hi arthasya vivakṣā dvāreṇa bhavati sūcakaḥ
translated: For, the word becomes an indicator of the meaning through the medium of the speaker's intention.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ tu sākṣāt tri rūpa liṅga pratyāyakaḥ
translated: But the eye is directly the conveyor of the three-featured inferential mark.

analyzed: sūcakaḥ eva tu para artha anumānam iti asmākam paribhāṣā iti
translated: But the conveyor itself is inference for others, such is our definition.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam śāntarakṣitena
translated: And thus it is said by Śāntarakṣita:

analyzed: tri rūpa liṅga vacasaḥ sattā saṃsūcaka tvataḥ  yat parārtha anumāna tvam uktam tat śrotra apekṣayā
translated: Because the statement of the three-featured inferential mark conveys existence,🔽the statement of what is inference for others is from the perspective of the listener.

analyzed: gauṇam sāṅketikam ca evam anumāna tvam āśritam
translated: Thus, the secondary and conventional nature of inference is accepted.

analyzed: sakta saṃsūcaka tvena tena na ati prasajyate  tattvasam pa
translated: By the conveyance of what is connected, there is no overextension.🔽Thus it is said in the Tattva-samgraha-pañjikā.

analyzed: iti vyākhyātam ca kamala śīlena vacanasya yat parārtha anumāna tvam uktam
translated: And it is explained by Kamalaśīla: The statement of what is inference for others is

analyzed: tad śrotra apekṣayā
translated: from the perspective of the listener.

analyzed: tena vaktra apekṣā bhāvī doṣaḥ na bhavati
translated: Therefore, the fault that does not exist from the perspective of the speaker does not occur.

analyzed: śrotra apekṣayā api trirūpa liṅga sūcanāt upacāreṇa anumāna kāraṇa tvāt samayāt vā anumāna tvam uktam
translated: From the perspective of the listener, because of conveying the three-featured inferential mark, by figurative use, because of being the cause of inference, or by convention, inference is stated.

original: saktasaṃsūcaka evānumānasaṃjñāniveśāt tenendriyasyāvinābhāvitvasaṃbandhajñānasya ca parārthānumānatvaprasaṅgādatiprasaṅgo na bhavati /
analyzed: sakta saṃsūcakaḥ eva anumāna saṃjñā niveśāt tena indriyasya avinābhāvi tva saṃbandha jñānasya ca parārtha anumāna tva prasaṅgāt atiprasaṅgaḥ na bhavati
translated: By including in the concept of inference only that which conveys what is connected, there is no overextension, such as the consequence that the sense faculty and the knowledge of the relation of invariable concomitance would be inference for others.

analyzed: tayoḥ sakta saṃsūcaka tva abhāvāt iti
translated: Because they do not indicate what is already known.

analyzed: sva artha anumanam nirūpayati tatra sva artham iti
translated: In the definition of inference for oneself, it is said for oneself.

analyzed: tri rūpa liṅga janyam anumeya artha vijñānam sva artha anumānam iti yāvat
translated: Inference for oneself is the cognition of the inferred object produced by a reason with three characteristics.

analyzed: kim tat anumeya artha vijñānam
translated: What is that cognition of the inferred object?

analyzed: yat tri rūpa liṅga jñānāt bhavati tat āha tat ca iti  dharmi viśeṣa iti
translated: It is said to be that which arises from the knowledge of a reason with three characteristics.🔽In the particular subject means:

analyzed: dharmi viśeṣaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: The particular subject is the thesis.
The ascertainment of the invariable concomitance of the probandum.

analyzed: liṅge iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is in the reason.

original: sapakṣeṣu saṃbaddhaṃ vipakṣebhyo vyāvṛttaṃ pakṣe ca saṃbaddhaṃ liṅgaṃ paśyataḥ pakṣāṃśena bhavati liṅge sādhyāvinābhāvitvaniścaya iti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: sapakṣeṣu saṃbaddham vipakṣebhyaḥ vyāvṛttam pakṣe ca saṃbaddham liṅgam paśyataḥ pakṣa aṃśena bhavati liṅge sādhya avinābhāvi tva niścayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that for one who sees the reason related to similar instances and excluded from dissimilar instances, and related to the thesis, the ascertainment of the invariable concomitance of the probandum in the reason arises through the part of the thesis.

original: agnyadhyavasāya ityanye iti /🔽atrāgnirayamagnimānveti niścaya iti yāvat /
analyzed: agni adhyavasāyaḥ iti anye iti  atra agniḥ ayam agnimān veti niścayaḥ iti yāvat
translated: Others say it is the ascertainment of fire.🔽Here, it means the ascertainment this is fire, it has fire.

original: sāmānyamasya viṣaya iti tu pūrvamevoktam /🔽anumānalakṣaṇe trirūpaṃ liṅgaṃ prasaktam /
analyzed: sāmānyam asya viṣayaḥ iti tu pūrvam eva uktam  anumāna lakṣaṇe trirūpam liṅgam prasaktam
translated: But it was previously stated that its object is a universal.🔽In the definition of inference, a reason with three characteristics is implied.

analyzed: prasaktam trairūpyam nirūpayati saṃprati ityādinā
translated: The implied tripartite nature is being defined by now and so on.

original: tatra pakṣadharmatāsaṃjñakaṃ prathamaṃ rūpamāhaanumeye sattvameva niścitamiti /
analyzed: tatra pakṣa dharmatā saṃjñakam prathamam rūpam āha anumeye sattvam eva niścitam iti
translated: Among them, the first form called the property of the subject is stated as the mere presence in the object to be inferred is ascertained.

analyzed: kaḥ yam anumeyaḥ  āha parvata ādau dharmiṇi iti
translated: What is this object to be inferred?🔽It is said that the property-possessor is the mountain, etc.

analyzed: yadi api parvataḥ pratyakṣeṇa eva avagataḥ
translated: Although the mountain is indeed understood by perception,

analyzed: atha api na agni dharmā
translated: nevertheless, it does not have the property of fire.

analyzed: a toyam agnimān parvataḥ iti agni viśiṣṭa tayā bhavati anumeyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the mountain is to be inferred as qualified by fire, as the mountain has fire.

analyzed: tat idam jñāpayitum uktam parvate dharmiṇī iti
translated: This is stated to indicate that the property-possessor is the mountain.

analyzed: sati api trairūpye niścite tasmin na anumāna udayaḥ iti etat avagamayan āha niścitam iti
translated: Even when the three forms are present, if they are not ascertained, inference does not arise. Understanding this, it is said that they are ascertained.

analyzed: atra sattva grahaṇena iti
translated: Here, by mentioning presence,

analyzed: liṅgasya anumeya artha avabodhane sapakṣa sattva ādīni trīṇi bhavanti rūpāṇi aṅgāni
translated: when the inferential mark is in the cognition of the inferred object, there are three forms of the conditions, such as presence in similar instances.

analyzed: eteṣu anyatamena api vikalaḥ bhavati liṅga ābhāsaḥ
translated: Even if one of these is deficient, it becomes a fallacious inferential mark.

original: tatra pakṣasattvaṃ cedrūpaṃ neṣyate tadā'siddhe liṅgābhāse'tiprasaṅgaḥ syāttannimasāya tadrūpamupāttamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tatra pakṣa sattvam ced rūpam na iṣyate tadā asiddhe liṅga ābhāsa iti prasaṅgaḥ syāt tat nimasāya tat rūpam upāttam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If presence in the subject is not accepted as a form, then in a fallacious inferential mark due to being unestablished, there would be overextension. The intended form is included. This is the idea.

analyzed: sattvam eva iti ayogavyaccheda arthasya evakārasya prayojanam āha evakāreṇa ityādinā
translated: The purpose of the word mere in mere presence is stated by by the word 'mere', etc.

analyzed: pakṣa eka deśa asiddham udāharati yathā digambara prayogaḥ iti
translated: He cites an example of a fallacy where only a part of the subject is established: For example, in the argument of the Digambara (Jain).

analyzed: na sarveṣu taruṣu iti
translated: Not in all trees.

analyzed: yaḥ ayam hetutayā nirdiṣṭaḥ svāpaḥ patra saṅkoca lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: This sleep, characterized by the closing of leaves, which is indicated as the reason,

analyzed: sa sarveṣu taruṣu pakṣeṣu na asti
translated: does not exist in all trees, which are the subject.

analyzed: kecana hi asaṅkucita patrāḥ eva aharniśam
translated: For some trees have leaves that are never closed, either by day or night.

original: nānena sarveṣu taruṣu siṣādhayiṣitaṃ cetanatvaṃ siddhyet /🔽tasmāt pakṣaikadeśāsiddhaḥ asartyevakāre kasmiṃścittarau vivakṣitasya svāpasya sattvādatiprasaṅgaḥ syāt /🔽evakāreṇa pakṣe'sattvasya vyavacchedānnātiprasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na anena sarveṣu taruṣu siṣādhayiṣitam cetana tvam siddhyet  tasmāt pakṣa eka deśa asiddhaḥ asarti evakāre kasmiṃścid tarau vivakṣitasya svāpasya sattvāt atiprasaṅgaḥ syāt  eva kāreṇa pakṣe sattvasya vyavacchedāt na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: By this (reason), the property to be proved, sentience, cannot be established in all trees.🔽Therefore, it is not established in part of the subject. If the word 'only' were used, it would lead to an overextension, because sleep, which is intended in some tree, would exist.🔽The idea is that by the word 'only', the non-existence in the subject is excluded, so there is no overextension.

analyzed: niścitam iti asya prayojanam āha niścita grahaṇena iti
translated: He states the purpose of the word 'certain': By the word 'certain', etc.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ asti nāma parvate dhūmaḥ
translated: The idea is this: There is smoke on the mountain.

original: paśyato'sya taṃ dhūmo vā bāṣpo veti yadā saṃśayo'bhūt /
analyzed: paśyataḥ asya tam dhūmaḥ vā bāṣpaḥ vā iti yadā saṃśayaḥ bhūt
translated: When there was doubt in the mind of the observer as to whether it was smoke or mist,

analyzed: tadā ayam dhūma ādi tvena saṃdihyamānaḥ bhūta saṅghātaḥ sandigdha asiddhaḥ
translated: then this collection of elements, being doubted as smoke, etc., is an uncertain reason.

analyzed: bāspaḥ eva vā tayā sandigdhaḥ
translated: Or it is doubtful as mist.

original: atra pakṣasattvaṃ mātrajñātamiti bhavatyatiprasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atra pakṣa sattvam mātra jñātam iti bhavati atiprasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that here the mere presence of the reason in the subject is known, so there is over-extension.

analyzed: idam atra bodhyam liṅgena tri rūpeṇa bhāvyam
translated: This should be understood here: the reason must have three aspects.

analyzed: eka rūpa vaikalye api asat liṅgam eva
translated: Even if one aspect is missing, it is not a valid reason.

original: trarūpyāṃśe ced bhramastena jāyamānaṃ jñānaṃ nānumānaṃ bhrama eva /
analyzed: ced bhramaḥ tena jāyamānam jñānam na anumānam bhramaḥ eva
translated: If there is error in one of the three aspects, the knowledge arising from that is not inference, but error itself.

analyzed: ced saṃśayaḥ na bhavet eva anumānam
translated: If there is doubt in one of the three aspects, then inference would not be possible at all.

original: na hyakṣamiva sattayaiva liṅgaṃ jñānaṃ janayituṃ prabhavati /
analyzed: na hi akṣam iva sattayā eva liṅgam jñānam janayitum prabhavati
translated: For the reason cannot generate knowledge by its mere presence, like a sense organ.

analyzed: evam sthite kim liṅga lakṣaṇa vicāre niścaya pada grahaṇa vicāreṇa iti
translated: Given this situation, what is the point of examining the definition of the reason, by introducing the term certainty?

analyzed: sattva āśabdāt paścāt evakāreṇa iti
translated: After the word existence, by the word only.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ anumeyaḥ eva sattvam ced liṅgasya rūpam ucyeta
translated: The idea is this: if existence is said to be the form of the reason only in the inferable,

analyzed: pakṣāt anyatas vyāvartyeta
translated: it would be excluded from other than the subject.

analyzed: tathā asati sapakṣa sattvam rūpam aparam vyāhatam bhavati
translated: If that were so, the other form, existence in similar instances, would be contradicted.

original: tathā ca sati bhavatyasādhāraṇe sapakṣavipakṣavyāvṛtte pakṣamātravṛttāvasādhāraṇe'tiprasaṅga iti /
analyzed: tathā ca sati bhavati asādhāraṇe sapakṣa vipakṣa vyāvṛtte pakṣa mātra vṛttau asādhāraṇa iti prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: And if that were so, there would be over-extension to the uncommon, which is excluded from similar and dissimilar instances, and occurs only in the subject.

analyzed: atha dvitīyam rūpam nirūpayati sapakṣaḥ eva ityādinā
translated: Now he defines the second form, beginning with only in similar instances.

analyzed: iti vartate iti
translated: This is the meaning of iti (thus).

original: iti ca vartata ityarthaḥ liṅgasyedaṃ dvitīyaṃ rūpamapi vartata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: iti ca vartate iti arthaḥ liṅgasya idam dvitīyam rūpam api vartate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is iti (thus) also occurs. The meaning is that the second form of the inferential mark also occurs.

analyzed: tatra sattva grahaṇena iti
translated: There, by the mention of existence.

analyzed: a gṛhīte dvitīyam rūpam eva parityaktam
translated: When not grasped, the second form itself is abandoned.

analyzed: tathā asati śabdaḥ nityaḥ kṛtaka tvāt iti asmin viruddha iti prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In that case, there is over-extension in the contradictory case of The word is eternal because it is produced.

analyzed: kṛtaka tvam hi asti pakṣe śabde
translated: For, production does exist in the subject, in sound.

original: yadyapi tṛtīyaṃ rūpaṃ vipakṣe'sattvamityetanna viruddha iti na tatrātiprasaṅgāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api tṛtīyam rūpam vipakṣesattvam iti etat na viruddhaḥ iti na tatra atiprasaṅga avakāśaḥ
translated: Although the third form, non-existence in the dissimilar instance, is not contradictory, so there is no opportunity for over-extension there.

analyzed: atha api tad rūpam adhunā anupāttam iti abhipretya idam prayojanam uktam
translated: But even now, intending that form to be unstated, this purpose is stated.

original: saṃpakṣa eva sattvamiti dvitīyarūpagamyaṃ tu tat /
analyzed: saṃpakṣe eva sattvam iti dvitīya rūpa gamyam tu tat
translated: Existence only in the similar instance is understood from the second form.

original: upātte tu vipakṣāsattve sapakṣe sattvopādānasya asādhāraṇavyāvṛttiḥ prayojanam /
analyzed: upātte tu vipakṣa asattve sapakṣe sattva upādānasya asādhāraṇa vyāvṛttiḥ prayojanam
translated: But when non-existence in the dissimilar instance is stated, the purpose of stating existence in the similar instance is to exclude the uncommon [reason].

original: śabdo nityaḥ śrāvaṇatvādityatra pakṣamātravṛtti śrāvaṇatvaṃ vipakṣata iva sapakṣato'pi hi vyāvṛttam /
analyzed: śabdaḥ nityaḥ śrāvaṇa tvāt iti atra pakṣa mātra vṛtti śrāvaṇa tvam vipakṣataḥ iva sapakṣataḥ api hi vyāvṛttam
translated: In Sound is eternal because it is audible, audibility occurring only in the subject is excluded from both the dissimilar instance and the similar instance.

original: sattvaśabdātpūrvasminnevakāreṇeti sapakṣe sattvamevetyanuktvā sapakṣa eva sattvamityuktyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: sattva śabdāt pūrvasmin evakāreṇa iti sapakṣe sattvam eva iti an uktvā sapakṣe eva sattvam iti uktyā iti arthaḥ
translated: The word 'only' before the word 'existence' means that instead of saying 'existence only in similar instances', it is said 'existence only in similar instances'.

original: sattvamevetyuktāvayogavyavacchedena sarveṣu sapakṣeṣu sattvaṃ vivakṣitaṃ syāt /
analyzed: sattvam eva iti uktau ayoga vyavacchedena sarveṣu sapakṣeṣu sattvam vivakṣitam syāt
translated: If it were said 'existence only', it would mean that existence in all similar instances is intended by excluding impossibility.

original: tathā ca satiprayatnānantarīyakatvena liṅgena śabde'nityatvasādhanaṃ vyāhanyeta /
analyzed: tathā ca sati prayatna ānantarīyaka tvena liṅgena śabde nitya tva sādhanam vyāhanyeta
translated: And if that were so, the proof of impermanence in sound by the reason 'being a product of effort' would be contradicted.

analyzed: yat yat prayatna ānantarīyakam tat tat anityam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭa ādi
translated: Whatever is a product of effort is seen to be impermanent, like a pot and so on.

original: nahi vidyudādāvanityatayā niścate prayatnānantarīyakatvaṃ netyetāvatā tasyānityatvasādhakatvaṃ hīyate /
analyzed: nahi vidyut ādau anitya tayā prayatna ānantarīyaka tvam na iti etāvatā tasya anitya tva sādhaka tvam hīyate
translated: For when lightning and so on are ascertained to be impermanent, the fact that they are not products of effort does not detract from their being a proof of impermanence.

original: sapakṣeṣu sattvamevetyayogavyavacchedārthakaivakāragrahaṇe tu vidyudādau prayatnānantarīyakatvābhāvena tasya hetutvaṃ hīyate iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: sapakṣeṣu sattvam eva iti ayoga vyavaccheda arthaka evakāra grahaṇe tu vidyut ādau prayatna ānantarīyaka tva abhāvena tasya hetu tvam hīyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But if the word 'only' is taken to mean the exclusion of impossibility, in the sense of 'existence only in similar instances', then the fact that lightning and so on are not products of effort detracts from their being a reason. This is the idea.

analyzed: na vidyut vat iti
translated: Not like lightning.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādayaḥ sapakṣāḥ grāhyāḥ yeṣu laṅgam idam asti
translated: Similar instances such as pots should be taken, in which this reason exists.

analyzed: na vidyut ādayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Not lightning and so on. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atha tṛtīyam rūpam āha a sapakṣe ced ti
translated: Now he states the third characteristic: 'And in dissimilar instances, there is absence.'

analyzed: asattva grahaṇena iti  ayam āśayaḥ vipakṣe sattvam eva niścitam iti asmin tṛtīye rūpesattvam ced na upādīyeta
translated: By the word 'non-existence' [it is meant].🔽The idea is this: If non-existence were not accepted in this third form, 'mere non-existence in the dissimilar',

analyzed: a sapakṣe niścitam iti arthaḥ syāt
translated: it would mean 'ascertained non-existence in the dissimilar'.

analyzed: tathā asati viruddhasya idam rūpam
translated: In that case, this would be the form of the contradictory [reason].

analyzed: katham liṅgasya rūpam bhavitum arhati iti
translated: How could it be the form of the logical mark?

analyzed: etena viruddhe liṅga lakṣaṇasya katham atiprasaṅga āpādanam ghaṭeta
translated: By this, the objection that the characteristic of the logical mark would lead to over-extension in the case of the contradictory [reason] is refuted.

original: dvitīyasya rūpasya sapakṣe sattvasyābhāvāditi śaṅkā parāstā /
analyzed: dvitīyasya rūpasya sapakṣe sattvasya abhāvāt iti śaṅkā parāstā
translated: The doubt that the second form, 'existence in the similar', is absent, is thus removed.

analyzed: eva kāreṇa sādhāraṇasya iti
translated: By the word 'only', [it is meant] 'the common [reason]'.

original: vipakṣaikadeśavṛtteritiśeṣaḥ dhūme sādhye'gnau hetau sādhāraṇe'sti pakṣe sattvaṃ sapakṣe ca mahānasādau sattvam /
analyzed: vipakṣa eka deśa vṛtteḥ iti śeṣaḥ dhūme sādhya ignau hetau sādhāraṇeḥ sti pakṣe sattvam sapakṣe ca mahānasa ādau sattvam
translated: The remainder is 'occurring in part of the dissimilar'. In the case of smoke as the probandum and fire as the probans, the common [reason] exists in the subject, and exists in the similar instance such as a kitchen.

original: vipakṣe ca kvacit hrade'sattvaṃ ceti trayāṇāmapi rūpāṇāṃ sattvādatiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: vipakṣe ca kvacid ca iti trayāṇām api rūpāṇām sattvāt atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: But it does not exist in some dissimilar instances such as a lake. Since all three forms exist, there would be over-extension.

original: evakāragrahaṇe cāyogavyavacchedalābhāt sarvebhyo vipakṣebhyo vyāvṛttatvalābhāt vipakṣe'yogolake vahneḥ sattvānnātiprasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: evakāra grahaṇe ca ayoga vyavaccheda lābhāt sarvebhyaḥ vipakṣebhyaḥ vyāvṛtta tva lābhāt vahneḥ sattvāt na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But by mentioning the word 'only', since the exclusion of impossibility is obtained, since the quality of being excluded from all dissimilar instances is obtained, since fire exists in the dissimilar instance such as a heap of coals, there is no over-extension. This is the idea.

original: nanu sapakṣa eva sattvamityavadhāraṇagarbhaṃ dvitīyaṃ rūpamuktam /
analyzed: nanu sapakṣaḥ eva sattvam iti avadhāraṇa garbham dvitīyam rūpam uktam
translated: But the second characteristic has been stated as containing the determination that the presence [of the reason] is only in the similar instance.

analyzed: tat ca na sādhāraṇe syāt
translated: And that would not be in a common [reason].

analyzed: katham atiprasaṅga avasaraḥ na
translated: How is there an occasion for overextension? No.

analyzed: dvitīya rūpa antargata avadhāraṇa arthaḥ eva tu rūpam
translated: But the third characteristic is indeed for the purpose of the determination contained within the second characteristic.

analyzed: tat eva tu nirūpyate
translated: But that itself is being determined.

original: tat adhunā avadhāraṇāghaṭitameva tu dvitīyaṃ rūpaṃ bodhyam /
analyzed: tat adhunā avadhāraṇā ghaṭitam eva tu dvitīyam rūpam bodhyam
translated: But now the second characteristic should be understood as not containing the determination.

analyzed: niścita grahaṇasya prayojanam āha niścita graṇena iti
translated: He states the purpose of the word certain: By the word certain, etc.

original: vītarāgo'pi lokakalyāṇāyedaṃ vaktīti vadantaṃ vādiṇaṃ prayogeṇa nirasyati kaścitavītarāgo'yaṃ puruṣaḥ vaktṛtvāt rathyāpuruṣavat iti /
analyzed: vīta rāgaḥ api loka kalyāṇāya idam vakti iti vadantam vādiṇam prayogeṇa nirasyati kaścid a vīta rāgaḥ ūyam puruṣaḥ vaktṛ tvāt rathyā puruṣa vat iti
translated: Someone refutes by the application a proponent who says that even one free from passion speaks this for the welfare of the world. This person is free from passion, because he is a speaker, like a man in the street.

analyzed: ayam ca hetuḥ sandigdha anaikāntikaḥ
translated: And this reason is doubtful and inconclusive.

analyzed: vīta rāgā upi kim iti na brūyāt iti asti eva sandehaḥ
translated: There is indeed doubt, thinking Why would one free from passion not speak?

analyzed: yaḥ na a vīta rāgaḥ
translated: One who is not free from passion,

original: sa na vaktā iti upalakhaṇḍādinidarśanena vyatireke samarthyamāne bhavati saṃśayaḥ upalagvaṇḍasyāvaktṛtvaṃ kiṃ vītarāgatvakṛtamuta svata eveti /
analyzed: sa na vaktā iti upala khaṇḍa ādi nidarśanena vyatireke samarthyamāne bhavati saṃśayaḥ upalagvaṇḍasya avaktṛ tvam kim vīta rāga tva kṛtam uta svatas eva iti
translated: when the exclusion is being established by the example of a piece of stone, etc., there is doubt: Is the fact that a piece of stone does not speak due to being free from passion, or is it just by itself?

analyzed: tat vipakṣesattvam na niścitam iti sandigdha anaikāntikaḥ uyam
translated: The absence of the reason in the dissimilar instances is not certain, so this is an uncertain reason with a doubtful counter-example.

analyzed: etad vyāvṛttaye niścita padam iti bhāvaḥ  eva kāreṇa vipakṣa eka deśa vṛtteḥ ityādi
translated: That non-existence in the counter-example is not certain, so this is an inconclusive reason with a doubtful negative pervasion.🔽The word certainly is used to exclude this.🔽The word only excludes the reason that occurs in part of the counter-example.

original: idaṃ ca vākyaṃ 'niścitagrahaṇene'tyataḥ prāk 'evakāreṇa sādhāraṇasye'tyatraiva sthānamarhati /🔽iha tuevakāraḥ asattvagrahaṇātprāgeva 'asapakṣa evāsattva'miti kuto nopātta ityasya prayojanaṃ vaktavyam /
analyzed: idam ca vākyam niścita grahaṇena iti atas prāk evakāreṇa sādhāraṇasya iti atra eva sthānam arhati  iha tu eva kāraḥ asattva grahaṇāt prāk eva asapakṣaḥ eva asattvam iti kutas na upāttaḥ iti asya prayojanam vaktavyam
translated: And this sentence deserves to be placed right after the word certainly in the sentence by the word 'only' in 'only in the dissimilar'...🔽But here the word only should be stated even before the word non-existence as non-existence only in the dissimilar, and the purpose of this should be stated.

original: tacca dharmoddharācāryeṇo dāhṛtam'asattvavacanāt pūrvasminnavadhāraṇe'yamarthaḥ syāt vipakṣe eva yo nā'sti sa hetuḥ /
analyzed: tat ca dharmoddhara ācāryeṇa u dāhṛtam asattva vacanāt pūrvasmin avadhāraṇā iyam arthaḥ syāt vipakṣe eva yaḥ na asti sa hetuḥ
translated: And that has been quoted by the teacher Dharmottara: If this word 'only' were placed before the word 'non-existence', this would be the meaning: A reason is that which does not exist only in the counter-example.

original: tathā ca prayatnānantarīyakatvaṃ sapakṣe'pi sarvatra nāsti /
analyzed: tathā ca prayatna ānantarīyaka tvam sapakṣe api sarvatra na asti
translated: And thus, the fact of being the effect of effort does not exist everywhere even in the similar example.

analyzed: tatas na hetuḥ syāt
translated: Therefore, it would not be a reason.

analyzed: tatas pūrvam na kṛtam iti
translated: Therefore, it is not stated before.

analyzed: nyāyabim ṭī
translated: Nyāyabinduṭīkā.

analyzed: śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He objects: But is it not so?

analyzed: pariharati na iti pūrva vṛddhāḥ ityādi
translated: He replies: No, the elders... and so on.

original: ayamāśayaḥtridhā bhavanti vipakṣāḥ sādhyābhāvavān sādhyavadanya sādhyaviruddhaśceti /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ tridhā bhavanti vipakṣāḥ sādhya abhāvavān sādhya vat anya sādhya viruddhaḥ ca iti
translated: The idea is this: The counter-examples are of three kinds: having the probandum, being different from what has the probandum, and being contradictory to the probandum.

analyzed: tad anurodhena vyatireka avadhāraṇam api bhavati tredhā
translated: In accordance with that, the determination of the negative concomitance also becomes threefold.

analyzed: yatra na agniḥ na tatra dhūmaḥ
translated: Where there is no fire, there is no smoke.

original: yo niragniḥ sa nirdhūmaḥ yatrāgniviruddhaṃ jalaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ niragniḥ sa nirdhūmaḥ yatra agni viruddham jalam
translated: One who is without fire is without smoke. Where there is water, which is contradictory to fire,

analyzed: na tatra dhūmaḥ iti
translated: there is no smoke.

original: eṣu trividheṣvanyatamaniyamajñāpanāya punarupādānamiti bhāvaḥ /🔽yadvāsādhyahetvorniyamo hi sambaddhayoreva /
analyzed: eṣu trividheṣu anyatama niyama jñāpanāya punar upādānam iti bhāvaḥ  yat vā a sādhya hetvoḥ niyamaḥ hi sambaddhayoḥ eva
translated: The idea is that the repetition is for the purpose of indicating the restriction to one of these three kinds.🔽Or, the restriction of the probandum and the reason is only between what are related.

analyzed: saṃbandhaḥ ca tādātmyam tad utpattiḥ vā
translated: And the relation is identity or origination.

analyzed: yatra tad utpattiḥ vahneḥ dhūmasya
translated: Where there is origination from it, of smoke from fire,

original: yatra na vahnistatra na dhūma ityabhāvato bhavati vipakṣaḥ /
analyzed: yatra na vahniḥ tatra na dhūmaḥ iti abhāvataḥ bhavati vipakṣaḥ
translated: where there is no fire, there is no smoke. Thus the counter-example is by the absence.

original: yatra tu tādātmyaṃvṛkṣatādātmyaṃ śiśupāyāṃ tatra yo na vṛkṣaḥ sa na śiśupeti bhedataḥ /
analyzed: yatra tu tādātmyam vṛkṣa tādātmyam śiśupāyām tatra yaḥ na vṛkṣaḥ sa na śiśupā iti bhedataḥ
translated: But where there is identity, such as the identity of tree and shimshapa, there the non-tree is not the shimshapa. Thus it is by difference.

original: uṣṇo'yaṃ pradeśo vahnerityatra uṣṇaviruddhaḥ śītaḥ pradeśo bhavati vipakṣaḥ /
analyzed: uṣṇaḥ yam pradeśaḥ vahneḥ iti atra uṣṇa viruddhaḥ śītaḥ pradeśaḥ bhavati vipakṣaḥ
translated: In the case of This place is hot because of fire, the cold place which is contradictory to the hot place becomes the counter-example.

analyzed: yaḥ uṣṇaḥ sa vahnimān
translated: That which is hot has fire.

analyzed: yaḥ tu śītaḥ na sa tadvān
translated: But that which is cold does not have it.

analyzed: tad viruddha himavān iti
translated: And that is opposed to it, like the Himalayas.

original: teṣveteṣu vipakṣeṣu yathāyogyaṃ vyatireko bodhya iti vivekadyotanāya tṛtīyasya pṛthagupādānamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: teṣu eteṣu vipakṣeṣu yathāyogyam vyatirekaḥ bodhyaḥ iti viveka dyotanāya tṛtīyasya pṛthak upādānam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The third is separately mentioned to show the distinction, meaning that the negative concomitance should be understood as appropriate among these counter-examples.

analyzed: prayoga niyama artham iti kecid iti
translated: Some say it is for the purpose of regulating the formulation.

analyzed: para artha anumāne prayoge kārye niyama artham
translated: For the purpose of regulating the formulation in an inference for others.

original: anvayayirūpavat vyatirekirūpamapi yo dhūmavān so'gnimān yo niragnaḥ sa nirdhūma iti prayoktavyamityetajjñāpanāyeti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vyatireki rūpam api yaḥ dhūmavān saḥ agnimān yaḥ niragnaḥ sa nirdhūmaḥ iti prayoktavyam iti etat jñāpanāya iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Just as there is a positive concomitance, the negative concomitance should also be formulated as Whatever is smoky is fiery and Whatever is fireless is smokeless. This is the idea.

original: yadvāprayoge kartavye niyamajñāpanārthamayamāśayaḥprayoge hi anvayo vyatireko vā niyamavāneva prayoktavyo na tadvirahitaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā aprayoge kartavye niyama jñāpana artham ayam āśayaḥ prayoge hi anvayaḥ vyatirekaḥ vā niyamavān eva prayoktavyaḥ na tad virahitaḥ
translated: Or, the intention is to show the necessity of knowing the formulation when it is to be done. For in a formulation, either the positive or negative concomitance should be formulated with necessity, not devoid of it.

original: anyathā śyāmo'yaṃ tatputratvādityapi prayogaḥ sādhuḥ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā śyāmā uyam tad putra tvāt iti api prayogaḥ sādhuḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, the formulation This is dark because he is his son would also be correct.

analyzed: yaḥ tad putraḥ sa śyāmaḥ putra antara vat
translated: Whoever is his son is dark, like another son.

original: yastu na śyāmaḥ sa na tatputra iti anvayavyatirekayoḥ prayogasaṃbhavāt /
analyzed: yaḥ tu na śyāmaḥ sa na tad putraḥ iti anvaya vyatirekayoḥ prayoga saṃbhavāt
translated: But whoever is not dark is not his son. Because the positive and negative concomitances can be formulated.

analyzed: param na śyāma tva tad putra tvayoḥ asti kaścana pratibandhaḥ
translated: But there is no connection whatsoever between darkness and being his son.

analyzed: yat tayoḥ na prayojya prayojaka bhāvaḥ na vā tādātmyam
translated: The relation of employer and employed does not exist between them, nor is there identity.

analyzed: tad anvaya vyatirekau niyamavatoḥ eva prayoktavyau
translated: Anvaya and vyatireka should be stated only when there is a rule.

original: sati niyame dvayoranyataraprayoga eva tu paryāptaḥ /
analyzed: sati niyame dvayoḥ anyatara prayogaḥ eva tu paryāptaḥ
translated: When there is a rule, the statement of one of the two is sufficient.

analyzed: na ubhayam api apekṣitam iti dyotanāya pṛthak uktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that both are not required, and this is stated separately to indicate that.

analyzed: dharmottara ācāryaḥ ca idam āha tat ucyate ityādinā
translated: And the teacher Dharmaraja says this beginning with that is said.

analyzed: nyāyabim ṭī  liṅgam vibhajate tri rūpāṇi ca iti
translated: Nyāyabhāṣya.🔽He divides the inferential mark, saying and the three forms.

analyzed: trairūpya lakṣaṇa lakṣitāni liṅgāni tri prakārāṇi bhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the inferential marks characterized by the definition of the three forms are of three kinds.

original: trirūpāṇīti padaṃ vyācaṣṭetrīṇi rūpāṇi yeṣāṃ tānīti /
analyzed: tri rūpāṇi iti padam vyācaṣṭe trīṇi rūpāṇi yeṣām tāni iti
translated: He explains the word trirūpa as those that have three forms.

analyzed: prakāra bhedam āha anupalabdhiḥ ityādinā
translated: He states the difference in types beginning with non-apprehension.

analyzed: liṅgānām paryāya śabdān āha sādhanam ityādinā
translated: He gives synonyms for the inferential marks beginning with means of proof.

original: sukhapratipatteḥ prasiddheśca vibhajanakramavyutkrameṇa trīṇi tāni nirūpayatitatra kāryamityādinā prayogamukhena /
analyzed: sukha pratipatteḥ prasiddheḥ ca vibhajana krama vyutkrameṇa trīṇi tāni nirūpayati tatra kāryam ityādinā prayoga mukhena
translated: For the sake of easy understanding and well-known order, he describes the three in the reverse order, beginning with effect and so on, by way of application.

analyzed: kāryam liṅgam darśayati yatra dhūmaḥ tatra agniḥ iti anena
translated: He shows the inferential mark as effect by saying where there is smoke, there is fire.

analyzed: dhūmaḥ hi agneḥ kāryam
translated: For smoke is the effect of fire.

analyzed: tena idam kārya liṅgam ucyate
translated: Therefore, this is called the inferential mark of effect.

analyzed: kāryam bhavati hetoḥ gamakam
translated: The effect becomes the inferential mark of the reason.

analyzed: parārtha anumāne vaktavyam nyāya avayava vibhāga nirṇayam atra eva prasaṅgāt āha vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā saṃjñakam dvayam eva iti
translated: In inference for others, what needs to be stated is the determination of the division of the parts of reasoning. This is mentioned here incidentally. The two are only the pervasion and the property of the subject.

analyzed: atra pareṣām pakṣam nirasyan anuvadati anye tu ityādinā  nirasyati etat ca ayukta tyādinā
translated: Here, refuting the position of others, he repeats with Others, however, say... etc.🔽He refutes with This is not proper... etc.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ pratijñā iyam anupayoginī
translated: The idea is: the proposition is useless.

analyzed: nahi sādhana aṅgam pratijñā
translated: The proposition is not a part of the proof.

analyzed: nanu siṣādhayiṣitasya sādhyasya avabodhanāya tad apekṣā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is necessary for the understanding of the probandum that is desired to be proved,

analyzed: katham asambaddham abhidadhyāt śabdaḥ
translated: how could a word express something unrelated?

analyzed: na hi asti śabda arthayoḥ sambandhaḥ
translated: There is no relation between a word and its meaning.

analyzed: śabda pramāṇa nirākaraṇa avasare saṃbandha abhāvaḥ samarthitaḥ prāk
translated: The absence of relation was established earlier when the validity of words was being refuted.

analyzed: nanu vivakṣām avagamayati śabdaḥ
translated: But a word conveys the speaker's intention.
