analyzed: sādhya viparyaya bādhaka pramāṇena vā iti  sarveṣām eva ghaṭa ādīnām bhāvānām sattvena kṣaṇika tve sādhye sādhya viparyaye sthira tve yat bādhakam pramāṇam krama yaugapadya nivṛtti lakṣaṇam tena vipakṣe para abhimate vyoma ādau vikalpyamāne sati vyāptiḥ avadhāryate iti arthaḥ
translated: Or by a valid cognition that contradicts the contrary of the probandum.🔽When the probandum is the momentariness of all things like pots, etc., which are existent, the valid cognition that contradicts the contrary of the probandum, which has the characteristic of the cessation of sequence and simultaneity, by that, when the pervasion is ascertained in the case of the dissimilar instances accepted by the opponent, such as space, etc., which are being considered as either real or unreal, this is the meaning.

original: ayamāśayaḥsarvaṣāmeva bhāvānāṃ kṣaṇikatve sādhye sapakṣāsaṃbhavena yanna kṣaṇikaṃ tanna sat yathā parābhimataṃ vyomādīti vyatirekavyāptiravadhāryā🔽nanu satā kṣaṇikena bhāvyamiti ko'yaṃ niyamaḥ / /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ sarvaṣām eva bhāvānām kṣaṇika tve sādhye sapakṣa asaṃbhavena yat na kṣaṇikam tat na sat yathā para abhimatam vyoma ādi iti vyatireka vyāptiḥ avadhāryā 🔽nanu satā kṣaṇikena bhāvyam iti kaḥ ayam niyamaḥ
translated: The idea is this: When the momentariness of all things is to be proved, since there is no similar instance, the pervasion by the negative vyatireka is to be ascertained as follows: Whatever is not momentary is not existent, like space, etc., which are accepted by the opponent.

original: ghaṭādayaḥ santo'pyakṣaṇikā eva kiṃ na syuriti tu nāśaṅkanīyam /
analyzed: ghaṭa ādayaḥ santaḥ api akṣaṇikāḥ eva kim na syuḥ iti tu na āśaṅkanīyam
translated: But it should not be suspected that things like pots, even though existent, should not be momentary.

analyzed: yat u evam sattvam api eṣām mā bhūt
translated: Or let their existence also not be so.

analyzed: sattvam hi arthakriyā kāri tvam
translated: For existence is the capacity for effective action.

analyzed: artha kriyāḥ kurvat akhilam krameṇa yugapad vā kuryāt
translated: If it performs effective actions, it must perform all of them either successively or simultaneously.

analyzed: sthira tva bhāvānām ubhayathā api tat na ghaṭate
translated: But that is not possible in either case for permanent entities.

analyzed: tasmāt vyoma ādīnām iva avastu tā eva āpatet
translated: Therefore, they would fall into being non-entities like space, etc.

analyzed: atha teṣām vastu tve kṣaṇikaiḥ eva tar bhāvyam iti
translated: But if they are entities, then they must be momentary.

original: nanu vyomādisthirabhāvamanaṅgīkurvatāṃ mate vyomādervipakṣasyāprasiddhervipakṣe dharmiṇīti kathamucyate /
analyzed: nanu vyoma ādi sthira bhāvam an aṅgīkurvatām mate vyoma ādeḥ vipakṣasya aprasiddheḥ vipakṣe dharmiṇi iti katham ucyate
translated: But in the view of those who do not accept permanent entities like space, since space, etc. are not established as the counter-example, how can it be said that the property resides in the counter-example?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True,

original: atāpi nāsaṅgatiḥ na hyatra vaidharmyadṛṣṭāntenāvaśyaṃ vastubhūtena bhāvyam /
analyzed: na asaṅgatiḥ na hi atra vaidharmya dṛṣṭāntena avaśyam vastu bhūtena bhāvyam
translated: but still there is no irrelevance. For here in the counter-example of dissimilarity, it is not necessarily to be a real entity.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And thus it is said:

analyzed: tasmāt vaidharma dṛṣṭānte na iṣṭaḥ hetoḥ anāśrayaḥ
translated: Therefore, in the counter-example of dissimilarity, the reason is not necessarily to be based on a desired [entity].

original: iti / udāhṛtaṃ caitat kamalaśīlena tatvasaṃ / pañci /
analyzed: iti udāhṛtam ca etat
translated: And this has been stated by Kamalaśīla in the Tattva-saṃpradāya-pañcikā.

analyzed: trividha pratyakṣa anupalambhena iti
translated: By the three kinds of perception and non-perception.

original: pratyakṣaṃ cānupalambhaśca tayoḥ samāhāraḥ pratyakṣānupalambhaṃ tena /
analyzed: pratyakṣam ca anupalambhaḥ ca tayoḥ samāhāraḥ pratyakṣa anupalambham tena
translated: The combination of perception and non-apprehension is perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: tatra pratyakṣam eka anupalambhau dvau iti samudāyasya avayava bhedāt traividhyam
translated: There, perception and non-apprehension are two, so the threefoldness of the aggregate is due to the difference of components of the whole.

analyzed: pratyakṣa anupalambha lakṣaṇa kāraṇa trikeṇa kārya kāraṇa bhāva avadhārāt vyāpti avadhāraṇam iti yāvat
translated: The ascertainment of pervasion is due to the ascertainment of the relation of cause and effect by the triad of causes characterized by perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhā grāhakau anvaya vyatirekau
translated: The idea is this: positive and negative concomitance are the means of knowing the relation of cause and effect.

analyzed: tatra anvayaḥ pratyakṣeṇa gamyate
translated: Among them, positive concomitance is known by perception.

analyzed: vyatirekaḥ na upalambhena
translated: Negative concomitance is by non-apprehension.

analyzed: dhūmaḥ sati vahnau upalabhyate iti etat pratyakṣam
translated: Smoke is apprehended when there is fire - this is perception.

analyzed: asati na upalabhyate iti ayam anupalambhaḥ
translated: It is not apprehended when there is no fire - this is non-apprehension.

analyzed: ayam ca anupalambhaḥ prāk paścāt ca
translated: And this non-apprehension is before and after.

analyzed: utpatteḥ prāk kāraṇasya vahneḥ abhāvāt
translated: Before arising, because the cause, fire, does not exist.

analyzed: paścāt ca kāraṇe vahnau vinaṣṭe
translated: And after, when the cause, fire, is destroyed.

analyzed: evam pūrva apara kāla bhedāt anupalambha dvaividhyam
translated: Thus, due to the difference of time before and after, there are two kinds of non-apprehension.

analyzed: āhatya pratyakṣa anupalambha lakṣaṇa kāraṇa trikeṇa kārya kāraṇa bhāva avadhāraṇa dvārā bhavati vyāpti avadharaṇam iti
translated: In brief, the ascertainment of pervasion is by the ascertainment of the relation of cause and effect through the triad of causes characterized by perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: yadā dhūmaḥ tadā vahniḥ
translated: 'When there is smoke, then there is fire.

original: yadā na vahnistadā na dhūma' iti kālata upalambhānupalambhābhyāṃ traividhyamuktam /
analyzed: yadā na vahniḥ tadā na dhūmaḥ iti kālataḥ upalambha anupalambhābhyām traividhyam uktam
translated: When there is no fire, then there is no smoke.' Thus, the threefold [nature of the relation of invariable concomitance] has been stated in terms of the perception and non-perception of the effect and the cause in terms of time.

original: atha 'yatra dhūmastatra vahniryatra na vahnistatra na dhūmaḥ' iti deśata upalambhānupalambhābhyāṃ dvābhyāṃ militāste trayaḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvāvadhāraṇe kāraṇamiti bhavati kāraṇapañcakamityabhipretyāhapañcavidhapratyakṣamupalambhato veti /
analyzed: atha yatra dhūmaḥ tatra vahniḥ yatra na vahniḥ tatra na dhūmaḥ iti deśataḥ upalambha anupalambhābhyām dvābhyām militāḥ te trayaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva avadhāraṇe kāraṇam iti bhavati kāraṇa pañcakam iti abhipretya āha pañcavidha pratyakṣam upalambhataḥ vā iti
translated: Now, 'Where there is smoke, there is fire; where there is no fire, there is no smoke,' thus, those three [kinds of the relation of invariable concomitance] together with the two [kinds of the relation of invariable concomitance] in terms of the perception and non-perception of the effect and the cause in terms of space are the cause for the ascertainment of the relation of invariable concomitance between the effect and the cause. Thus, intending that there are five [kinds of the relation of invariable concomitance], he says, 'The fivefold perception is from the point of view of perception.'

analyzed: vyāpti avadhāraṇe kāraṇam ukta ka anavadhāraṇe doṣam āha vyāpti aniścayena aikāntikaḥ doṣaḥ iti
translated: Having stated the cause for the ascertainment of the relation of invariable concomitance, he states the fault in the non-ascertainment of the relation of invariable concomitance: 'The fault of inconclusiveness arises from the non-ascertainment of the relation of invariable concomitance.'

analyzed: ghaṭa vat iti
translated: 'Like a pot.'

analyzed: vaidharmya dṛṣṭāntaḥ yam
translated: This is an example of dissimilarity.

analyzed: ayam hetuḥ iti
translated: 'This is the reason.'

original: sādhyasya sapakṣeṃiścayāt vipakṣe sādhanābhāvasya sato'pi sādhyābhāvaprayuktatvāniścayāt jīvaccharīre sātmakatvasādhanāya paraiḥ prayujyamānaḥ saprāṇatvaheturasādhāraṇa iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: sādhyasya sapakṣe niścayāt vipakṣe sādhana abhāvasya sataḥ api sādhya abhāva prayukta tva aniścayāt jīvat śarīre sātmaka tva sādhanāya paraiḥ prayujyamānaḥ sa prāṇa tva hetuḥ asādhāraṇaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the reason 'having life' is inconclusive for proving that the living body has a soul, because the presence of the reason in the dissimilar instances is not ascertained, and because even though the absence of the reason in the dissimilar instances is present, the absence of the probandum is not ascertained to be invariably related to it.

analyzed: para matena āha aparaḥ ca asādhāraṇaḥ iti
translated: He states [the reason] according to the opponent's view: 'And another [reason] is inconclusive.'

analyzed: yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ śrāvaṇa tvāt iti
translated: As in Sound is impermanent because it is audible.

analyzed: pakṣa mātra vṛtti tvāt iti yāvat
translated: In other words, because it occurs only in the subject.

analyzed: ghaṭa vat ākāśa vat iti
translated: As in like a pot and like space.

analyzed: kramāt sapakṣa vipakṣayoḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: The positive and negative examples are mentioned in order.

analyzed: nanu yadi etat pramāṇam na iti
translated: If it is argued that this is not a valid means of knowledge,

original: yadanekagataṃ tadanekam anekavṛtti ca sāmānyam yat sat tat kṣaṇikam sacca vyometi vadadbhirasmābhiḥ sāmānyaṃ vyoma vā'bhyupagamya tatra darmaviśeṣasya sādhanāya neha vyāptiḥ pramāṇīkriyate /
analyzed: yat aneka gatam tat anekam aneka vṛtti ca sāmānyam yat sat tat kṣaṇikam sat ca vyoma iti vadadbhiḥ asmābhiḥ sāmānyam vyoma vā abhyupagamya tatra darma viśeṣasya sādhanāya na iha vyāptiḥ pramāṇīkriyate
translated: we accept the universal or space as something that exists in many things, is many, occurs in many things, is momentary if it exists, and exists in space, when we say this, we do not establish the pervasion here for the sake of proving a particular property in that [universal or space].

original: tayoranabhyupagamāditi cet kimartho'yaṃ vyāpyavyāpakabhāvopanyāsa iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tayoḥ anabhyupagamāt iti ced kimarthaḥ ūyam vyāpya vyāpaka bhāva upanyāsaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If it is argued that this is because those two [universal and space] are not accepted, the point is why is this relation of the pervaded and pervader mentioned?

analyzed: vyāpti smaraṇa artham iti  ayam āśayaḥ yat aneka gatam tat anekam
translated: For the sake of remembering the pervasion.🔽The idea is this: what exists in many things is many.

original: tasmāt anekagataṃ sāmānyamiṣyatā sāmānyamanekameveṣṭavyam ekaṃtaditi vadatā'nekagatamityetadvā parityājyam /
analyzed: tasmāt aneka gatam sāmānyam iṣyatā sāmānyam anekam eva iṣṭavyam ekam tat iti vadatā aneka gatam iti etat vā parityājyam
translated: Therefore, since the universal is accepted as existing in many things, the universal should be accepted as many only, by one who says it is one. Either this existing in many things should be abandoned.

original: iti paraṃ pratyaniṣṭe āpādayitavye'nekagatatvānekatvayorvyāpyavyāpakabhāve aniṣṭāpādakāṃśe'nekānugataikasāmānyavādinaṃ prati pradarśite ekatvaṃ vā parityājyaṃ /
analyzed: iti param prati aniṣṭe āpādayitavyena eka gatatva anekatvayoḥ vyāpya vyāpaka bhāve aniṣṭa āpādaka aṃśena eka anugata eka sāmānyavādinam prati pradarśite ekatvam vā parityājyam
translated: Thus, when an undesirable consequence is to be brought about regarding another, in the relation of pervaded and pervader between the many and the one, when the part that brings about the undesirable consequence has been shown to the proponent of the one general that inheres in the many, either oneness should be abandoned,

analyzed: aneka samaveta tvam vā na iṣṭavyam iti āpādanīya aniṣṭa aṃśaḥ smāritaḥ bhavet
translated: or inherence in the many should not be accepted. The undesirable part to be brought about would be recalled.

original: yathā katipayavahnidhūmavyaktīnāṃ katipayasthāneṣu yathā mahānasa ityekāṃśabodhane sakalavahnidhūmayoravinābhāva upapādyaḥ smārito bhavati tatheti
analyzed: yathā katipaya vahni dhūma vyaktīnām katipaya sthāneṣu yathā mahānase iti eka aṃśa bodhane sakala vahni dhūmayoḥ avinābhāvaḥ upapādyaḥ smāritaḥ bhavati tathā iti
translated: Just as when a few individual fires and smokes are cognized in a few places, such as a kitchen, the invariable concomitance between all fires and smokes should be established and recalled.

analyzed: idam ca aniṣṭa āpādanam para abhimata sāmānya pratiṣedha artham paryavasyati iti
translated: And this undesirable consequence concludes with the aim of negating the general accepted by the opponent.

original: vādineti / vijigīṣukathāyāṃ vādinā svapakṣasthāpanāya prayogaḥ kartavyaḥ /
analyzed: vādinā iti vijigīṣu kathāyām vādinā sva pakṣa sthāpanāya prayogaḥ kartavyaḥ
translated: The word by the proponent means that in a debate for victory, the proponent should make an argument to establish their own position.

analyzed: svārtha parārtha anumāna nirūpaṇena tatra yat jñātavyam tat avabodhitam bhavati
translated: By the examination of inference for oneself and for others, what needs to be known there has been understood.

analyzed: atha para ukta hetau doṣa udbhāvanam vidheyam
translated: Now, the fault in the reason stated by the opponent should be pointed out.

original: tadavabodhanāyāyamupakrama iti hetvābhāsanirūpaṇe saṅgatiḥ pradarśitā bhavati /
analyzed: tad avabodhanāya ayam upakramaḥ iti hetvābhāsa nirūpaṇe saṅgatiḥ pradarśitā bhavati
translated: The connection is shown in the definition of fallacious reasons, by saying that this is the introduction to the explanation of that.

analyzed: nyūna tā ādi uktiḥ iti  nyūna tā hetoḥ avaśya apekṣite rūpa traye nyatamasya nyūna tā
translated: The statement of deficiency, etc.🔽Deficiency is the absence of any one of the three necessary aspects of a reason.

analyzed: sandigdha sādhya dharmaḥ hi iti
translated: For example, the subject is doubtful with regard to the property to be proved.

original: siddhasya sādhane siddhasādhanaṃ nāma nigrahasthānāntaramiti pare /
analyzed: siddhasya sādhane siddhasādhanam nāma nigrahasthāna antaram iti pare
translated: Others say that when what is to be established is already established, the establishment of what is already established is a separate ground for defeat.

analyzed: trirūpam tu liṅgam
translated: But the inferential mark has three aspects.

analyzed: triṣu anyatamam ca pakṣa sattvam
translated: And the presence of the subject is one of the three.

analyzed: pakṣaḥ ca saṃdigdha sādhya dharmā
translated: And the subject is doubtful with regard to the property to be proved.

original: sādhyaṃcenniścitaṃ sandigdhasādhyakatvābhāvena pakṣasattvasya rūpasyāsaṃbhavāt hetulakṣaṇaṃ nāstītyasiddhāveva samāveśānna nigrahasthānāntaramiti
analyzed: sādhyam ced niścitam sandigdha sādhyaka tva abhāvena pakṣa sattvasya rūpasya asaṃbhavāt hetu lakṣaṇam na asti iti asiddhau eva samāveśāt na nigrahasthāna antaram iti
translated: If the property to be proved is certain, then the presence of the subject, due to the absence of doubt about the property to be proved, is impossible as a form, so the reason does not exist, and it is included only in the unestablished, so it is not a separate ground for defeat.

analyzed: hetoḥ anāśrayaḥ vyastaḥ hetoḥ vaiyarthyam nirastam
translated: The reason is not based on anything, and the reason is useless, are refuted.

analyzed: nahi sāmarthyam nāma svarūpāt anyat iti
translated: For what is called capability is not different from the essential nature.

original: samarthe vastuni sāmarthyaṃ nāma na vastusvarūpādbhinnaḥ kaścana dharmaḥ /
analyzed: samarthe vastuni sāmarthyam nāma na vastu svarūpāt bhinnaḥ kaścana dharmaḥ
translated: In a capable entity, capability is not a property different from the essential nature of the entity.

analyzed: vastu svarūpam eva tu tat
translated: It is just the essential nature of the entity itself.

original: tasminnasati vastveva netyuktaṃ bhavatīti hetorasāmarthye'vastutvameva tasyeti svarūpāsiddhāveva tasyāntarbhāva iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasmin asati vastu eva na iti uktam bhavati iti hetoḥ asāmarthya vastu tvam eva tasya iti svarūpa asiddhau eva tasya antarbhāvaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when that [universal] does not exist, it is said that the thing itself does not exist. Therefore, if the reason is not established, it is just non-existence. Thus, it is included only within the non-establishment of the property-possessor.

analyzed: yathā sarva gataḥ ātmā iti
translated: For example, the self is all-pervading.

analyzed: ātmā iti pakṣa nirdeśaḥ
translated: The word self indicates the subject.

analyzed: sarva gataḥ iti sādhya nirdeśaḥ
translated: The phrase is all-pervading indicates the probandum.

analyzed: tat iha bauddhasya ātmā eva na asaddhaḥ iti
translated: Here, for the Buddhist, the self itself does not exist.

analyzed: pakṣeṇa hi ubhaya saṃpratipannena bhāvyam
translated: For the subject must be established by both [parties in the debate].

analyzed: kim punar asya sarva deśa upalabhyamāna guṇaka tvam setsyati iti
translated: But how can it be established that it has the quality of being perceived in all places?

original: pakṣatayo'bhimatatasyā''tmana evāsiddhau taddharmatayā'bhimatasya hetoḥ kva siddhiriti kaimutikanyāyenāsiddhirityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: pakṣa tayā ubhimata tasya ātmanaḥ eva asiddhau tad dharma tayā abhimatasya hetoḥ kva siddhiḥ iti kaimutika nyāyena asiddhiḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: When the self, which is accepted as the subject, is not established, how can the reason, which is accepted as its property, be established? Thus, it is said that [the reason] is not established by the method of super-addition.

analyzed: pakṣasya asiddhim upapādayati tathā hi ityādinā  yat ca mānasena pratyakṣeṇa ātmanaḥ siddhiḥ iti
translated: In order to explain the non-establishment of the subject, [Dharmakīrti] says Thus... and so on.🔽And the establishment of the self by mental perception.

analyzed: tat nirasyati mānasasya api iti
translated: [Dharmakīrti] refutes that by saying Even for mental [perception]...

analyzed: satyam bhavati aham iti pratyayaḥ
translated: It is true that there is the notion I am.

analyzed: sa na kevalam aham iti etāvat mātra avalambanaḥ  gauroham
translated: But that [notion] does not depend only on I to that extent.🔽I am fair.🔽I am fat.

analyzed: sthūloham 🔽kṛśa ūham
translated: I am thin.

analyzed: gacchāmi aham iti sthaulya ādi bāhya dharma avalambanaḥ eva
translated: The meaning is that the notion I am going is based only on external properties like heaviness.

original: tasmādahamarthena tadanuguṇena dharmiṇā śarīreṇaiva bhāvyamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt ahamarthena tad anuguṇena dharmiṇā śarīreṇa eva bhāvyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that the self must exist only with the body, which is a property in accordance with that.

analyzed: bhāktaḥ yuktaḥ iti  bhākta tā āśrayaṇam eva yuktam iti arthaḥ
translated: It is proper to accept it figuratively.🔽The meaning is that it is proper to accept it only figuratively.

analyzed: skhalat vṛtti tva prasaṅgāt iti
translated: Because it would lead to the fault of having a wavering application.

original: āha ca kamalaśīlaḥ'yadyayaṃ gauṇaḥ syāt tadā skhaladvṛttirbhavet /
analyzed: āha ca kamalaśīlaḥ yadi ayam gauṇaḥ syāt tadā skhalat vṛttiḥ bhavet
translated: Kamalaśīla says, 'If this were figurative, then it would have a wavering application.

original: nahi loke siṃhamāṇavakayormukhyāropitayordvayorapi siṃha ityaskhalitā buddhirbhavati /
analyzed: nahi loke siṃha māṇavakayoḥ mukhya āropitayoḥ dvayoḥ api siṃhaḥ iti askhalitā buddhiḥ bhavati
translated: For in the world, when both a lion and a boy are superimposed as lions, the cognition of both as lions does not occur without wavering.

original: madīyāḥ śarīrādaya iti vyatirekadarśanāt skhaladvṛttirahaṃkāraḥ śarīrādiriti cenna /
analyzed: madīyāḥ śarīra ādayaḥ iti vyatireka darśanāt skhalat vṛttiḥ ahaṃkāraḥ śarīra ādiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the notion of 'I' has a wavering application to the body etc. because the distinction 'my body etc.' is seen, that is not so.

original: ātmanyapi skhaladvṛttitvaprasaṅgāt /🔽tatrāpi hi madīya ātmeti vyatireko dṛśyate /
analyzed: ātmani api skhalat vṛtti tva prasaṅgāt  tatra api hi madīyaḥ ātmā iti vyatirekaḥ dṛśyate
translated: Because it would lead to the fault of having a wavering application even to the self.🔽For there also, the distinction 'my self' is seen.

analyzed: kalpitaḥ utra bhedaḥ iti ced itaratra api samānam astu
translated: If it is argued that the difference is imagined here, then let it be the same in the other case also.'

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tatvasam pañci  kārya svabhāva liṅga abhāvāt iti
translated: In the Tattva-saṃ. paṃ.🔽Because there is no inference from effect or nature.

analyzed: kāryasya svabhāvasya vā liṅgasya abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is because there is no effect or nature as the inferential mark.

analyzed: tayoḥ abhāvam eva upapādayati nitya parokṣeṇa ityādinā
translated: He establishes the non-existence of those [two] with By what is eternal and imperceptible, etc.

analyzed: sati tasmin idam kāryam
translated: When that exists, this is the effect.

original: asati ca tasminnedaṃ ityanvayavyatirekasacāradarśane hi tasyedaṃ kāryamiti vijñāyeta /
analyzed: asati ca tasmin na idam iti anvaya vyatireka sacāra darśane hi tasya idam kāryam iti vijñāyeta
translated: And when that does not exist, this is not. When the concomitance and non-concomitance are seen, it would be known that this is the effect of that.

analyzed: nitya tayā parokṣa tayā ca abhyupagatasya deśa kāla pariccheda abhāvena anvaya tireka upalambha abhāvāt na kārya liṅga siddhiḥ
translated: But for what is accepted as eternal and imperceptible, due to the absence of spatial and temporal determination, there is no possibility of observing concomitance and non-concomitance, so the inference based on effect cannot be established.

original: ātmana evāsiddheḥ kaḥ svabhāvaliṅgasya prasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ eva asiddheḥ kaḥ svabhāva liṅgasya prasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Since the self itself is not established, what is the possibility of the inference based on nature? This is the point.

analyzed: anyeta api liṅgena iti
translated: And by the other inference,

original: jīvaccharīraṃ sātmakaṃ prāṇādimattvāditi yadanumānaṃ pradarśitaṃ tatra sādhyasyātmano'siddhatayā na tena hetorvyāptirniścīyeteti na tadanumānamātmasādhanāya prabhavatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: jīvat śarīram sātmakam prāṇa ādimat tvāt iti yat anumānam pradarśitam tatra sādhyasya ātmanaḥ usiddhatayā na tena hetoḥ vyāptiḥ niścīyeta iti na tat anumānam ātma sādhanāya prabhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The inference that has been shown, that the living body has a self because it has life and so on, since the probandum, the self, is not established, the pervasion of the reason by that is not ascertained, so that inference is not capable of proving the self. This is the point.

analyzed: na kā api vipratipattiḥ iti
translated: There is no disagreement at all,

original: asmadabhyupagatā kṣaṇikavijñānadhīreva bhavatā''tmeti śabdāntareṇa vyavahriyata iti nātra no vipratipattiriti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: asmad abhyupagatā kṣaṇika vijñāna dhīḥ eva bhavatā ātmā iti śabda antareṇa vyavahriyate iti na atra naḥ vipratipattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The momentary consciousness that we accept is simply referred to by the word self by you with a different name, so there is no disagreement on our part in this matter. This is the point.

analyzed: nanu vyāpti asiddhiḥ api dūṣaṇam iti
translated: But is not the non-establishment of pervasion also a fault?

original: sopādhikatvena vyāpyatvāsiddhiriti pararasiddhāvantarbhāvyamānā yā vyāpyatvāsiddhiḥ sā kuto nokteti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: sopādhika tvena vyāpya tva asiddhiḥ iti para rasiddhau antarbhāvyamānā yā vyāpya tva asiddhiḥ sā kutas nā uktā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that why is not the non-establishment of pervasion included in the opponent's non-establishment, which is the non-establishment of pervasion due to the presence of a limiting condition?

analyzed: na sva lakṣaṇābhyām iti
translated: Not by the individual characteristics.

analyzed: sarvam eva hi vastu svalakṣaṇam
translated: For every existent is an individual characteristic.

analyzed: svam eva lakṣaṇam yasya tat
translated: That which has its own characteristic is that.

analyzed: na anyena anugatena sāmānyena lakṣyate
translated: It is not characterized by another universal that is not followed.

analyzed: tasmāt sarvam eva kṣaṇikam tad tad vyakti lakṣaṇam eva
translated: Therefore, everything is momentary, characterized by that and that individual.

original: tāsāṃ ca tattadvyaktīnāṃ deśakālabhedena paricchedena paricchinnatayā tattadvayaktīnāmeva sāhacaryagrahāt sāmānyānavalambhinī vyāptirnaiva siddhayet
analyzed: tāsām ca tad tad vyaktīnām deśa kāla bhedena paricchedena paricchinna tayā tad tad vayaktīnām eva sāhacarya grahāt sāmānya anavalambhinī vyāptiḥ nā eva siddhayet
translated: And since those individual things are delimited by being delimited by the difference of place and time, the pervasion that does not apprehend the universal would not be established at all, because the concomitance of those individual things is grasped.

analyzed: sāmānya mukhena eva hi vyāptiḥ grāhyā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the pervasion is to be grasped only through the universal.

analyzed: tatra yadi sādhanam sādhyena vyāptam ityādi
translated: There, if it is said that the reason is pervaded by the probandum, etc.

original: upādhiparijñānapūrvakaṃ vā'nyathā vā sādhane sādhyavyāptyuparodhagrahe syādevānaikāntikateti vyabhicāronnāyakatāmātreṇa na doṣāntarateti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: upādhi parijñāna pūrvakam vā anyathā vā sādhane sādhya vyāpti uparodha grahe syāt evā anaikāntika tā iti vyabhicāra unnāyaka tā mātreṇa na doṣa antara tā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Or, whether it is preceded by the knowledge of the limiting condition or not, when there is the apprehension of the contradiction of the pervasion of the probandum by the reason, there would be the fallacy of being inconclusive. The idea is that it is not another fault merely by pointing out the fallacy.

original: nanu sāmānyamanabhupagacchatāṃ sāmānyamukhenaiva vyāptigraha ityetat kathaṃ syāditi śaṅkatenānvatyādinā /
analyzed: nanu sāmānyam anabhupagacchatām sāmānya mukhena eva vyāpti grahaḥ iti etat katham syāt iti śaṅkatena anu ati ādinā
translated: But how can it be that for those who do not accept universals, the comprehension of pervasion is only through universals? This is suspected with But how is this possible?.

analyzed: samādhattena eva doṣaḥ iti
translated: He answers with The same fault applies.

analyzed: nanu apohaḥ iti saṃjñā bheda mātram
translated: But isn't apoha just a difference in name?

original: anekānugataṃ tvabhyupagamyate tvayā'pītyāśaṅkāṃ pariharannāhananu ko'yamapoho nāmetyādinā /🔽bāhya eveti /
analyzed: aneka anugatam tu abhyupagamyate tvayā api iti āśaṅkām pariharan āha nanu kaḥ yam apohaḥ nāma ityādinā  bāhye eva iti
translated: Isn't it accepted by you too as something that pervades many? To remove this doubt, he says But what is this thing called apoha? and so on.

analyzed: yaḥ abhyupagataḥ bāhyaḥ gavādiḥ saḥ eva
translated: Only external means only that which is accepted as external, like a cow and so on, that is itself.

analyzed: na anyat sāmānyam paraiḥ iva iṣyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: It is not a different universal, like that postulated by others. This is the meaning.

analyzed: apohaḥ ca paryudāsataḥ prasajya pratiṣedhataḥ ca bhavati dvedhā
translated: And apoha is of two kinds: as a determination and as a negation.

analyzed: paryudāsaḥ ca bhavati dvedhā artha ātmā buddhi ātmā ca iti
translated: And determination is also of two kinds: as the essence of an object and as the essence of an idea.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And it is said thus:

analyzed: tathā hi dvividha upohaḥ paryudāsa niṣedhataḥ
translated: Thus, apoha is of two kinds: as a determination and as a negation.

analyzed: dvividhaḥ paryudāsaḥ api buddhi ātma artha ātma bhedataḥ
translated: And determination is also of two kinds: as the essence of an idea and as the essence of an object.

analyzed: iti tatvasam
translated: Thus it is said in the Tattva-samgraha.

analyzed: tatra prathamam artha ātma ātmakam apoham vyācaṣṭe apohyetan yasmāt iti
translated: There, he first explains the apoha that has the essence of an object: It is to be excluded from another.

original: anyasmāt mahiṣāderanyad vijātīyaṃ śābaleyādi apohyate vyāvartyate iti seyaṃ vyāvṛttirapohaḥ /
analyzed: anyasmāt mahiṣa ādeḥ anyat vijātīyam śābaleya ādi apohyate vyāvartyate iti sā iyam vyāvṛttiḥ apohaḥ
translated: Another, of a different species, such as a Shabaleya, is excluded, i.e., set apart, from a Mahisha and so on. This exclusion is the Apoha.

analyzed: sā ca iyam vyāvṛttiḥ śābaleya ādi ātmā eva
translated: And this exclusion is of the nature of the Shabaleya and so on.

analyzed: abhāvasya avastu tva ādinī arthaḥ  yadi api na śābaleya ātmā bāhuleyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that negation is not a real entity, and so on.🔽Although the Bahuleya is not of the nature of the Shabaleya,

analyzed: navā bāhuleya ātmā śābaleyaḥ
translated: nor is the Shabaleya of the nature of the Bahuleya,

analyzed: atha api ubhau api ago nivṛtti ātmānau tu
translated: nevertheless, both are of the nature of the exclusion of non-cow.

original: anūditaṃ caitat /🔽yadrūpaṃ śābaleyasya bāhuleyasya nāsti tat /
analyzed: anūditam ca etat  yat rūpam śābaleyasya bāhuleyasya na asti tat
translated: And this has been stated:🔽That form which does not exist in the Shabaleya,

analyzed: bāhuleyasya yat rūpam śābaleyasya na asti tat
translated: that which does not exist in the Bahuleya,

analyzed: a tad rūpa parāvṛttiḥ dvayoḥ api samā matā
translated: the exclusion of that form is considered equal for both.

analyzed: iti
translated: The exclusion of that form is the exclusion of non-cow.

analyzed: apohaḥ ca artha ātmā buddhi ātmā ca iti dvedhā bhavati
translated: And Apoha is twofold: of the nature of the object and of the nature of the cognition.

analyzed: tatra prathamam artha ātmā uktaḥ
translated: Among them, the first, of the nature of the object, has been stated.

analyzed: atha buddhi ātmānam āha yathā pratibhāsam ityādinā
translated: Now he states the one of the nature of cognition, beginning with according to appearance and so on.

original: śābaleyabāhuleyādīn viśeṣān paśyataḥ svalakṣaṇairata eva mitho bhinnairapi tairyathāpratibhāsamarthapratibhāsātmā buddhāvākāra udbhavati /
analyzed: śābaleya bāhuleya ādīn viśeṣān paśyataḥ sva lakṣaṇaiḥ atas eva mithas bhinnaiḥ api taiḥ yathā pratibhāsam artha pratibhāsa ātmā buddhau ākāraḥ udbhavati
translated: The cognition of the cow, though having a form that is different from the forms of Śābaleya, Bāhuleya, etc., arises in the form of the object, in accordance with the appearance, due to those [forms] which are mutually different due to their own characteristics.

analyzed: saḥ ayam apohaḥ ucyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The form that arises in the cognition, consisting of the appearance of an object as it appears, even from those [cows] that are mutually different due to their individual characteristics, is called apoha. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu katham asmin apohaḥ iti saṃjñā
translated: But how can this be called apoha?

analyzed: tatra āha apohyate pṛthakkriyate smin iti uktam ca
translated: To that [the author] says: It is said that apoha is that in which something is excluded, i.e., separated. And it is said:

analyzed: eka pratyavamarśasya yāḥ uktāḥ hetavaḥ purā
translated: The causes that were previously stated for a single reflective awareness,

analyzed: abhaya ādi samāḥ arthāḥ prakṛtyā eva anya bhedinaḥ
translated: The objects such as cow and so on, which are naturally different from others,

analyzed: tān upāśritya yat jñāne bhāti artha pratibimbakam
translated: Relying on them, the reflection of the object appears in cognition.

analyzed: kalpaka īrtha ātmatā bhāve pi arthāḥ iti eva niścitam
translated: Even in the absence of the nature of the object in the cause, it is certainly ascertained as an object.

analyzed: pratibhāsa antarāt bhedāt anya vyāvṛtta vastunaḥ
translated: Due to the difference from a different appearance, of an object that is excluded from others,

analyzed: prāpti hetu tayā āśliṣṭa vastu dvārā gateḥ api
translated: Even though the cognition proceeds by way of an object that is not connected as the cause of attainment,

original: vijātīyaparāvṛttaṃ tat phalaṃ yatsvalakṣaṇam //🔽tasminnadhyavasāyādvā tādātmyenāsya viplutaiḥ //
analyzed: vijātīya parāvṛttam tat phalam yat sva lakṣaṇam  tasmin adhyavasāyāt vā tādātmyena asya viplutaiḥ
translated: That result which is the individual characteristic, which is turned away from the heterogeneous,🔽Or due to the ascertainment of that, being deluded as if it were identical with that,

analyzed: tatra anya apohaḥ iti eṣā saṃjñā uktā sa nibandhanā
translated: There, this name apoha is stated along with its basis.

analyzed: iti tatvasam
translated: Thus in Tattva-samgraha.

analyzed: darśitam ca artha ātmanaḥ svarūpam tatra eva
translated: And the nature of the essence of an object has been shown there itself:

analyzed: sva lakṣaṇe api tad hetau anya viśleṣa bhāvataḥ iti
translated: Even in the particular characteristic, it is due to the existence of the disjunction from others.

analyzed: atha prasajya pratiṣedha rūpam apoham āha yathātattvam iti  prasajya rūpa upohaḥ iti
translated: Now, he states the apoha which has the form of a non-implicative negation: As it is in reality...🔽The apoha is of the nature of a non-implicative negation.
The meaning is: the apoha has the form of a non-implicative negation.

analyzed: uktam ca etat
translated: And this has been stated:

analyzed: prasajya pratiṣedhaḥ ca gauḥ agauḥ na bhavati ayam
translated: The non-implicative negation is: this cow is not non-cow.

analyzed: ati vispaṣṭaḥ eva ayam anya apohaḥ uvagamyate
translated: This other-exclusion is understood to be extremely clear.

analyzed: iti tatvasam
translated: This is from the Tattva-sam.

analyzed: nivṛtti mātram iti
translated: Merely an exclusion.

original: na tu nivṛttaḥ sa hi paryudāsa iti yāvat /
analyzed: na tu nivṛttaḥ sa hi paryudāsaḥ iti yāvat
translated: But not an excluded thing, that is, an affirmation, is what is meant.

analyzed: prasajya pratiṣedhena hi apohanam avagamyate iti āha apohanam apohaḥ iti kṛtvā iti
translated: For an exclusion is understood to be the negation by a non-implicative negation, he says: Considering that the negation is an exclusion.

original: prasajyapratiṣedharūpāpohapakṣe gauriti pratītau kevalo vidhiḥ svalakṣaṇātmā viṣayo bhavatītyāgataṃ na tvapoha ityāśayenāśaṅkatenanvityādinā
analyzed: prasajya pratiṣedha rūpa apoha pakṣe gauḥ iti pratītau kevalaḥ vidhiḥ sva lakṣaṇa ātmā viṣayaḥ bhavati iti āgatam na tu apohaḥ iti āśayena āśaṅkate nanu ityādinā
translated: When the theory of exclusion having the form of a non-implicative negation is accepted, it follows that in the cognition cow, the object is only an affirmation having the nature of a particular characteristic, and not an exclusion. With this idea in mind, he raises the question beginning with But...

analyzed: samādhatte na iti
translated: He answers: No.

analyzed: yadi api prasajya pratiṣedha ātma apoha upohanam eva
translated: Even though the exclusion which has the nature of a non-implicative negation is only a negation,

analyzed: pratyaye viṣayaḥ tu tad viśiṣṭaḥ vidhiḥ eva
translated: The object is qualified by that [exclusion], and the injunction alone [is the object].

analyzed: na kevalam vidhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not only the injunction.

analyzed: ukta artha dārḍhya ārya pareṣām matam nirasyan āha yat tu iti
translated: In order to strengthen the stated meaning, refuting the views of others, he says but what is said...

analyzed: na gavātmā a gavātmā iti
translated: Not the self of a cow, not the self of a non-cow.

analyzed: gavā ātmā ayam
translated: This is the self of a cow.

analyzed: nāgava ātmā anāgauḥ  iti prasajya pratiṣedha lakṣaṇa upohaḥ sāmarthyāt arthāpatteḥ paścāt pratīyate
translated: Not the self of a non-cow, not a non-cow.🔽Thus, the apoha characterized by absolute negation is understood later by implication from the meaning, by force.

analyzed: prathamam tu vidheḥ eva vastunaḥ sva lakṣaṇasya eva iti arthaḥ
translated: But first, only the injunction, only the particular characteristic of an entity, is understood. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tat idam mata dvayam loka anubhava viruddham iti āha tat na ityādinā
translated: This pair of views is contrary to worldly experience. He says that is not so and so on.

original: nanu śābde vyavahāre gaurityeva śabda uccāryate /
analyzed: nanu śābde vyavahāre gauḥ iti eva śabdaḥ uccāryate
translated: But in verbal usage, only the word cow is uttered.

analyzed: na anya apoḍhaḥ iti śabdaḥ
translated: Not the word excluded from other.

analyzed: katham anya apoḍhasya śabdataḥ pratipattiḥ bhavet
translated: How can there be understanding of excluded from other from the word?

analyzed: anyaḥ śabdaḥ
translated: The word is one thing.

analyzed: anyasya arthasya tu pratipattiḥ iti katham iti āśayena śaṅkate yadi api iti
translated: But the understanding of the meaning is another thing. How is this? With this idea, he doubts with even though...

analyzed: apohaḥ eva śabda arthaḥ iti āśayena pariharati tathā api iti
translated: With the idea that exclusion alone is the meaning of a word, he answers even so...

analyzed: śabdāt artha pratipatti kāle eva apohaḥ api pratipadyeta iti etat draḍhayan āha yathā ca ityādinā
translated: In order to strengthen the point that the exclusion is also cognized at the time of understanding the meaning from the word, he says And just as... etc.

analyzed: pratyakṣasya iti
translated: Of perception means:

original: gāṃ paśyan puruṣaḥ sapadi nāyamaśva iti prasajyapratiṣedhalakṣaṇamabhāvaṃ gṛhṇātyeva /
analyzed: gām paśyan puruṣaḥ sapadi na ayam aśvaḥ iti prasajya pratiṣedha lakṣaṇam abhāvam gṛhṇāti eva
translated: A person seeing a cow immediately grasps the absence characterized by the negation of identity, thinking This is not a horse.

analyzed: pratyakṣam tu svayam vikalpa rahitam
translated: But perception itself is free from conceptualization.

analyzed: vikalpa utpādana śaktimat
translated: It has the power to produce conceptualization.

analyzed: vikalpa utpādana śaktimat tā eva tu vikalpa grāhi tā pratyakṣasya
translated: But the fact that perception has the power to produce conceptualization is what makes it grasp conceptualization.

original: ataeva bhavati gāṃ purataḥ sthitāṃ paśyataḥ sapadi nāyamaśva ityadhyavasāya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva bhavati gām puratas sthitām paśyataḥ sapadi na ayam aśvaḥ iti adhyavasāyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: For this very reason, it is possible for one who sees a cow standing in front to immediately ascertain This is not a horse. This is the point.

analyzed: tathā vikalpānām api iti
translated: So also of conceptual cognitions means:

analyzed: vikalpāḥ śabdāt jāyamānāḥ bodhāḥ
translated: Conceptual cognitions are cognitions arising from words.

analyzed: pratyakṣam ekam nāma jāti ādi kalpanā hīnam
translated: Perception is one kind that is free from conceptualization of universals etc.

original: anyat sarvameva jñānamanumānaṃ vā śābdaṃ vā bhavati vakalpātmakameva /
analyzed: anyat sarvam eva jñānam anumānam vā śābdam vā bhavati vakalpa ātmakam eva
translated: All other knowledge is either inference or verbal, and is essentially conceptual.

analyzed: teṣām eṣām śābdānām vikalpānām eṣā tad anurūpa anuṣṭhāna janana śaktiḥ
translated: These verbal conceptual cognitions have the power to produce action in accordance with them.

analyzed: anuṣṭhānam pravṛtti nivṛtti ātmakam
translated: Action is of the nature of engagement and disengagement.

analyzed: sā śaktiḥ eva apoha lakṣaṇa abhāva grahaṇam ucyate
translated: That very power is called the apprehension of the absence characterized by exclusion.

analyzed: apoha adhyavasāyaḥ iti yāvat
translated: It means the ascertainment of exclusion.

original: tasmāt gāmānayeti śabdaṃ śṛṇvataḥ puruṣasya sapadi bhavatyapoḍhādhyavasāyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt gām ānaya iti śabdam śṛṇvataḥ puruṣasya sapadi bhavati apoḍha adhyavasāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, when a person hears the word bring the cow, the ascertainment of the excluded [object] immediately occurs.

original: yathādhyavasāyaṃ ca pravartate /🔽ataḥ śabdānāmapoḍhe saṅketa iti susthitamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yathā adhyavasāyam ca pravartate  atas śabdānām apoḍhe saṅketaḥ iti susthitam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And he acts according to the ascertainment.🔽Therefore, the idea that words denote the excluded [object] is well-established. This is the meaning.

analyzed: śabda arthayoḥ vācya vācaka bhāva svarūpam avadhārayati tasmāt sthitam etat iti  adhyavasāyāt eva iti
translated: Having ascertained the nature of the relation of denoted and denotative between word and meaning, he says therefore this is established.

analyzed: apoha adhyavāsāyāt eva iti arthaḥ
translated: Only from ascertainment means only from the ascertainment of exclusion.

analyzed: śabdena bhavati adhyavasāyaḥ
translated: The ascertainment occurs through the word.

analyzed: tasmāt eva apoḍhaḥ bāhya arthaḥ śabda vācyaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the external object that is excluded is denoted by the word. This is the meaning.

analyzed: bāhya artha pratipatti ādhāyaka apoha adhyavasāya prayojaka tā eva śabdasya bāhya artha vācaka tā iti yāvat
translated: It means that the word's function of denoting the external object is only to cause the ascertainment of exclusion, which brings about the understanding of the external object.

analyzed: na tu sva lakṣaṇa parisphūrttyā iti
translated: Not by the manifestation of the specific individual characteristic means

analyzed: na pratyakṣeṇa iva sva lakṣaṇa parisphūrtti ādhānena iti arthaḥ
translated: not by bringing about the manifestation of the specific individual characteristic, as in perception. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tatra kāraṇam āha pratyakṣa vat iti 🔽atra āpta saṃvādam āha yat āha iti
translated: The reason for that is stated: because it is like perception.🔽Here he cites an authoritative source: What is said means

analyzed: avyāpṛta akṣasya śabdena śabda arthayoḥ vācya vācaka bhāva tattvam śāntarakṣitena nirūpitam
translated: The truth of the relation of denoted and denotative between word and meaning has been determined by Śāntarakṣita, by means of a word that does not engage the senses.

analyzed: tatra ayam prathamaḥ śabdaiḥ apohaḥ pratipādyate
translated: There, this first exclusion is taught by words.

analyzed: bāhya artha ādi avasāyinyāḥ buddheḥ śabdāt samudbhavāt
translated: Because the cognition that ascertains external objects etc. arises from a word,

analyzed: tad rūpa pratibimbasya dhiyaḥ śabdāt ca janmani
translated: and because the cognition that is a reflection of that form is born from a word,

analyzed: vācya vācaka bhāvaḥ yam jātaḥ hetu phala ātmakaḥ
translated: this relation of denoted and denotative becomes causal, having the nature of cause and effect.

analyzed: iti tattvasam pa
translated: Thus in the Tattvasaṃ.

analyzed: vyākhyātam ca kamala śīlena prathamaḥ iti  yathā ukta artha pratibimba ātmā
translated: And it has been explained by Kamalaśīla: 'The first' etc.🔽Having the nature of a reflection of the object as stated.

analyzed: yathā ukta arthaḥ ca paryudāsa ātmaka upohaḥ
translated: And the object as stated is exclusion having the nature of preclusion.

analyzed: tatra kāraṇam āha bāhya artha adhyavasāyinyā ityādi
translated: There, he gives the reason beginning with 'because it ascertains external objects' etc.

original: ya eva hi śabde jñāne pratibhāsate sa eva śabdārtho yuktaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ eva hi śabde jñāne pratibhāsate saḥ eva śabda arthaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Indeed, only that which appears in the cognition of a word should be considered the meaning of the word.

analyzed: na ca atra prasajya pratiṣedha adhyavasāya usti
translated: And there is no ascertainment of a negation by apposition here.

analyzed: kim tarhi
translated: Nor is there the appearance of the particular that arises from sense cognition. What then?

analyzed: bāhya artha adhyavasāyinī kevalam śābdī buddhiḥ upajāyate
translated: Only a verbal cognition that ascertains external objects arises.

original: tena tadevārthapratibimbakaṃ śābde jñāne sākṣāt tadātmatayā pratibhāsanācchābdo'rtho yukto nānya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tena tat eva artha pratibimbakam śābde jñāne sākṣāt tad ātma tayā pratibhāsanāt śābdaḥ ūrthaḥ yuktaḥ na anyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, that very reflection of the object, appearing directly in verbal cognition as having that as its nature, is rightly called the object of the word, not anything else. This is the idea.

original: yaścāpi śabdasyārthena saha vācyavācakabhāvalakṣaṇaḥ saṃbandhaḥ prasiddho nāsau kāryakāraṇabhāvādanyo'tratiṣṭhate /
analyzed: yaḥ ca api śabdasya arthena saha vācya vācaka bhāva lakṣaṇaḥ saṃbandhaḥ prasiddhaḥ na asau kārya kāraṇa bhāvāt anyaḥ atra tiṣṭhate
translated: And the relation characterized by the relation of denoted and denotator, which is well-known to exist between a word and its meaning, does not stand here as anything other than the relation of cause and effect.

analyzed: api tu kārya kāraṇa bhāva ātmakaḥ eva iti darśayati tad rūpa pratibimbasya atyādi
translated: But rather, it is of the nature of the relation of cause and effect. This is shown by the words of that reflection, etc.

original: tat adhyavasitabahirbhāvalakṣaṇaṃ rūpaṃ svabhāvo yasya tattathoktam /
analyzed: tat adhyavasita bahirbhāva lakṣaṇam rūpam svabhāvaḥ yasya tat tathā uktam
translated: That which has the nature of the form characterized by the determined external existence is said to be such.

original: tadrūpaṃ ca tat pratibimbaṃ ceti samāsaḥ /
analyzed: tad rūpam ca tat pratibimbam ca iti samāsaḥ
translated: The compound tattvarūpapratibimba means that form and reflection.

original: tasya tadrūpapratibambasya dhiyaḥ saṃbandhinaḥ śabdāt janmanyutpāde sati sa vācyavācakalakṣaṇo nirūpyamāṇaḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvātmaka eva jātaḥ🔽tathāhiśabdaḥ pratibimbasya janakatvādvācaka ucyate /
analyzed: tasya tad rūpa pratibambasya dhiyaḥ saṃbandhinaḥ śabdāt janmani utpāde sati sa vācya vācaka lakṣaṇaḥ nirūpyamāṇaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva ātmakaḥ eva jātaḥ  tathā hi śabdaḥ pratibimbasya janaka tvāt vācakaḥ ucyate
translated: When there is the birth, the origination, of that reflection, which is related to the cognition, from the word, that relation characterized by the relation of denoted and denotator, when examined, is found to be of the nature of the relation of cause and effect.🔽For example, the word is said to be the denotator because it is the producer of the reflection.

analyzed: tat ca pratibimbam śabdena janyamāna tvāt vācyam
translated: And that reflection is said to be the denoted because it is produced by the word.

analyzed: iti tattvasam pa
translated: Thus it is in the Tattva-saṃ.

analyzed: tattvataḥ sva lakṣaṇasya śabda vācya tve doṣam āha kiñca iti
translated: He states the fault in the real denotability of the specific individuality: and also, etc.

original: idaṃ ca śabdaprāmāṇyamanabhyupagacchataḥ svasamayaniṣṭhān prati pratipādyate /🔽ayamāśayaḥ yadi śabdasya tattvato bāhyārthavācakatā sākṣādiṣyeta /
analyzed: idam ca śabda prāmāṇyam anabhyupagacchataḥ sva samaya niṣṭhān prati pratipādyate  ayam āśayaḥ yadi śabdasya tattvataḥ bāhya artha vācaka tā sākṣāt iṣyeta
translated: And this [argument] about the validity of words is taught to those who adhere to their own conventions, by one who does not accept [the validity of words].🔽The idea is this: if the denotativeness of words with regard to external things were directly admitted as real,

original: tadā tasminnarthe śabdasya prāmāṇyāpātena śabdapramāṇato'vagatasyārthasya sattvaviniścayāt ' ayaṃ gaurastī' ti astipadaprayogo vyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tadā tasmin arthe śabdasya prāmāṇya āpātena śabda pramāṇataḥ uvagatasya arthasya sattva viniścayāt ayam gauḥ asti i ti asti pada prayogaḥ vyarthaḥ
translated: then, because of the validity of words with regard to that object, the existence of the object known by verbal testimony would be ascertained, and so the use of the word 'is' in 'this is a cow' would be pointless.

analyzed: na asti iti ca anupapannam iti
translated: And it would be impossible to say 'it does not exist'.

analyzed: upasaṃharati tasmāt na sva lakṣaṇam iti
translated: He concludes: therefore, the specific individuality, etc.

original: śabdaśravaṇasamantaraṃ yathāsaṅketaṃ samupajātāduktalakṣaṇādhyavasāyādbhavati bāhyārthāvabodhaḥ tasya sattā tu nāvagamyate /
analyzed: śabda śravaṇa samantaram yathāsaṅketam samupajātāt ukta lakṣaṇa adhyavasāyāt bhavati bāhya artha avabodhaḥ tasya sattā tu na avagamyate
translated: The knowledge of external objects arises from the ascertainment described above, which arises immediately upon hearing the word, in accordance with the convention. But its existence is not known.

analyzed: atas tat avabhdhanāya asti iti  uktam artham śaṅkā tad parihāra mukhena viśadayati nanu iti
translated: Therefore, the use of the word 'is' for the purpose of knowing that is reasonable.🔽He clarifies the stated meaning through a doubt and its resolution: But, etc.

analyzed: pratyakṣāt śābde vaiṣamyam āha pratyakṣyasya aniścaya ātmaka tvāt ityādinā
translated: He states the inequality between perception and verbal testimony: because the object of perception is uncertain, etc.

analyzed: vikalpasya tu iti
translated: But for an option,

analyzed: pratyakṣam hi sva lakṣaṇa mātram gṛhṇāti
translated: For perception grasps only the particular.

analyzed: na ekam api vikalpam anyat tu vikalpa viśiṣṭam eva
translated: But an option is different, qualified by something else.

analyzed: atas eva pratyakṣāt anyat viniścaya ātmakam eva iti
translated: For this very reason, it is said that inference is only of the nature of ascertainment, different from perception.

analyzed: śabdasya ced bāhya arthe sākṣāt vācaka tā
translated: And if a word has the power to directly denote an external object,

analyzed: tena tad artha avabodhaḥ viniścaya ātmakaḥ eva syāt
translated: then the understanding of its meaning would be of the nature of ascertainment alone.

original: tathā ca svalakṣāṇasya tadarthasya sattā tenaivāvadhṛteti na tadavabodhanāya astītipadāpekṣeti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca sva lakṣāṇasya tad arthasya sattā tena eva avadhṛtā iti na tad avabodhanāya asti iti pada apekṣā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And in that case, since the existence of the particular object, which is its meaning, is apprehended by that [perception] itself, there is no need for the word 'asti' to convey the understanding of that [particular object]. This is the idea.

analyzed: na kiñcid pramāṇam upalabhāmaha eti
translated: We do not find any means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: pramāṇa asaṃbhavam eva upapādayati tathā hi ityādi nā
translated: He explains the impossibility of means of valid knowledge with the words Thus, etc.

original: yā vyaktiryenendriyeṇa gṛhyate tanniṣṭhā jātirapi tenaivendriyeṇa gṛhyata ityeṣa pareṣāṃ svagoṣṭhīniṣṭhaḥ samayaḥ kevalam /
analyzed: yā vyaktiḥ yena indriyeṇa gṛhyate tad niṣṭhā jātiḥ api tena eva indriyeṇa gṛhyate iti eṣa pareṣām sva goṣṭhī niṣṭhaḥ samayaḥ kevalam
translated: This is the settled opinion of others, based on their own school, that a universal belonging to a particular individual is also grasped by the same sense organ by which that individual is grasped.

analyzed: na hi unmīlita nayanam paśyataḥ api puṃsaḥ nīla ādi varṇāt sāsnā lāṅgūla ādi sanniveśa viśeṣa lakṣaṇa ākṛteḥ ca anyat nayana pathā ivatarati
translated: For even a person with open eyes, when seeing blue and other colors, does not perceive anything other than the particular arrangement characterized by dewlap, tail, etc.

original: tat sāmānye na pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tat sāmānye na pratyakṣam pramāṇam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that perception is not a valid means of knowledge regarding universals.

analyzed: nanu mā bhūt sāmānye pratyakṣam
translated: But let there be no perception of universals.

original: athāpi gamekāṃ purataḥ paśyato'nubhūtānekagovyakteḥ puṃso bhavati kaścidekākāraparāmarśalakṣaṇaḥ pratyayaḥ /
analyzed: athā api gam ekām puratas paśyataḥ anubhūta aneka go vyakteḥ puṃsaḥ bhavati kaścid eka ākāra parāmarśa lakṣaṇaḥ pratyayaḥ
translated: Even so, when a person sees a single cow in front of him and has experienced many individual cows, there arises in him a certain cognition characterized by the apprehension of a single form.

analyzed: tatra ca ālambanam kim api nimittam kalpanīyam
translated: And in this case, some object as the basis must be imagined.

original: anyathā tadanupapattestadeva ca sāmānyamityāśayena pareṇa kriyamānāmāśaṅkāmanūdya nirasyatinaceti /🔽vyaktibhya eva svahetudattaśaktibhya iti /
analyzed: anyathā tad anupapatteḥ tat eva ca sāmānyam iti āśayena pareṇa kriyamānām āśaṅkām anūdya nirasyati na ca iti  vyaktibhyaḥ eva sva hetu datta śaktibhyaḥ iti
translated: Otherwise, due to its non-apprehension, that itself is the universal. With this idea, the opponent raises a doubt and refutes it, saying not so.🔽From the individuals themselves, which possess the power given by their own causes.

original: gavādivyaktayaḥ svahetubhyo jāyamānāṃ śaktiviśeṣaviśiṣṭā eva jāyante /
analyzed: gavā ādi vyaktayaḥ sva hetubhyaḥ jāyamānām śakti viśeṣa viśiṣṭāḥ eva jāyante
translated: The individual cows, etc. are born from their own causes, endowed with a special power.

original: yayā mitho bhinnā api gośabdābhilapyāḥ kāścideva vyaktayo gaurityekākāraparāmarśe hetavo bhavanti /
analyzed: yayā mithas bhinnāḥ api go śabda abhilapyāḥ kāścid eva vyaktayaḥ gauḥ iti eka ākāra parāmarśe hetavaḥ bhavanti
translated: By which, even though they are mutually different, some individuals that are denoted by the word cow become the cause of the apprehension of a single form cow.

analyzed: tasmāt na eka ākāra parāmarśa pratyaya upapattaye sāmānyam ālambana antaram kalpanīyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, in order for the cognition of a single form to be possible, a universal as another object is not to be imagined. This is the idea.

analyzed: bhinnānām api satām katham eka ākāra parāmarśa prati ahetu tvam iti atra āha bhede pi ityādi
translated: Even when different, how can they be the cause of a cognition with a single form? To this he says Even in difference, some are restricted.

analyzed: atra āpta saṃvādam āha bhede pi niyatāḥ kecid iti
translated: Here he gives an example of a reliable person: Even in difference, some are restricted.

analyzed: indriya ādi vat iti
translated: Like the sense faculties, etc.

original: indriyatvāviśeṣe'pi kāsāñcideva vyaktīnāṃ rupagrahaṇasāmarthyaṃ kāsāñcideva rasagranaḥasāmarthyamiti yathā niyataṃ tathetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: indriya tva aviśeṣe api kāsāñcid eva vyaktīnām rupa grahaṇa sāmarthyam kāsāñcid eva rasa granaḥ asāmarthyam iti yathā niyatam tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: Even when there is no difference in being a sense faculty, some individual sense faculties have the capacity to apprehend form, while some have the capacity to apprehend taste. Just as there is restriction, that is the meaning.

analyzed: ādi śabdāt harītakī ādayaḥ gṛhyante
translated: The word etc. includes harītakī and so on.

analyzed: nanu sati api sāmānya āśrayaṇasya āvaśyaka tve kim sāmānyena
translated: Even when the reliance on universals is necessary, what is the use of universals?

original: vyaktibhirevālam /🔽tāsāmeṣa svabhāvaviśeṣo yadekākārapratyavamarśahetutvamiti svabhāvāśrayaṇetottaraṃ pramāṇikavastvapalāpāyaivetyāśaṅkāṃ parihannāha kiñceti
analyzed: vyaktibhiḥ eva alam  tāsām eṣa svabhāva viśeṣaḥ yat eka ākāra pratyavamarśa hetutvam iti svabhāva āśrayaṇa itas uttaram pramāṇika vastu apalāpāya eva iti āśaṅkām parihannāha kiñca iti
translated: It is enough with just the individuals.🔽This is their specific nature, that they are the cause of a cognition with a single form. Therefore, by relying on nature, it would only be for the denial of a real entity that is established by means of valid cognition. To remove this doubt, he says Moreover...

original: ayamāśayaḥdravyādibhyo vyāvṛttaṃ bhinnaṃ sāmānyamatiriktaḥ padārthaṃ iti vadatāṃ mate jātivyaktyoratyantabhedo bhavatyabhimataḥ /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ dravya ādibhyaḥ vyāvṛttam bhinnam sāmānyam atiriktaḥ padārtham iti vadatām mate jāti vyaktyoḥ atyanta bhedaḥ bhavati abhimataḥ
translated: The idea is this: According to the view of those who say that the universal, which is distinct from substance and so on, is a separate category, it is intended that there is absolute difference between the universal and the individual.

analyzed: go tva aśva tva ādi tu sutarām bhinnam
translated: But the universal of cow, horse, etc. is certainly different.

original: evaṃ bhedāviśeṣe'pi gotvaṃ govyaktiṣveva samavaiti nānyatra /
analyzed: evam bheda aviśeṣe pi go tvam go vyaktiṣu eva samavaiti na anyatra
translated: Thus, even in the absence of difference, cowness inheres only in individual cows, not elsewhere.

original: aśvatvamaśvavyaktiṣveva samavaiti nānyatretyatra kiṃ niyāmakamiti śaṅkāyāṃ svabhāva evaiṣa gotvādīnāṃ /
analyzed: aśva tvam aśva vyaktiṣu eva samavaiti na anyatra iti atra kim niyāmakam iti śaṅkāyām svabhāvaḥ eva eṣa go tva ādīnām
translated: Horeness inheres only in individual horses, not elsewhere. What is the determining factor in this? The answer given by them is that this is the very nature of cowness etc.,

analyzed: yat na anyatra samavaiti iti svabhāva āśrayaṇena eva uttaram taiḥ api deyam
translated: that it does not inhere elsewhere. The answer is given by them only by assuming a nature.

original: tadasmān prati ko'yamākṣepaḥ svabhāvāśrayaṇenottaramasaṃgatamiti /🔽asmābhiḥ pratipādyamānaṃ svabhāvāśraṇenottaraṃ prāmāṇikaṃ paraiḥ pratipādyamānaṃ tvaprāmāṇikamityeṣa viśeṣa iti /
analyzed: tat asmān prati kaḥ yam ākṣepaḥ svabhāva āśrayaṇena uttaram asaṃgatam iti  asmābhiḥ pratipādyamānam svabhāva āśraṇena uttaram prāmāṇikam paraiḥ pratipādyamānam tu aprāmāṇikam iti eṣa viśeṣaḥ iti
translated: What is this objection against us that the answer given by assuming a nature is irrelevant?🔽The answer that is being presented by us by assuming a nature is valid, but that presented by others is invalid. This is the difference.

analyzed: sāmānya sādhaka tayā paraiḥ āśritam anumānam dūṣayan āha tathā idam aparam ityādinā
translated: Refuting the inference accepted by others as proving the universal, he says Thus, this other... etc.

analyzed: atra ucyate iti
translated: Here it is said.

analyzed: sādhyam vikalpya dūṣayati viśiṣṭa vuddheḥ ityādinā
translated: He criticizes the probandum by raising an option with The cognition of the qualified... etc.

analyzed: bhinna viśeṣaṇa iti
translated: Different qualifier means:

original: viśeṣyāt bhinnaṃ yadviśeṣaṇamviśiṣṭabuddhau viśeṣyatayā bhāsamānasya yadviśeṣaṇatayā bhāsate viśeṣyato bhinnaṃ /
analyzed: viśeṣyāt bhinnam yat viśeṣaṇam viśiṣṭa buddhau viśeṣya tayā bhāsamānasya yat viśeṣaṇa tayā bhāsate viśeṣyataḥ bhinnam
translated: That which is different from the qualified, which appears as the qualified in the cognition of the qualified, appears as the qualifier, different from the qualified.

analyzed: tad grahaṇa nāntarīyaka tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: being inseparable from the apprehension of that.

analyzed: prathama vikalpe dūṣaṇam āha vastu grāhiṇi pratyakṣe ubhaya pratibhāsa abhāvāt iti
translated: In the first alternative, he states the fault: Because there is no appearance of both in perception that apprehends the object.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya ubhaya pratibhāsa abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because there is no appearance of both the qualifier and the qualified.

original: gauriti yadvastupratyakṣaṃ tat piṇḍaṃ tato bhinnaṃ gotvaṃ sāmānyaṃ cobhayamavabhāsayatītyetat sarvānubhavaviruddham /
analyzed: gauḥ iti yat vastu pratyakṣam tat piṇḍam tatas bhinnam go tvam sāmānyam ca ubhayam avabhāsayati iti etat sarva anubhava viruddham
translated: The perception of the object called cow does not manifest both the individual and the universal cow as different from it. This contradicts all experience.

original: puraḥsthitaṃ paśyato hi sphurati vastumātramiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: puras sthitam paśyataḥ hi sphurati vastu mātram iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that for one who sees it in front, only the object appears.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram āha viśiṣṭa buddhi tvam ca iti
translated: He states another fault: If it is the cognition of the qualified...

analyzed: anekāntika tām upapādayati bhinna viśeṣaṇa grahaṇam antareṇa api iti
translated: He explains the inconclusive nature: Even without the apprehension of a different qualifier...

analyzed: yathā svarūpavān ghaṭaḥ iti
translated: For example, the pot that has its own nature.

analyzed: ghaṭasya svarūpam hi ghaṭāt na atiricyate
translated: The nature of the pot does not go beyond the pot.

analyzed: go tvam sāmānyam iti vā iti  na sāmānyam go tvāt anyat
translated: The universal 'cowhood'...🔽The universal is not different from the cow.

original: gotve sāmānyatvamiti ca na gotvato bhinnaṃ /
analyzed: go tve sāmānya tvam iti ca na go tvataḥ bhinnam
translated: And cowhood is the universal is not different from the cow.

analyzed: tad svarūpam eva tu tat
translated: But that is its own nature.

analyzed: dvitīya vikalpe dūṣaṇam āha dvitīya ityādinā
translated: In the second alternative, he states the fault with In the second... and so on.

original: siddhasādhanamupapādayatisvarūpavān ghaṭa ityādivaditi /🔽ayaṃ gauriti pratyakṣe vastuto vastumātragrāhiṇyapi svarūpavān ghaṭa ityatra kalpitabhedamādāya viśeṣyaviśeṣaṇabhāvopapattivat piṇḍādananyatve'pi gotvasya kalpitabhedamādāya viśeṣyaviśeṣaṇabhāvopapattyā arthāntaraprasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: siddhasādhanam upapādayati svarūpavān ghaṭaḥ ityādi vat iti  ayam gauḥ iti pratyakṣe vastutas vastu mātra grāhiṇī api svarūpavān ghaṭaḥ iti atra kalpita bhedam ādāya viśeṣya viśeṣaṇa bhāva upapatti vat piṇḍāt ananyatve pi gotvasya kalpita bhedam ādāya viśeṣya viśeṣaṇa bhāva upapattyā artha antara prasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: He explains the establishment of the established: Like in 'the pot that exists,' etc.🔽In the perception This is a cow, although it actually grasps only the entity, just as in The pot that exists, the relation of qualifier and qualified is possible by taking the imagined difference, similarly, even though cowhood is not different from the individual, the relation of qualifier and qualified is possible by taking the imagined difference, so there is the consequence of being a different object. This is the idea.

analyzed: gauḥ ayam iti anugata vyavahāraḥ tu a go vyāvṛttim eva avalambate
translated: As for the general usage This is a cow, it relies only on the exclusion of non-cows.

analyzed: sā ca vyāvṛttiḥ vyāvarttyāt na atiricyate iti āha ago vyāvṛtti anubhava bhāvi tvāt iti
translated: And that exclusion does not go beyond what is excluded, so he says because it is produced by the experience of the exclusion of non-cows.

original: evaṃ sāmānyasādhakatayā parābhimataṃ prayogaṃ nirasya sāmānyanirāsakaṃ prayogaṃ pradarśayatisāmānyasya niṣedhāyetyādināyadyatropalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptaṃ sannopalabhyate iti /
analyzed: evam sāmānya sādhaka tayā para abhimatam prayogam nirasya sāmānya nirāsakam prayogam pradarśayati sāmānyasya niṣedhāya ityādinā yat yatra upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptam sat na upalabhyate iti
translated: Having thus refuted the argument accepted by others as establishing universals, he displays the argument refuting universals, beginning with For the negation of universals, etc. If what is capable of being perceived is not perceived.

analyzed: upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptatve sati api anupalabhyamāna tvam hetuḥ
translated: The reason is being not perceived, even though it is capable of being perceived.

analyzed: hetoḥ asiddhi śaṅkām nivārayati na ca asiddhi saṃbhāvanā iti
translated: He removes the doubt of the non-establishedness of the reason, saying And when there is a doubt of non-establishedness...

analyzed: varṇa saṃsthāna sahitam iti
translated: Along with color and shape means:

original: satyapīndriyasaṃprayogādāvupalambhakasamavāye upalabhyamāne ca vyaktiviśeṣe tatra gotvaṃ vipratipannaṃ naivopalabhyate /
analyzed: sati api indriya saṃprayoga ādau upalambhaka samavāye upalabhyamāne ca vyakti viśeṣe tatra go tvam vipratipannam na eva upalabhyate
translated: Even when there is a conjunction of the perceiver in the case of contact with the sense organ, and when a particular individual is perceived, the cow-ness which is disputed is not perceived at all.

analyzed: upalabhyamānam vyakteḥ svarūpam tu varṇa saṃsthāna ātmakam
translated: But the nature of the individual which is perceived is of the nature of color and shape.

original: na tato'nyā gotvajātirupalabhyate iti nāsiddho heturiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na tatonyā go tva jātiḥ upalabhyate iti na asiddhaḥ hetuḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the universal cow-ness is not perceived apart from that. Thus, the reason is not non-established, this is the idea.

original: nanu darśanāgocarasyāpi jñānasyeva cākṣuṣopalambhāgocarasyāpi sāmānyasya nāsadbhāva ityāśaṅkāmanūdya pariharatināpītyādinā /
analyzed: nanu darśana agocarasya api jñānasya iva cākṣuṣa upalambha agocarasya api sāmānyasya na asadbhāvaḥ iti āśaṅkām anūdya pariharati nā api ityādinā
translated: Even though it is not the object of perception, like knowledge, the universal which is not the object of the visual perception, is not non-existent - anticipating this doubt, he replies with Nor is it... and so on.

analyzed: upakrāntam sāmānya nirasanam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: He concludes the refutation of the universal, saying Therefore...

analyzed: nā api iti prasakta anuprasaktyā prāptaḥ ayam vicāraḥ
translated: Nor is it... - this consideration has come up as a consequence.

analyzed: hetu doṣa nirūpaṇa prakaraṇe siddhi nirūpaṇa avasare sāmānya vicāraḥ prasaṅgataḥ prāptaḥ
translated: In the context of the examination of the faults of the reason, in the course of the examination of non-establishedness, the consideration of the universal has come up as a consequence.

original: sa ca prāsaṅgiko vicāraḥ 'tasmāt sarvaṃ saṃskṛtaṃ vastu paraparikalpitasāmānyena śūnya' miti samupasaṃhṛtaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca prāsaṅgikaḥ vicāraḥ tasmāt sarvam saṃskṛtam vastu para parikalpita sāmānyena śūnya miti samupasaṃhṛtaḥ
translated: And that incidental discussion has been concluded with the statement: Therefore, all conditioned things are empty of the generality imagined by others.

original: yathā saṃskṛtaṃ sarvaṃ vastu niḥsāmānyakaṃ tathā na kenāpyuparacitamiti prasaktamanuprasaktametat /
analyzed: yathā saṃskṛtam sarvam vastu niḥsāmānyakam tathā na kena api uparacitam iti prasaktam anuprasaktam etat
translated: Just as all conditioned things are without generality, it is implied that they are not imagined by anyone. This is a further implication.

original: nanu śākhācaṅkramaṇaṃ yat saṃskṛtavastunirdeśamanupravṛttirasmin vicāra iti /
analyzed: nanu śākhā caṅkramaṇam yat saṃskṛta vastu nirdeśam anupravṛttiḥ asmin vicāre iti
translated: But isn't the discussion here an extension of the teaching on conditioned things, like the wandering of a monkey from one branch to another?

analyzed: na etat
translated: No, that is not so.

original: ' yadi nityaḥ kartā jagato na kāraṇaṃ kimasya tarhi kāraṇam /
analyzed: yadi nityaḥ kartā jagataḥ na kāraṇam kim asya tarhi kāraṇam
translated: If the eternal creator is not the cause of the world, then what is its cause?

original: sattvānāṃ śubhāśubhākhyaṃ karma' ityādinā pramāṇanirūpaṇāt prameyanirūpaṇe'vatarato dvārametat /
analyzed: sattvānām śubha aśubha ākhyam karma ityādinā pramāṇa nirūpaṇāt prameya nirūpaṇā iva tarataḥ dvāram etat
translated: The good and bad karma of beings, etc. - this is the door to entering the discussion of the object of knowledge after the examination of the means of knowledge.

original: etena pūrvameveśvaro jagataḥ kartā nirasta iti punaruktametaditi śaṅkā parihṛtā /
analyzed: etena pūrvam eva īśvaraḥ jagataḥ kartā nirastaḥ iti punar uktam etat iti śaṅkā parihṛtā
translated: The doubt that this is a repetition because the creator has already been refuted as the cause of the world is removed by this.

analyzed: prakara antareṇa tad niṣedhaḥ utra pravartate iti
translated: The refutation is undertaken here by a different method.

original: tatreśvarasādhakatayā paropanyastasya prayogasya nirasanamiha tu tasya sargādikartṛtvānupapattiriti nirasanaprakārabhedaḥ /
analyzed: tatra īśvara sādhaka tayā para upanyastasya prayogasya nirasanam iha tu tasya sarga ādi kartṛ tva anupapattiḥ iti nirasana prakāra bhedaḥ
translated: The refutation of the argument presented by the opponent in support of God is done here by showing the impossibility of His being the agent of creation etc. This is the difference in the mode of refutation.

analyzed: tatra tāvat na nityaḥ yuktaḥ iti
translated: To begin with, He cannot be eternal.

analyzed: nityaḥ janana maraṇa śūnyaḥ
translated: Eternal means devoid of birth and death.

analyzed: asamarthaḥ
translated: He is incapable.

analyzed: atha api kartā iti vyāhatam
translated: If He is the agent, it is contradictory.

analyzed: atha samarthaḥ nityaḥ ca
translated: If He is both capable and eternal,

original: tadā tvayaṃ doṣa ityāhanityeṃ kartari samarthe satīti /
analyzed: tadā tu ayam doṣaḥ iti āha nitye kartari samarthe sati iti
translated: then this fault arises. He says: If the eternal agent is capable.

analyzed: tat asya svarūpam pralaya kāla ipi iti
translated: This is His nature even at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: nahi nityasya svarūpam kāla bhedāt bhidyeta
translated: For the nature of the eternal cannot be differentiated by differences in time.

analyzed: yadi bhidyeta
translated: If it were to be differentiated,

analyzed: tarhi anitya tā eva āpatet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: then it would follow that it is non-eternal. This is the idea.

analyzed: sarga ādīnām ayaugapadyasya saha kārya samavadhāna mūlaka tām āśaṅkya nirasyati
translated: Suspecting that the non-simultaneity of creation etc. is based on the non-co-existence of co-operating factors, he refutes it.

analyzed: sahakāri virahāt ityādinā
translated: With due to the absence of co-operating factors and so on.

analyzed: anityasya sahakāriṇaḥ api tad āyatta tvāt iti
translated: Because even the non-eternal co-operating factors depend on that.

original: kāryamātraṃ prati tasya kāraṇatvena sahakāriṇo janayanneṣa nityaḥ samarthaḥ kuto yugapanna janayatītīyamāśaṅkā tatrāpi tulyaiveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: kārya mātram prati tasya kāraṇa tvena sahakāriṇaḥ janayan eṣa nityaḥ samarthaḥ kutas yugapad na janayati iti iyam āśaṅkā tatra api tulyā evā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the doubt is equally applicable there also, that this eternal, efficient one, producing the auxiliaries as the cause of mere effect, why does it not produce simultaneously?

analyzed: nanu satyam eṣa samarthaḥ nityaḥ ca
translated: But it is true that this is efficient and eternal.

analyzed: param īśvaraḥ yam
translated: This is the supreme Lord.

original: satyāmicchāyāṃ kuryāt na cenna kuryāditi na sarvakāryayaugapadyaprasaṅga ityāśayena śaṅkatebuddhimatvādīśvarasyeti /
analyzed: satyām icchāyām kuryāt na ced na kuryāt iti na sarva kārya yaugapadya prasaṅgaḥ iti āśayena śaṅkate buddhimatvāt īśvarasya iti
translated: If there is true desire, he would create; if not, he would not create. Thus there is no contingence of all effects being produced simultaneously. With this idea, he doubts that the omniscience etc. of God.

analyzed: adhiṣṭhātṛ nirapekṣa pradhāna kāraṇa vāde sā iyam āśaṅkā avataret
translated: This doubt would arise in the doctrine that the primordial matter is the cause, independent of a ruler.

original: jaḍatvāt tasya /🔽cetanaṃ kāraṇamabhyupagacchato'smān prati tu nāsyāḥ śaṅkāyā avasara iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: jaḍa tvāt tasya  cetanam kāraṇam abhyupagacchataḥ usmān prati tu na asyāḥ śaṅkāyāḥ avasaraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Because of its inertness.🔽But for us who accept an intelligent cause, there is no occasion for this doubt. This is the idea.

original: icchānāṃ vā kuto na yaugapadyamityāśayenāha tā apīti /
analyzed: icchānām vā kutas na yaugapadyam iti āśayena āha tāḥ api iti
translated: Or, with the idea that the desires are not simultaneous, he says: those also.

analyzed: sahakāri lakṣāṇayā āgantuka śaktayā iti  ayam āśayaḥ satyam sahakāriṇyaḥ api etad āyattāḥ
translated: By the definition of auxiliaries, the adventitious power.🔽The idea is this: it is true that even the auxiliaries depend on this.

original: śaktasyāsyāsya śaktiviśeṣarūpāstāḥ ayaṃ ca nityaḥ samarthaśca sarvakāryorpādane /
analyzed: śaktasya asya asya śakti viśeṣa rūpāḥ tāḥ ayam ca nityaḥ samarthaḥ ca sarva kāryoḥ pādane
translated: They are in the form of special powers of this efficient one, and this one is eternal and capable of producing all effects.

original: athāpi tāḥ sahakārilakṣaṇāḥ śaktayastvāgantukyaḥ ataḥ sargādīnāṃ na yaugapadyaprasaṅgaṃ iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atha api tāḥ sahakāri lakṣaṇāḥ śaktayaḥ tu āgantukyaḥ atas sarga ādīnām na yaugapadya prasaṅgam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that even if those powers are auxiliary, they are adventitious, so there is no possibility of the creation etc. being simultaneous.

analyzed: sa ca nityaḥ  sāmarthyam ca asya avyāhatam
translated: And that is eternal.🔽And its capability is unobstructed.

analyzed: sahakāri sarvam tad adhīnam
translated: And all that is auxiliary is dependent on it.

original: athāpi te sahakāriṇaḥ kādācitkā ityatat vyāhataṃ vaca ityāśayenāhatarhi mātā'pi satīti /
analyzed: atha api te sahakāriṇaḥ kādācitkāḥ iti atat vyāhatam vacaḥ iti āśayena āha tarhi mātā api satī iti
translated: Now, if those auxiliaries are occasional, then the statement is contradicted. With this idea in mind, he says then even when the mother is present.

analyzed: yat kiñcid etat asāram iti arthaḥ
translated: This is of no consequence, the meaning is that it is worthless.

original: kāryasya svabhāvaviśeṣamavalambhya pratyavatiṣṭhatenanveṣa eva kāryasya svabhāva iti /
analyzed: kāryasya svabhāva viśeṣam avalambhya pratyavatiṣṭhate nanu eṣaḥ eva kāryasya svabhāvaḥ iti
translated: It is replied that the nature of the effect is precisely this.

analyzed: nirasyati tat na iti
translated: This is refuted.

analyzed: samarḥ ced kasmāt na sva kāryam sādhayati
translated: If it were to assume another nature, why would it not accomplish its own effect?

original: yadi na sādhayedasamrtha eva sa iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yadi na sādhayet asamrthaḥ eva saḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If it did not accomplish it, then it would not be capable, this is the idea.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram āha na api iti
translated: He states another fault.

original: sraṣṭā'yaṃ kramāt bhāvān sṛjatīti hi bhavān manyate /🔽samarthasya nityasya kramāt kāryādhānamityanupapannam /
analyzed: sraṣṭā ayam kramāt bhāvān sṛjati iti hi bhavān manyate  samarthasya nityasya kramāt kārya ādhānam iti anupapannam
translated: You think that this creator creates things in order.🔽It is not possible that a capable, eternal entity produces effects in order.

analyzed: nairapekṣyāt samartha tvāt ca kartuḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that because the agent is independent and capable, it does not depend on anything else.

analyzed: atra āpta saṃvādam āha yat āha iti
translated: Here he states the agreement with the authoritative: what is said.

analyzed: kālayoḥ kārya niṣpādana kāle
translated: At the time of the production of the effect.

original: atatkālecityarthaḥ /🔽sadṛśātmanaḥsamarthasya nityasya svarūpaṃ hi na viparivartate jātu /
analyzed: a tad kāla iciti arthaḥ  sadṛśa ātmanaḥ samarthasya nityasya sva rūpam hi na viparivartate jātu
translated: The meaning is at a time other than that.🔽The nature of an eternal and capable thing with a similar self never changes.

analyzed: tathā asati anitya tā āpatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if it were so, it would lead to the fault of non-eternality.

analyzed: etena iti nityānām nitya tayā abhimatānām jīvātmanām
translated: By this, of the eternal souls that are considered to be eternal,

analyzed: akṣaṇikānām akṣaṇika tayā abhimatānām ghaṭa ādīnām ca
translated: and of the pots and so on that are considered to be non-momentary.

original: yadidaṃ kramāt kāryādhānaṃ dṛśyate tat sthira tayā'bhimate kasmiṃścadapi na ghaṭata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yat idam kramāt kārya ādhānam dṛśyate tat sthira tayā abhimate kasmiṃścana api na ghaṭate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that this production of effects in sequence is not possible in anything considered to be stable.

original: uktaṃ ca śāntarakṣitena🔽kāryāṇi hi vilambante kāraṇāsannidhānataḥ /
analyzed: uktam ca śāntarakṣitena  kāryāṇi hi vilambante kāraṇa asannidhānataḥ
translated: And it is said by Śāntarakṣita:🔽For effects are delayed due to the absence of the cause.

analyzed: samartha hetu sadbhāve kṣepaḥ teṣām hi kiṃkṛtaḥ
translated: When the capable cause exists, what is the reason for their delay?

analyzed: iti tattva pa
translated: Thus it is the truth.

analyzed: ataeva kārya kriyā samarthānām sarveṣām kṣaṇika tā evā iti susthitam
translated: For this very reason, it is well established that all things capable of producing effects are momentary.

analyzed: nanu sarvasya kṣaṇika tā iti pratyakṣa viruddham
translated: But isn't it contradictory to perception to say that everything is momentary?

original: pratyakṣeṇākṣaṇikataiva hi gamyata ityāśaṅkatenacātra pratyakṣavirodha iti /
analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa akṣaṇika tā eva hi gamyate iti āśaṅkate na ca atra pratyakṣa virodhaḥ iti
translated: The idea is that non-momentariness is indeed perceived by perception. He doubts that there is no contradiction with perception here.

analyzed: atra pratividhante pratyakṣeṇa ityādinā  akṣaṇikasya iti
translated: In response to this, they [the Sautrāntikas] say by perception and so on.🔽Of the non-momentary.

analyzed: akṣaṇika tvasya iti yāvat
translated: This means of the non-momentariness.

analyzed: nahi iti
translated: For it is not so.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ pratyakṣam hi sākṣātkāraḥ
translated: The idea is this: Perception is direct cognition.

analyzed: sa ca kṣaṇikaḥ
translated: And that is momentary.

original: yadā svayamudbhavati tadā vartamānaṃ vastumātraṃ gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: yadā svayam udbhavati tadā vartamānam vastu mātram gṛhṇāti
translated: When it arises by itself, it grasps only the present object.

analyzed: na tasya pūrva apara kṣaṇa yogam ca
