translated: Not its connection with the preceding and subsequent moments.

original: svayaṃ ca kṣaṇāntare vinaśyan anekakṣaṇayogamekasya gṛhītuṃ na kalpante iti /
analyzed: svayam ca kṣaṇa antare vinaśyan aneka kṣaṇa yogam ekasya gṛhītum na kalpante iti
translated: And itself perishing in another moment, it is not capable of grasping the connection of one thing with many moments.

original: pūrvāparakṣaṇayośca na vartamāne sākṣātkārakāle prakāśo ghaṭeta /
analyzed: pūrva apara kṣaṇayoḥ ca na vartamāne sākṣātkāra kāle prakāśaḥ ghaṭeta
translated: And the manifestation of the preceding and subsequent moments would not be possible at the time of the manifestation of the present.

analyzed: tathā asati tayoḥ api kālayoḥ vartamāna tā āpatteḥ iti āha na hi prāk ūrdhvam iti
translated: Thus, he says for it is not so before or after.

original: yadi punaḥ pratyakṣakāle pūrvāparakṣaṇayogasyāpi prakāśa iṣyeta /
analyzed: yadi punar pratyakṣa kāle pūrva apara kṣaṇa yogasya api prakāśaḥ iṣyeta
translated: But if the connection of the preceding and subsequent moments were to be manifested at the time of perception,

original: tarhi sākṣātkriyamāṇasya vastunastadaivājanmata āvināśamanuvartamānaḥ kālānvayo'pi prakāśeta /
analyzed: tarhi sākṣātkriyamāṇasya vastunaḥ tadā eva ājanmataḥ ā vināśam anuvartamānaḥ kāla anvayaḥ upi prakāśeta
translated: then the connection of time, which continues from the very birth of the object being directly cognized up to its destruction, would also be manifested.

original: tathāsatyutpannasya vastuno vināśāvadhirapi bhavatāṃ mate vijñāta eva bhavedityāśayenāhajanmavināśāvadhīti /
analyzed: tathā asati utpannasya vastunaḥ vināśa avadhiḥ api bhavatām mate vijñātaḥ eva bhavet iti āśayena āha janma vināśa avadhi iti
translated: With such a view, he says: The limit of origination and destruction would be known even in your view.

analyzed: nanu pratyabhijñā pratyakṣam kāla dvaya saṃbandham gṛhṇāti iti atra āha etena iti
translated: But it is not so, because the perception of recognition grasps the relation between the two times. To this he says: By this.

analyzed: etena iti anena abhipretam pratyabhijñāyāḥ apratyakṣa tvam upapādayati sākṣātkāri hi jñānam ityādinā  sākṣāt kartavyam
translated: By this, he explains the intended non-perception of recognition. He says: For, knowledge is that which causes direct perception.🔽What is to be directly perceived.

analyzed: sākṣātkartum kṣamam iti yāvat  na ca smaraṇam pratyakṣam iti
translated: That which is capable of directly perceiving.🔽And memory is not perception.

analyzed: smaraṇam pratyakṣa ātmakam na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that memory does not have the nature of perception.

analyzed: atra kumārila matam nirasyan tad matena ākṣipati atha iti
translated: Here, refuting the view of Kumārila, he criticizes it with his view, beginning with If it is said.

analyzed: idānīntanam avasthānam na sākṣātkuryāt iti
translated: It would not directly perceive the present state.

analyzed: ayam iti tu bhavati idānīntanasya grahaṇam
translated: This refers to the grasping of the present.

analyzed: tat ca akṣasa apekṣam
translated: And that depends on the eye.

analyzed: tat aindrikasya asya pratyakṣa tā avyāhatā eva iti
translated: Therefore, the perceptibility of this [cognition] based on the eye is not obstructed.

analyzed: pratyakṣa viruddhā ca kṣaṇika tā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And momentariness is contradicted by perception, this is the meaning.

analyzed: tasya kārikām anuvadati yat āha ityādinā
translated: He repeats the verse on the stated meaning, beginning with When it is said.

analyzed: atirekiṇī iti
translated: Additional.

analyzed: smṛtitaḥ bhinnā
translated: It is different from memory.

analyzed: sākṣātkara pramā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: it is a direct cognition.

original: tadetat kumāriloktaṃ pratikṣipatismaraṇagrahaṇarūpaṃ tarhi pratyabhijñānaṃ syāditi /
analyzed: tat etat kumārila uktam pratikṣipati smaraṇa grahaṇa rūpam tarhi pratyabhijñānam syāt iti
translated: This is what Kumārila said, which he refuted, saying Then recognition would be in the form of memory and apprehension.

analyzed: nanu nā iyam pratyabhijā smṛteḥ atiricyate
translated: But this recognition is not different from memory.

original: ayamitivat sa ityavi grahaṇāt /🔽smaryamāṇe ca tadavasthe'kṣāyogāt na sākṣātkārarūpatā /
analyzed: ayam iti vat saḥ iti avi grahaṇāt  smaryamāṇe ca tad avasthā īkṣā yogāt na sākṣātkāra rūpa tā
translated: Because it apprehends this in the same way as that, like this is the same as that.🔽And when what is being remembered is in the same state, there is no direct cognition form, because the sense organs are not in contact.

analyzed: gṛhyamāṇe ca idam avasthe na smaraṇa ātma tā
translated: And when what is being apprehended is in the same state, there is no nature of memory.

analyzed: tasmāt smaraṇa grahaṇa ubhaya ātma tā eva prasajet
translated: Therefore, it would follow that it has the nature of both memory and apprehension.

analyzed: na tu smṛti vyatirikta sākṣātkāri pramā ātma tā
translated: But it does not have the nature of a valid cognition that is a direct cognition distinct from memory.

original: ubhayarūpatā caikajñānasya na ghaṭeteti bhāvaḥ /🔽nanuekamevānyena rūpeṇa smaryate /
analyzed: ubhaya rūpa tā ca eka jñānasya na ghaṭeta iti bhāvaḥ  nanu ekam eva anyena rūpeṇa smaryate
translated: The point is that a single cognition cannot have both forms.🔽But isn't it that the same thing is remembered in one form

analyzed: anyena rūpeṇa tu gṛhyate
translated: and apprehended in another form?

analyzed: prādhānyam tu gṛhyamāṇa rūpataḥ
translated: But the primary form is that of what is being apprehended.

analyzed: saṃskāra sāpekṣa tā tu gṛhyamāṇasya upalakṣaṇa aṃśe
translated: And the dependence on impressions is in the part that is indicated in what is being apprehended.

original: ataḥ purasthitavastugrahaṇarūpaiveyaṃ pratyabhijñetyāśayena parasya pratyavasthānamanūdya nirasyati yena hītyādinā /
analyzed: atas pura sthita vastu grahaṇa rūpā eva iyam pratyabhijñā iti āśayena parasya pratyavasthānam anūdya nirasyati yena hi ityādinā
translated: Therefore, this recognition is in the form of apprehending an object in front of one. Anticipating this objection from the opponent, he refutes it with the words By what... and so on.

analyzed: an unmattena na śakyate vaktum iti
translated: It cannot be said by one who is not insane.

original: ekaṃ vastu rūpe ca bhinne dve iti vadannunmatta eva syāt /
analyzed: ekam vastu rūpe ca bhinne dve iti vadan unmattaḥ eva syāt
translated: One who says that one thing is different in form is indeed insane.

analyzed: rūpa bhedaḥ hi sva rūpa bhedāt ananyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: For the difference in form is not different from the difference in own-form, this is the idea.

analyzed: bhāve api iti ekasya smaraṇa grahaṇa bhāva abhyupagame api iti arthaḥ
translated: Even if it exists, the meaning is even if one admits the existence of memory and perception of one thing.

analyzed: pratyakṣa apratyakṣa tvam syāt iti
translated: There would be the state of being perceptible and imperceptible.

analyzed: ekasya eva jñānasya aṃśataḥ pratyakṣa tvam aṃśatas upratyakṣa tvam ca āpatet
translated: It would follow that the same cognition would be perceptible in part and imperceptible in part.

analyzed: na tu pratyakṣa tā eva iti arthaḥ
translated: But not just perceptibility, this is the meaning.

analyzed: tasmāt pratyabhijñā pratyayaḥ bhrāntaḥ eva nirviṣaya tvāt iti
translated: Therefore, the cognition of recognition is indeed mistaken, because it is without an object.

analyzed: nirviṣaya tva atyathā avasthita vastu aviṣaya tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Because it is without an object, the meaning is because it does not have as its object a thing as it exists.

analyzed: āha ca śāntarakṣitaḥ
translated: And Santarakṣita says:

analyzed: nanu ca pratyabhijñānam saḥ eva iti upajāyate
translated: But recognition arises as It is the same,

analyzed: akṣa vyāpāra sadbhāve niṣprakampam abādhitam  tatas pratyakṣa bādheyam durvārā sarva hetuṣu
translated: unwavering and uncontradicted when the operation of the senses is present.

analyzed: kṣaṇa bhaṅga prasiddhi artham upātteṣu na yujyate
translated: Therefore, in all the reasons adduced to establish momentariness, it is not proper to say that it is contradicted by perception, which is unavoidable.

analyzed: na khalu pratyabhijñānam pratyakṣam upapadyate
translated: Indeed, recognition does not occur as perception.

analyzed: vastu rūpam anirdaśyam sa abhilāpam ca tat yatas
translated: Because the form of the object is undemonstrable, and it is associated with verbal expression.

analyzed: bhrāntam ca pratyabhijñānam pratyekam tad vilakṣaṇam
translated: And the recognition is erroneous, because each is different from that.

analyzed: abheda adhyavasāyena bhinna rūpe api vṛttitaḥ
translated: Even in the case of different forms, it occurs by the determination of non-difference.

analyzed: iti tattva pa
translated: Thus it is.

analyzed: pratyabhijñāyāḥ bhrama tve prayogam āha prayogaḥ ca evam iti
translated: The argument for the error of recognition is stated as follows: The argument is thus.

analyzed: sa tattvataḥ na eka ālambanaḥ iti  tattvataḥ na abhinna ālambanaḥ
translated: And that is not really based on the same object.🔽It is not really based on an undifferentiated object.

analyzed: adhyasta abheda ālaṃbanaḥ iti yāvat
translated: It is based on the superimposition of non-difference, that is the meaning.

analyzed: viruddha vyāpta upalabdhiḥ iti
translated: The perception of what is pervaded by the contradictory.

analyzed: viruddha vyāpta upalabdhim upapādayati ekatva anekatvayoḥ igyādinā
translated: In explaining the perception of what is pervaded by the contradictory, he says: By the one and many, etc.

analyzed: ekatva anekatvayoḥ bheda abhedayoḥ
translated: By the one and many, by difference and non-difference.

analyzed: viṣaya virodhāt viṣayiṇoḥ api upalambhayoḥ virodhaḥ iti āha tad viṣayayoḥ api iti
translated: The contradiction of the two perceptions is due to the contradiction of their objects. Thus he says: Of their objects also, etc.

analyzed: na pratyabhijñānam kṣaṇika anumāne bādhakam iti
translated: Recognition is not a counter-instance to the inference of momentariness.

analyzed: bhrānti tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is erroneous.

analyzed: viruddha vyaptiḥ na asti iti āśaṅkatena ca iti
translated: He doubts that there is no pervasion by the contradictory, saying: But if it is said, etc.

analyzed: atas eva iti
translated: For this very reason.

original: ayamāśayaḥ nanu viruddho'yaṃ hetuḥpratyabhijñā hi deśāre kālātare vā'nubhūtasya taddeśakālayogaṃ tadevedaṃ nīlamiti gamayati /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ nanu viruddhaḥ ayam hetuḥ pratyabhijñā hi deśa are kāla atare vā anubhūtasya tad deśa kāla yogam tat eva idam nīlam iti gamayati
translated: The idea is this: Surely this reason is contradictory, for recognition does indeed convey that what was experienced in a different place or time is the same as that, as in This is the same blue.

analyzed: autsargikam etat
translated: This is the general rule.

analyzed: lūna punarjāta ādiṣu ca sāmānya aikyam
translated: And in the case of what is cut and grows again, etc., there is unity of the universal.

analyzed: tat evam pratyabhijñā tvam viruddham
translated: Thus, the fact of recognition does not contradict being based on the same object.

analyzed: vahneḥ iva jalam
translated: Like water in fire.

analyzed: virodhāt eva ca anaikāntika tā api iti ced na
translated: And because of contradiction, it is also inconclusive, if you say. No.

analyzed: sthirasya krameṇa akrameṇa vā kriyā kāri tvam anupapannam iti asakṛt uktam eva
translated: It has been said many times that it is not logically possible for a permanent thing to be the cause of action, either successively or simultaneously.

original: tat pratyabhijñānasyaikālambanatvaṃ naivopapadyate iti na viruddhatvamanaikāntikatā veti /
analyzed: tat pratyabhijñānasya eka ālambana tvam na eva upapadyate iti na viruddha tvam anaikāntika tā vā iti
translated: Therefore, the fact of recognition is not logically possible to be based on the same object, so it is not contradictory or inconclusive.

analyzed: nanu pratyabhijñānam eva svarasataḥ vastu aikvam avagamayati
translated: But surely recognition itself naturally conveys the oneness of the thing.

analyzed: na eva
translated: Not so.

original: tasyaikālambanatvaṃ kiṃ yuktaṃ na vetyetadevādya vicāryata iti pratyabhijñānato vastvaikyopapādanamanupapannamipyāhanaca pratyabhijñānameveti
analyzed: tasya eka ālambana tvam kim yuktam na vā iti etat eva adya vicāryate iti pratyabhijñānataḥ vastu aikya upapādanam anupapannam ipya āha na ca pratyabhijñānam eva iti
translated: The question is being considered first whether its being based on the same object is proper or not. Thus the establishment of the oneness of the thing from recognition is not logically possible. Therefore it is said: And recognition itself is not.

analyzed: jagataḥ buddhimat viracita tva asaṃbhavam upakrāntam upasaṃharati tasmāt sthitam etat iti
translated: Having begun the impossibility of the world being created by an intelligent being, he concludes: Therefore, this is established.

analyzed: sattva lokam iti
translated: The world of beings.

analyzed: sattva ani prāṇinaḥ  tad lakṣāṇaḥ lokaḥ sattva lokaḥ
translated: Beings are living creatures.🔽The world that has their characteristics is the world of beings.

original: bhājana lokaḥsattvānāṃ prāṇināṃ bhājanabhūtaḥ āśrayabhūto loko bhājanalokaḥ /
analyzed: bhājana lokaḥ sattvānām prāṇinām bhājana bhūtaḥ āśraya bhūtaḥ lokaḥ bhājana lokaḥ
translated: The world of the receptacle is the world that is a receptacle, a support, for living creatures.

analyzed: tat imam ati vicitram cittam eva racayati cittam buddhiḥ jñānam iti paryāyāḥ
translated: This very mind, which is extremely varied, creates it. Mind, intellect, knowledge are synonyms.

original: cittamevabāhyātmanā bhāsata iti cittavilāsa eva sarmaviti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: cittam eva bāhya ātmanā bhāsate iti citta vilāsaḥ eva bhāvaḥ
translated: The mind itself appears as external and internal. The meaning is that the world is just the sport of the mind.

analyzed: karma jam hi jagat uktam aśeṣam
translated: For the entire world is said to be born from karma.

original: karma cittamavadhūya na cānyatdvividhaṃ satyaṃpāramārthikasatyaṃ sāṃvṛtika satyaṃ ceti /
analyzed: karma cittam avadhūya na ca anyat dvividham satyam pāramārthika satyam sāṃvṛtika satyam ca iti
translated: And karma is nothing but mind. There are two kinds of truth: ultimate truth and conventional truth.

original: tatra pāramārthikadṛṣtayā tu cittameva sarvasya mūlam sāṃvṛtidṛṣṭayā tu aśeṣaṃ jagat sattvānāṃ karmaṇā jātam /
analyzed: tatra pāramārthika dṛṣtayā tu cittam eva sarvasya mūlam sāṃvṛti dṛṣṭayā tu aśeṣam jagat sattvānām karmaṇā jātam
translated: However, from the perspective of ultimate truth, mind alone is the root of everything. But from the perspective of conventional truth, the entire world is born from the karma of beings.

original: tadevaṃ karma cittaṃ cetyubhayaṃ vinā jagato na kiñcinmūlamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tat evam karma cittam ca iti ubhayam vinā jagataḥ na kiñcid mūlam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Thus, the meaning is that apart from these two, karma and mind, there is no root at all for the world.

analyzed: vaibhāṣika matam āśritya iti etat vaktuḥ dṛṣtayā
translated: This is said with the view of the speaker, relying on the Vaibhāṣika view.

original: vaibhāṣikādyavāntarabhedo hi bhagavataḥ paścāttanaḥ yadvacanamāśritya vaibhāṣikāḥ pravartante iti yāvat /
analyzed: vaibhāṣika ādi avāntarabhedaḥ hi bhagavataḥ paścāttanaḥ yat vacanam āśritya vaibhāṣikāḥ pravartante iti yāvat
translated: For the Vaibhāṣika and other sub-divisions are later than the Blessed One, in that they proceed relying on the statements of the Blessed One, and so on.

analyzed: atha sarvajñām sādhayan parasya āśaṅkām anuvadati nanu iti
translated: Now, proving the omniscient one, he repeats the doubt of the opponent with the words But is it not so?

analyzed: kim pramāṇam pramāṇam na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: What is the means of valid knowledge? The meaning is that there is no means of valid knowledge.

original: asti pramāṇamanumānamityabhiprāyeṇāhaucyate iti catvāryāsatyāni teṣāṃ sākṣātkāro yasya bhavati sa sarvajñaḥ /
analyzed: asti pramāṇam anumānam iti abhiprāyeṇa āha ucyate iti catvāri āsatyāni teṣām sākṣātkāraḥ yasya bhavati sa sarvajñaḥ
translated: With the intention that there is a means of valid knowledge, namely inference, he says it is said - one who has the direct realization of those four noble truths is omniscient.

original: sākṣātkāraśca sphuṭāvabhāsa ityabhiprāyeṇa teṣāṃ sphuṭāvabhāse prayogaṃ darśayatiyo ya ityādinā /
analyzed: sākṣātkāraḥ ca sphuṭa avabhāsaḥ iti abhiprāyeṇa teṣām sphuṭa avabhāse prayogam darśayati yaḥ yaḥ ityādinā
translated: And with the intention that direct realization is clear manifestation, he shows the application to their clear manifestation with the words he who and so on.

analyzed: vyāpti avabodhakam prathamam vākyam
translated: The first sentence informs about the pervasion.

analyzed: dvitīyam ca pakṣa dharmatā avabodhakam
translated: And the second informs about the property of the subject.

analyzed: tatra sādara nirantara dīrgha kāla abhyāsa sahita cetaḥ guṇa tā hetuḥ
translated: There, the quality of the mind accompanied by earnest, uninterrupted, and long-lasting practice is the reason.

analyzed: sphuṭi bhāva yogya tā sādhyam
translated: The suitability for clear manifestation is the probandum.

analyzed: udāharaṇam kāminī ākāraḥ kāmuka citta gataḥ
translated: The example is the form of the lover in the mind of the lover.

analyzed: catur ārya satya viṣaya ākārāḥ bodhi citta gatāḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: The subject is the aspects of the four noble truths that are imbued with the thought of awakening.

original: svabhāvahetunā'nena caturṇāmāryasatyānāṃ sphuṭībhāvayogyatve siddhe sphuṭāvabāṣāsaṃbhavanirasanamukhena sarvajñāsiddhirnirastā bhavati /
analyzed: svabhāva hetunā anena caturṇām ārya satyānām sphuṭībhāva yogya tve siddhe sphuṭa avabāṣa asaṃbhava nirasana mukhena sarvajña asiddhiḥ nirastā bhavati
translated: When it is established by this intrinsic nature reason that the four noble truths are suitable for clear realization, the establishment of omniscience is refuted by the method of refuting the possibility of clear understanding.

analyzed: idam atra bodhyam
translated: This is what should be understood here.

original: sarvajñe pramāṇaṃ neti vadato'yamāśayaḥna tasmin pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇam /
analyzed: sarvajñe pramāṇam na iti vadataḥ yam āśayaḥ na tasmin pratyakṣam pramāṇam
translated: The intention of one who says that there is no valid cognition regarding an omniscient one is this: Perception is not a valid cognition regarding him.

analyzed: na hi dṛśyate kaścid sarva darśī
translated: For no one who sees everything is seen.

analyzed: na api anumānam
translated: Nor is there inference.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa sajāteyeṣu eva tad prasarāt
translated: Because it operates only on things of the same type that have been seen.

analyzed: na ca śabdaḥ tad bodhake prāmāṇya saṃśayāt
translated: And there is no verbal testimony, because there is doubt about its validity in conveying that.

analyzed: sarvajña tā ca na ghaṭate
translated: And omniscience is not possible.

analyzed: na hi atīndriyān arthān kaścid draṣṭum śaknoti
translated: For no one can see things beyond the senses.

analyzed: indriya āyatta prakāśāḥ hi arthaḥ
translated: For an object is illuminated by the senses.

original: prajñāprakarṣe'pi nendriyārthayoḥ svabhāvaṃ samatilaṅghya kiñcit jñātuṃ śaknoti / uktaṃ ca
analyzed: prajñā prakarṣe api na indriya arthayoḥ svabhāvam samatilaṅghya kiñcid jñātum śaknoti uktam ca
translated: Even with the highest wisdom, one cannot know anything by completely transcending the nature of the senses and objects. It is said:

analyzed: ye pi sa atiśayāḥ dṛṣṭāḥ prajñā megha abalaiḥ narāḥ
translated: Even those men who are seen to have exceedingly great wisdom and strength of clouds,

analyzed: stoka stoka antara tvena na tu atīndriya darśanāt
translated: by the difference of just a little bit, not by seeing beyond the senses.

original: prājño'pi hi naraḥ sūkṣmānarthān draṣṭuṃ kṣamo'pi san /
analyzed: prājñaḥ api hi naraḥ sūkṣmān arthān draṣṭum kṣamaḥ api san
translated: For even a wise man, though able to perceive subtle matters,

analyzed: sva jātīn an atikrāman atiśete parān narān
translated: does not surpass other men without transgressing his own kind.

analyzed: iti tattvasam pa
translated: Thus it is said in the Tattva-samgraha-pañjikā.

analyzed: tasmāt abhyāsa atiśaye sati api niravadhau artha indriyayoḥ svabhāva atilaṅghanam durghaṭam eva
translated: Therefore, even with excessive practice, it is impossible for the senses to transcend their nature with regard to an unlimited object.

analyzed: yat tu yoga abhyāsa balāt atīndriya artha darśanam ghaṭeta iti
translated: But it is also not possible that the perception of imperceptible objects is accomplished by the power of yoga practice.

original: tadapyanupapannam /🔽so'pi vicāryamāṇoṃavaratānudhyānalakṣaṇaḥ avicchinnasmṛtidhārārūpaḥ svayaṃ na sākṣātkārātmā /
analyzed: tat api anupapannam  saḥ api avicchinna smṛti dhārā rūpaḥ svayam na sākṣātkāra ātmā
translated: That is also not reasonable.🔽That [yoga] also, when examined, is characterized by the uninterrupted flow of memory in the form of continuous meditation, and is not itself the nature of direct perception.

analyzed: smṛtiḥ api anubhūta artha avalaṃbanī iti na yoga abhyāsataḥ upi atīndriya artha sākṣātkāri tā iti na sarvajñaḥ siddhyati iti
translated: And memory depends on experienced objects, so even through yoga practice, there is no direct perception of imperceptible objects. Thus omniscience is not established.

analyzed: sarvajñam samarthayataḥ tu ayam āśayaḥ yāvat na bādhakam upalabhyate
translated: But for one who seeks to establish omniscience, this is the intention: As long as an opposing factor is not perceived,

analyzed: tāvat na asti iti na niścīyeta
translated: it cannot be ascertained that it does not exist.

analyzed: na haya dṛṣṭi mātreṇa arthasya asambhavaḥ
translated: For the non-existence of an object is not due to mere non-perception.

original: tat sarvajñe pratyakṣādipramāṇānupalambhamātreṇa kathaṃ tatpratiṣedhaḥ kartuṃ śakyeta /
analyzed: tat sarvajñe pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇa anupalambha mātreṇa katham tad pratiṣedhaḥ kartum śakyeta
translated: How can that [omniscience] be refuted merely by the non-perception of perception etc. with regard to the omniscient one?

analyzed: na ca svāpnikānām tad tad puruṣa mātra vedyānām aparaiḥ anupalabhyamānānām apalāpaḥ kartum śakyeta
translated: And the denial of the objects of dreams, which are known only to the person who dreams and are not perceived by others, cannot be made.

original: yāvadbādhakaṃ nopalabhyate tāvat tatra saṃśayastu syādeva /
analyzed: yāvat bādhakam na upalabhyate tāvat tatra saṃśayaḥ tu syāt eva
translated: As long as a contradiction is not perceived, doubt may indeed arise there.

original: evaṃ sati kathaṃ bhavān sugatasārvajñyaṃ pratiṣeddhuṃ prabhavati /🔽nanu bādhakaṃ pradarśitam'sarvajñatā ca na ghaṭate' ityādinā /
analyzed: evam sati katham bhavān sugata sārvajñyam pratiṣeddhum prabhavati  nanu bādhakam pradarśitam sarvajña tā ca na ghaṭate ityādinā
translated: If this is so, how can you refute the omniscience of the Sugata?🔽Hasn't a contradiction been shown by saying Omniscience is not possible?

analyzed: atrā ucyate na kim api daurghaṭyam
translated: To this it is said: There is no difficulty at all.

analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam svabhāva viśeṣaḥ indriya arthayoḥ cakṣuḥ rūpam eva gṛhṇīyāt
translated: And this specific nature of the sense faculties and objects - the eye would only apprehend form.

original: na śrotrādi śrotraṃ śabdameva gṛhṇīyānna rūpam /
analyzed: na śrotra ādi śrotram śabdam eva gṛhṇīyāt na rūpam
translated: The ear, etc. would only apprehend sound, not form.

analyzed: evam rūpam cakṣuṣā eva gṛhyeta na itareṇa indriyeṇa
translated: Thus, form would only be apprehended by the eye, not by other sense faculties.

analyzed: śabdaḥ śrotreṇa eva na itareṇa indriyeṇa iti
translated: Sound would only be apprehended by the ear, not by other sense faculties.

analyzed: satyam
translated: This is true.

analyzed: indriyeṇa ced gṛhyeta tadā tathā eva
translated: If it were apprehended by the sense faculty, then it would be just so.

analyzed: cittena ced na ayam niyamaḥ
translated: If it were by the mind, this rule would not apply.

original: nanu mano nāmāntaramindriyaṃ bāhyendriya dvāreṇaivārthe pravartetetyanullaṅghanīyo niyamaḥ /
analyzed: nanu manaḥ nāma antaram indriyam bāhya indriya dvāreṇa eva arthe pravarteta iti anullaṅghanīyaḥ niyamaḥ
translated: Isn't the internal sense faculty called mind only active towards an object through the external sense faculties? This rule cannot be transgressed.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: na manaḥ nāma indriyam kiñcid ānantaram  manaḥ cittam buddhiḥ vijñānam iti anartha antaram
translated: The mind is not a sense faculty that immediately follows any [sense faculty].🔽Mind, thought, cognition, and consciousness are not different in meaning.

analyzed: pratisattvam bhinnā citta dhārā anuvartate
translated: The stream of mind continues separately for each individual.

analyzed: ca rāga ādi vividha mala āvilā bhavati
translated: And it becomes defiled by various impurities such as attachment.

analyzed: āvidyam ca mala jālam āgantukam
translated: And the net of impurities is due to ignorance, and is adventitious.

analyzed: nairātyma bhāvanayā ca apacīyate
translated: And it is diminished by the cultivation of non-self.

analyzed: catur ārya bhāvanayā ca bhavati prakarṣaḥ
translated: And there is progress by the cultivation of the four noble truths.

original: yathā yathā nairātmyabhāvanayā'pacīyante rāgādayo malāstathā tathā caturāryabhavanayā ca prakarṣaṃ gatayā pravardhate prajñā /
analyzed: yathā yathā nairātmya bhāvanayā apacīyante rāga ādayaḥ malāḥ tathā tathā catur ārya bhavanayā ca prakarṣam gatayā pravardhate prajñā
translated: As attachment and other impurities are diminished by the cultivation of non-self, so by the cultivation of the four noble truths, which has become advanced, wisdom increases.

analyzed: aneka bhava anusyūta sādara nirantara ārya satya bhāvanayā kāṣṭām gatayā yoga lakṣaṇayā bhavati caturṇām api ārya satyānām aparokṣam
translated: By the cultivation of the four noble truths, which is continuous, uninterrupted, and respectful, and which has become advanced through the characteristics of yoga, there is direct perception of all four noble truths.

analyzed: yoga jam api hi pratyakṣam
translated: For direct perception arises from yoga as well.

analyzed: sphuṭa avabhāsa tvāt
translated: Because it appears clearly.

analyzed: indriya artha svabhāva niyamaḥ tu aindriyake na aparokṣa mātre
translated: But there is restriction to the nature of sense faculties and objects in direct perception that is merely non-apparent.

analyzed: catur ārya aparokṣeṇa bhavati sarvajñaḥ
translated: One becomes omniscient by the non-apparent perception of the four noble truths.

original: sādaranirantarābhyāsāt prajñāprakarṣo bhatītyatra tu bhavatyayaṃ prayogaḥ'yo yaḥ sādare' tyādi riti /
analyzed: sādara nirantara abhyāsāt prajñā prakarṣaḥ bhati iti atra tu bhavati ayam prayogaḥ yaḥ yaḥ sādare tyādi riti
translated: The excellence of wisdom comes from reverent and uninterrupted practice. Here this argument is used: 'Whatever is reverent...' and so on.

analyzed: yathā yuvatī ākāraḥ kāminaḥ puruṣasya iti
translated: As the form of a young woman is for a passionate man.

analyzed: sphuṭa avabhāsa yogyaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: suitable for clear manifestation.

analyzed: kāmi cittam bhavati kāmyamāna ākāram
translated: The mind of a passionate person becomes the form of the desired one.

analyzed: tasmāt kāmyamāna yuvati ākāraḥ cittasya guṇaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, the form of the desired young woman becomes a quality of the mind.

original: so'yaṃ kāmicittaguṇabhūto yuvatyākāraḥ sādaranirantaradīrghakālābhyāsasahitaḥ sphuṭībhāvayogyo bhavati sphuṭāvabhāso bhavati
analyzed: saḥ ayam kāmi citta guṇa bhūtaḥ yuvatī ākāraḥ sādara nirantara dīrgha kāla abhyāsa sahitaḥ sphuṭībhāva yogyaḥ bhavati sphuṭa avabhāsaḥ bhavati
translated: This form of the desired young woman, which is a quality of the passionate person's mind, accompanied by reverent, uninterrupted, and long-term practice, becomes suitable for clear manifestation, becomes clearly manifest.

original: tathā vivekinaścittaṃ vibhāvyamānacaturāryasatyākāraṃ bhavatīti so'yaṃ caturāryasatyākāraścetoguṇabhūtaḥ sādaranirantaradīrghakālābhyāsasahitaḥ sphuṭāvabhāsayogyo bhavati /
analyzed: tathā vivekinaḥ cittam vibhāvyamāna catur ārya satya ākāram bhavati iti sā uyam catur ārya satya ākāraḥ cetaḥ guṇa bhūtaḥ sādara nirantara dīrgha kāla abhyāsa sahitaḥ sphuṭa avabhāsa yogyaḥ bhavati
translated: In the same way, the mind of a discerning person becomes the form of the four noble truths that are being contemplated. Therefore, this form of the four noble truths, which is a quality of the mind, accompanied by reverent, uninterrupted, and long-term practice, becomes suitable for clear manifestation.

analyzed: sphuṭa avabhāse ca tad aparokṣataḥ sarvajñaḥ bhavati iti
translated: And when there is clear manifestation, one becomes omniscient through direct perception of that.

analyzed: kāni catur ārya satyāni
translated: And what are the four noble truths?

analyzed: duḥkham samudayaḥ nirodhaḥ mārgaḥ ca iti
translated: Suffering, origination, cessation, and the path.

original: rūpaskandho vedanāskandhaḥ saṃjñāskandhaḥ saṃskāraskandho vijñānaskandha iti tadetat skandhapañcakaṃ duḥkha mucyate /
analyzed: rūpa skandhaḥ vedanā skandhaḥ saṃjñā skandhaḥ saṃskāra skandhaḥ vijñāna skandhaḥ iti tat etat skandha pañcakam mucyate
translated: The form aggregate, the feeling aggregate, the perception aggregate, the formation aggregate, and the consciousness aggregate - this fivefold aggregate is said to be suffering.

analyzed: yena asya skandha pañcakasya samudayaḥ saḥ ayam samudayaḥ
translated: That by which there is origination of this fivefold aggregate is this origination.

analyzed: yaḥ nirodhaḥ duḥkhasya sa nirodhaḥ
translated: That which is the cessation of suffering is that cessation.

original: nirodhasyāsya yat dvāraṃ sa mārga ucyate /
analyzed: nirodhasya asya yat dvāram sa mārgaḥ ucyate
translated: That which is the door to this cessation is said to be the path.

analyzed: hetoḥ dūṣaṇa traya rahita tām upapādayan tatra āśraya asiddhi hetu asiddhi rāhityam upapādayati na tāvat āśraya dvāreṇa iti
translated: Establishing the absence of the three faults in the cause, he establishes there the absence of the non-establishment of the basis and the non-establishment of the reason, saying Not first by way of the basis.

analyzed: dharmiṇām āśrayāṇām pakṣa tayā nirdiṣṭānām
translated: The dharmas, which are the bases, are indicated as the thesis.

original: te hi saṅkalpapathamārūḍhā duḥkhādyāryacatuṣṭayākārāḥ pratyātmaṃ cetastale prakāśanta eveti nāśrayāsiddhiḥ /
analyzed: te hi saṅkalpa patham ārūḍhāḥ duḥkha ādi ārya catuṣṭaya ākārāḥ pratyātmam cetaḥ tale prakāśante eva iti na āśraya asiddhiḥ
translated: For they are mounted on the path of imagination, and the aspects of the four noble truths such as suffering are clearly manifest in the mind's surface of each person, so there is no non-establishment of the basis.

analyzed: cetaḥ guṇa mātrasya iti
translated: Of the mere qualities of the mind.

analyzed: mātra śabdaḥ kṛṣna arthaḥ
translated: The word mere has the meaning of black.

original: cittasyālambanākāratayā ālambanamātraṃ cittākāra eveti te cetoguṇāḥ pratyātmaṃ prakāśanta eveti na hetvasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: cittasya ālambana ākāra tayā ālambana mātram citta ākāraḥ eva iti te cetaḥ guṇāḥ pratyātmam prakāśante eva iti na hetu asiddhiḥ
translated: Since the object is the mere object of the mind, the mere object is just the aspect of the mind, so those qualities of the mind are clearly manifest in each person, so there is no non-establishment of the reason.

original: dharmiṇi ca sādara nirantaradīrghakālābhyāsaviśiṣṭacetoguṇatāyāḥ saṃbhavena pakṣadharmatā na nopapadyate /
analyzed: dharmiṇi ca sādara nirantara dīrgha kāla abhyāsa viśiṣṭa cetaḥ guṇa tāyāḥ saṃbhavena pakṣa dharma tā na na upapadyate
translated: And in the case of the subject, the quality of the mind being distinguished by reverence, continuity, and long duration, the property of being the subject is not unestablished for us.

original: nacaiṣa viruddha iti /🔽kāminyākārekāmini citte yogyaṃ yuvatyākārastasmin /
analyzed: na ca eṣa viruddhaḥ iti  kāminī ākāre kāmini citte yogyam yuvatī ākāraḥ tasmin
translated: And this is not contradictory.🔽The form of the young woman is suitable in the mind of the lover, in the form of the lover.

original: kāminyā yuvatyā ākāre kāminā'nudhyāyamāne iti vā /
analyzed: kāminyāḥ yuvatyāḥ ākāre kāminā anudhyāyamāne iti vā
translated: Or, when the form of the young woman is being contemplated by the lover.

analyzed: virodhaḥ hi sādhya abhāvena ced vyāptaḥ hetuḥ
translated: For contradiction is when the reason is pervaded by the absence of the probandum.

analyzed: na ca iha tathā
translated: But it is not so here.

original: sādaranirantaradīrghakālābhyāsaviśiṣṭā ye ye cetoguṇā yuvatyākārādayaste sarve'pi sphūṭāvabhāsayogyā eva na tu sarva te sphuṭāvabhāsāyogyāḥ
analyzed: sādara nirantara dīrgha kāla abhyāsa viśiṣṭāḥ ye ye cetaḥ guṇāḥ yuvatī ākāra ādayaḥ te sarve api sphūṭa avabhāsa yogyāḥ eva na tu te sphuṭa avabhāsa ayogyāḥ
translated: All those qualities of the mind, such as the form of the young woman, which are distinguished by reverence, continuity, and long duration, are indeed suitable for clear manifestation, but not all of them are suitable for clear manifestation.

original: nanu sādaranirantaradīrdhakālābhyāsaviśiṣṭeṣu katipayacetoguṇeṣu sphuṭāvabhāsayoghyatvadarśane'pi sarveṣāṃ tathātve ko niyamaḥ /
analyzed: nanu sādara nirantara dīrdha kāla abhyāsa viśiṣṭeṣu katipaya cetaḥ guṇeṣu sphuṭa avabhāsa yoghya tva darśane api sarveṣām tathātve kaḥ niyamaḥ
translated: But even when we see that some qualities of the mind, distinguished by reverence, continuity, and long duration, are suitable for clear manifestation, what rule is there that all of them are so?

analyzed: tasmāt anaikāntikaḥ ayam hetuḥ iti śaṅkāḥ vārayan āha na ca anaikāntikaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, this reason is inconclusive. To ward off this doubt, he says: And it is not inconclusive.

analyzed: na vayam sahacāra darśana mātreṇa vyāptim brūmaḥ
translated: We do not speak of pervasion merely by seeing co-occurrence.

analyzed: kintu kāya kāraṇa bhāvāt pratibandhāt iti āha abhyāsa ityādinā
translated: But because of the relation of cause and effect between the body and the mind, there is restriction. This is stated by through repetition, etc.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ vā katham etayoḥ siddhi ati iti atra āha pratyakṣa anupalambhataḥ iti
translated: How is the relation of cause and effect between these two established? In this regard, it is said through perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is through perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ tu anvaya vyatireka sacārābhyām siddhi ati
translated: The relation of cause and effect is established through the concomitance of positive and negative instances.

analyzed: tatra anvaya sahacāraḥ pratyakṣa gamyaḥ
translated: There, the concomitance of positive instances is understood through perception.

original: vyatirekasahacāro'nupalambhagamyaḥ /🔽itthaṃ ca sarvopasaṃhāreṇa pratyakṣānupalambhābhyāṃ tayoḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ siddhyantīti kāryakāraṇabhāvalakṣaṇāt pratibandhādhvayāptisiddhiriti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vyatireka sahacāraḥ anupalambha gamyaḥ  ittham ca sarva upasaṃhāreṇa pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām tayoḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ siddhi antī iti kārya kāraṇa bhāva lakṣaṇāt pratibandha adhva yāpti siddhiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The concomitance of negative instances is understood through non-apprehension.🔽Thus, through perception and non-apprehension, the relation of cause and effect between them is established by including all cases. Therefore, the establishment of attainment through restriction characterized by the relation of cause and effect is the idea.

analyzed: prakṛte pratyak sa anupalambhau upapādayati tathā hi iti
translated: In the present context, perception and non-apprehension are explained by thus, etc.

analyzed: kāmi antarvarttini kāmi citta antarvattini
translated: In the mind of the one who desires, which is internal.

analyzed: trividha pratyakṣa anupalambha sādhyaḥ iti  pratyakṣam anupalaṃbhaḥ ca iti anayoḥ samāhāraḥ pratyakṣa anupalambham
translated: It is to be accomplished by the three kinds of perception and non-apprehension.🔽The combination of perception and non-apprehension is perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: anupalabdhiḥ sphuṭa ābha tvasya iti iyam ekā anupalabdhiḥ
translated: Non-apprehension is of the clarity of appearance. This is one non-apprehension.

analyzed: pascāt abhyasa saṃvedanam sphuṭa basa saṃvedanam ca iti pratyakṣa dvayam
translated: The two kinds of perception are: (1) the perception of repeated practice, and (2) the perception of clear appearance.

analyzed: taiḥ etaiḥ tribhiḥ prakāra ryuktaḥ pratyakṣa anupalambha samudāyaḥ
translated: The collection of perception and non-perception, which has these three modes,

analyzed: tad sādhyaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: is the means of establishing the relation of cause and effect. This is the meaning.

original: idamatrāvedyateyathā paścādabhyāsasaṃvedanaṃ sphuṭābhasaṃvedanaṃ ceti pratyakṣadvayam tathā pūrvamabhyāsaviśiṣṭacetoguṇānupalambhaḥ sphuṭāvabhāsānupalambhaścetyanupalambhadvayaṃ kiṃ na syāt /
analyzed: idam atra āvedyate yathā paścāt abhyāsa saṃvedanam sphuṭa ābha saṃvedanam ca iti pratyakṣa dvayam tathā pūrvam abhyāsa viśiṣṭa cetaḥ guṇa anupalambhaḥ sphuṭa avabhāsa anupalambhaḥ ca iti anupalambha dvayam kim na syāt
translated: This is what is stated here: Just as there are two kinds of perception - the perception of repeated practice and the perception of clear appearance - why can't there be two kinds of non-perception - the non-perception of the quality of the mind distinguished by previous practice and the non-perception of clear appearance?

original: vastutastu svetarayāvatkāraṇfsamavadhāne satyapi yasminna sati kāryānupalambha ityeko'nupalambhaḥ /
analyzed: vastutas tu sva itara yāvat kāraṇ samavadhāne sati api yasmin na sati kārya anupalambhaḥ iti ekaḥ anupalambhaḥ
translated: In reality, however, when all the causes other than itself are present, the non-perception of the effect in the absence of that is one kind of non-perception.

original: sati tu yasmin kāryopalambha iti pratyakṣamekam /
analyzed: sati tu yasmin kārya upalambhaḥ iti pratyakṣam ekam
translated: But when that is present, the perception of the effect is one kind of perception.

original: itthaṃ ca pratyakṣānupalambhābhyāṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvāvadhāraṇamiti tu yuktam /
analyzed: ittham ca pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām kārya kāraṇa bhāva avadhāraṇam iti tu yuktam
translated: Thus, it is proper that the relation of cause and effect is ascertained by perception and non-perception.

original: evaṃ sthite kāraṇopalambhaṃ kāryopalambhaṃ ca pṛthak gaṇayitvā pratyakṣadvayaṃ cet saṃpādyeta kāraṇānupalambhaṃ kāryānupalambhaṃ ca pṛthaggaṇayitvā'nupalambhadvayāśrayaṇena cāturvidhyaṃ kiṃ na syāt /
analyzed: evam sthite kāraṇa upalambham kārya upalambham ca pṛthak gaṇayitvā pratyakṣa dvayam ced saṃpādyeta kāraṇa anupalambham kārya anupalambham ca pṛthak gaṇayitvā anupalambha dvaya āśrayaṇena cāturvidhyam kim na syāt
translated: If, in this way, two kinds of perception are admitted, by counting separately the perception of the cause and the perception of the effect, why should not a fourfold division be admitted, by relying on two kinds of non-perception, by counting separately the non-perception of the cause and the non-perception of the effect?

original: anayaivāśaṅkayā pūrvaṃ 'kāryahetordhūmādervahnyādinā mahānasādau dṛṣṭāntadharmiṇi trividhapratyakṣānupalambhena pañcavidhapratyakṣānupalambhato ve' tyetadvākyaṃ prakārāntareṇonnītam /
analyzed: anayā eva āśaṅkayā pūrvam kārya hetoḥ dhūma ādeḥ vahni ādinā mahānasa ādau dṛṣṭānta dharmiṇi trividha pratyakṣa anupalambhena pañcavidha pratyakṣa anupalambhataḥ vā iti etat vākyam prakāra antareṇa unnītam
translated: With this very doubt in mind, the sentence or by fivefold perception and non-perception of the example-subject such as a kitchen, of the effect-reason such as smoke, by the three kinds of perception and non-perception of fire, etc. was stated in a different way earlier.

original: nibandhakārasya tu hārdamiha paśyatāṃ naḥ pūrvavyākhyānaṃ nibandhakarturhārdaṃ nānusaratīti /
analyzed: nibandha kārasya tu hārdam iha paśyatām naḥ pūrva vyākhyānam nibandha kartuḥ hārdam na anusarati iti
translated: But the heart of the author of the commentary is seen by us here, that the earlier explanation does not follow the heart of the author of the treatise.

analyzed: śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He doubts with But surely...

original: caturāryasākṣātkāritvasiddhāvapi na sarvasākṣātkaritvaṃ saṃbhavati atha kathaṃ sarvajñatāsiddhiriti śaṅkiturāśayaḥ yadyapi catuṣvāryasatyeṣvanangargato naiko'pi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: catur ārya sākṣātkāri tva siddhau api na sarva sākṣātkari tvam saṃbhavati atha katham sarvajña tā siddhiḥ iti śaṅkituḥ āśayaḥ yadi api catuṣu ārya satyeṣu anangargataḥ na ekaḥ api bhāvaḥ
translated: Even if the existence of the realization of the four noble truths is established, the realization of everything is not possible. The intention of the doubter is How then is omniscience established? Although in the four noble truths there is not a single existent that is not included,

analyzed: atha api sarvajña tām vyaktam prasādhayan śaṅkate aśeṣeṇa iti
translated: Now, even if he clearly establishes omniscience, he doubts with without exception.

analyzed: sākalyena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is in its entirety.

analyzed: sarva dharma iti
translated: All dharmas means:

analyzed: dharma śabdaḥ bhāva mātra vacanaḥ
translated: The word dharma means mere existence.

original: kāryakāraṇabhāvāpannaṃ yadbījāṅkurādi yacca citta caittaṃ sa dharma iti paribhāṣyate /
analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāva āpannam yat bīja aṅkura ādi yat ca citta caittam sa dharmaḥ iti paribhāṣyate
translated: What is subject to the relation of cause and effect, such as seed and sprout, and what is mind and mental factors, is defined as dharma.

analyzed: yat pramāṇa saṃvādi iti
translated: That which is in agreement with valid cognition means:🔽The reason is the statement of a certain meaning that is in agreement with valid cognition.

analyzed: sākṣātkāri jñānam iti
translated: The probandum is that it is preceded by the direct realization of that meaning.🔽The direct realizing cognition means:

analyzed: sākṣātkāri yat jñānam iti arthaḥ  sākṣāt
translated: The meaning is the cognition that is direct realization.🔽Directly or indirectly means:

analyzed: sākṣātkāra pūrvaka tvam sākṣāt pāramparyeṇa vā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is preceded by direct realization, either directly or indirectly.

analyzed: agneḥ dāhaka tvam svayam sākṣātkṛtya procyamāne sākṣāt
translated: When it is said that the burning of fire is directly realized by oneself and then stated, it is direct.

original: tathāvidhajñānapūrvakatvaṃ svayamananubhūya sākṣātkarturvacane prāmāṇyamanu prayujyamāne paramparayā /
analyzed: tathāvidha jñāna pūrvaka tvam svayam an anubhūya sākṣātkartuḥ vacane prāmāṇyam anu prayujyamāne paramparayā
translated: When the statement of one who has not personally experienced the fact of being preceded by such a cognition is used to establish the validity of the direct realization, it is indirect.

original: tathā sugatānuyāyināṃ 'kṣāṇikaḥ sarva eva saṃskārā' ityasmin vacane ca /
analyzed: tathā sugata anuyāyinām kṣāṇikaḥ sarve eva saṃskārāḥ iti asmin vacane ca
translated: Similarly, in the statement of the followers of the Sugata that all conditioned things are momentary,

analyzed: kārya hetuḥ iti
translated: causal reason means:

analyzed: ukta vacanasya ukta sākṣātkāra kārya tvāt
translated: Because the statement has the effect of directly cognizing what is stated.

analyzed: hetoḥ isiddhi ādi dūṣaṇa tra rāhityam upapādayati na asya asiddhiḥ ityādinā
translated: To explain the absence of faults such as the reason being unestablished, he says this is not unestablished and so on.

analyzed: sarva dharma kṣaṇa bhaṅga prasādhanāt asya vacanasya iti
translated: Because this statement establishes the momentariness of all phenomena.

original: kṣāṇabhaṅgo hi sarvadharmāṇāṃ svabhāvaḥ tadarthāvabodhakatayā cāsya vākyasya pramāṇasaṃvādiniścitārthāvabodhatvarūpahetornāsiddhiriti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: kṣāṇa bhaṅgaḥ hi sarva dharmāṇām svabhāvaḥ tad artha avabodhaka tayā ca asya vākyasya pramāṇa saṃvādi niścita artha avabodha tva rūpa hetoḥ na asiddhiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The momentariness is the nature of all phenomena. And because this statement makes one understand that meaning, the reason which is the form of the statement's definite understanding of its meaning in accordance with valid cognition, is not unestablished. This is the idea.

original: pramāṇaniścitārthakatvasya hetuviśeṣaṇasya prayojanaṃ prakāśayannanaikāntikatāṃ vārayativacanamātrasya saṃśayapiparyāsapūrvakatve'pīti /🔽pramāṇaniścitārthasyeti /
analyzed: pramāṇa niścita arthaka tvasya hetu viśeṣaṇasya prayojanam prakāśayan anaikāntika tām vārayati vacana mātrasya saṃśaya piparyāsa pūrvaka tve pi iti  pramāṇa niścita arthasya iti
translated: Illuminating the purpose of the qualification of the reason as having a meaning ascertained by valid cognition, he wards off the charge of being inconclusive, saying even though mere statements may have doubt and error as antecedents.🔽Of that which has a meaning ascertained by valid cognition.

analyzed: pramāṇena niścita ūrthaḥ yasya tasya vākyasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: of that statement which has a meaning ascertained by valid cognition.

analyzed: nanu anayoḥ vyāpau kim pramāṇam
translated: But what is the valid cognition regarding the pervasion of these two?

analyzed: tatra āha pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām iti
translated: In that regard, he says by perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: pramāṇa saṃvādi vacanam hi sva artha sākṣātkāra kāryam
translated: For a statement in accordance with valid cognition is the effect of directly cognizing its own meaning.

analyzed: kāraṇe sati kārya upalambhaḥ
translated: When there is a cause, the effect is apprehended.

original: asati kāraṇe kāryānupalambha iti pratyakṣānupalambhābhyāṃ kāryakāraṇavyorvyāptirnirābādhā gṛhyata eveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: asati kāraṇe kārya anupalambhaḥ iti pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām kārya kāraṇa vyoḥ vyāptiḥ nirābādhā gṛhyate eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the invariable concomitance between cause and effect is indeed perceived without hindrance by perception and non-perception, since an effect is not perceived in the absence of a cause.

analyzed: tatra api ced āśaṅkā
translated: And if there is doubt even in that case,

analyzed: kārya hetu mātra uccheda prasaṅgaḥ iti āha anyathā iti
translated: he says otherwise to indicate the undesirable consequence of the destruction of mere causal relations.

analyzed: atrā ayam sarvajña samarthana saṅgrahaḥ
translated: Here is the summary of the defense of omniscience:

analyzed: prakāśita pūrvaḥ ca asmābhiḥ anyatra
translated: And this has been explained by us elsewhere.

original: pramāṇānāṃ nivṛttyā tu prameyaṃ na nivartate /
analyzed: pramāṇānām nivṛttyā tu prameyam na nivartate
translated: But the object of knowledge is not averted by the cessation of the means of knowledge.

analyzed: avyāpaka nivṛttyā syāt na avyāpyasya nivartanam
translated: By the cessation of what is not all-pervading, there cannot be the cessation of what is all-pervading.

original: sā pramāṇanivṛttiśca kvacid dṛṣṭā na sādhanam /
analyzed: sā pramāṇa nivṛttiḥ ca kvacid dṛṣṭā na sādhanam
translated: And that cessation of the means of knowledge is not seen as an instrument anywhere.

analyzed: sarva pramātṛ sandohe tad dṛṣṭiḥ tu mudurgrahā
translated: But the vision of that [omniscience] is easily grasped in the collection of all knowers.

analyzed: sarvajñe bādhakam nā api pramāṇam upalabhyate
translated: And no means of knowledge is found to contradict [the existence of] the omniscient one.

original: ye nāma bodhisattvāḥ syuḥ prakṛtyaiva kṛpāmayāḥ /
analyzed: ye nāma bodhisattvāḥ syuḥ prakṛtyā eva kṛpā mayāḥ
translated: Those who are indeed bodhisattvas, naturally full of compassion,

analyzed: aśeṣa dharma nairātmya bhāvanā abhyāsa pāṭavāt
translated: by the sharpness of their practice in meditating on the selflessness of all phenomena,

analyzed: vyapeta sarva āvaraṇāḥ rāga ādi mala varjitāḥ
translated: free from all obscurations, devoid of the stains of passion and so forth,

analyzed: prajñā prakarṣa yogena sārvajñyam samupāgatāḥ
translated: having attained omniscience by the perfection of wisdom,

analyzed: kṛpā prakaṣa yogena sarva sattva uddidḥirṣayā
translated: and by the sharpness of their compassion, out of their desire for the welfare of all beings,

analyzed: āsaṃsāram vartamānāḥ su accha spaṭika nirmalāḥ
translated: Existing until the end of the world, pure like clear crystal,

analyzed: doṣa vātaiḥ aprakampyāḥ te buddhāḥ jagataḥ hitāḥ iti
translated: Unmoved by the winds of faults, those Buddhas are for the benefit of the world.

analyzed: bhava praramparā siddhaye tu kim pramāṇam iti
translated: But what is the means of knowledge for the establishment of the continuity of existence?

original: kiṃ śabdaḥ pratikṣepepramāṇa nāstītyarthaḥ lokāyata tānuyāyinaḥ seyamāśaṅkā /
analyzed: kim śabdaḥ na asti iti arthaḥ sā iyam āśaṅkā
translated: The word 'kim' (what) is for rejection. The meaning is that there is no means of knowledge. This is the doubt of those who follow Lokāyata.

analyzed: anyeḥ tad a pratikṣepāt
translated: Because others do not reject it.

original: ayamabhiprāyaḥastu nāma ye sthiramātmānamabhyupacchanti teṣāṃ kathamapi punarbhavapratyāśā /
analyzed: ayam abhiprāyaḥ astu nāma ye sthiram ātmānam abhyupacchanti teṣām katham api punarbhava pratyāśā
translated: The intention is this: Let it be that for those who accept a permanent self, there is somehow hope for rebirth.

original: sarvasya kṣaṇikatāṃ vadataḥ kathaṃ punarbhavakathā ghaṭeteti /
analyzed: sarvasya kṣaṇika tām vadataḥ katham punarbhava kathā ghaṭeta iti
translated: But for one who says that everything is momentary, how can there be talk of rebirth?

analyzed: pratividhatte ucyate ityādinā
translated: He replies with 'It is said' and so on.

original: kṣaṇabhaṅgavādibhirasmābhirapyahaṃpratyayāspadabhūtā vijñānadhārā pratisattvaṃ bhinnā'nuvartata eva bhave bhava ityabhyupagataṃ nāma /
analyzed: kṣaṇabhaṅga vādibhiḥ asmābhiḥ api ahaṃpratyaya āspada bhūtā vijñāna dhārā pratisattvam bhinnā anuvartate eva bhave bhave iti abhyupagatam nāma
translated: Even for us who assert momentariness, the stream of consciousness which is the basis of the notion of 'I' continues separately for each being, and is accepted as 'existence' in existence.

analyzed: pūrva pūrva cittasya eva svabhāvaḥ uttarottaram cittam janayati iti
translated: The nature of each preceding mind produces the subsequent mind.

analyzed: tasmāt maraṇa kāla bhāvi cittasya api citta antara utpādaka tvam asti eva
translated: Therefore, even the mind that occurs at the time of death has the ability to produce another mind.

original: atrāyaṃ prayoto bhavatītyāśayenāhayaccittaṃ taccittāntaraṃ pratisandhatte iti /
analyzed: atra ayam prayotaḥ bhavati iti āśayena āha yat cittam tat citta antaram pratisandhatte iti
translated: With the intention that this is the application, he says: The mind that connects with another mind.

analyzed: utpādayati iti etat
translated: This means that it produces.

analyzed: ayam ca utpādya utpādaka bhāvaḥ eka santāna anvayinoḥ eva pūrva apara cittayoḥ
translated: And this relation of what is produced and what produces is only between the previous and subsequent minds that are in the same continuum.

analyzed: maraṇa kāla bhāvi cittam pakṣaḥ
translated: The mind that exists at the time of death is the subject.

analyzed: citta antara utpādaka tvam sādhyam citta tvaḥ hetuḥ
translated: The production of another mind is the probandum. The property of being a mind is the reason.

analyzed: idānīntana cittam dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: The present mind is the example.

analyzed: na ca arhat caramacittena vyabhicāraḥ iti
translated: And there is no fallacy with the final mind of an arhat.

original: arhatāmapagatarāgādīnāṃ caramaṃ cittaṃ cittāntaraṃ notpādayatīti saugaterapīṣyata iti tasmiṃścitte vyabhicāra iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: arhatām apagata rāga ādīnām caramam cittam citta antaram na utpādayati iti saugateḥ api iṣyate iti tasmin citte vyabhicāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the final mind of the arhats, who are free from passion and so on, does not produce another mind, so it is accepted even by the Buddhists. Therefore, there is a fallacy in that mind.

analyzed: imām anaikāntika āśaṅkām pariharati tasya āgama mātra pratīta tvāt iti
translated: He resolves this doubt about the inconclusive nature of the reason by saying because it is known only from scripture.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ parakīya āgama eka siddhena arhat caramacittena aṃna aikāntika āśaṅkā para āgamasya aprāmāṇyam vadatā nā udbhāvyā
translated: The idea is this: One should not raise the doubt about the inconclusive nature of the reason with the final mind of an arhat, which is established only by the scripture of the other [school], by saying that the scripture of the other [school] is not authoritative.

analyzed: paramata abhupagamena ced abhyupagamyatām tathā eva punar bhavaḥ pi iti
translated: If it is accepted by accepting the highest truth, let rebirth be just like that.

analyzed: niṣkleśa citta antara jananāt vā iti
translated: Because it produces another mind without defilements.

original: ayamāśayaḥna saugatānāṃ sarveṣāmabhimatametat arhato bhavati caramaṃ cittaṃ /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ na saugatānām sarveṣām abhimatam etat arhataḥ bhavati caramam cittam
translated: The idea is this: this is not accepted by all Buddhists, that the last mind of an arhat becomes mind.

analyzed: yat cintā antaram na utpādayata iti
translated: And that which does not produce another thought.

analyzed: kecid kathayanti nāma evam
translated: Some say it is so in name.

original: vastutasteṣāmapi vītarāgāṇāṃ vyapetasakalāvidyāmūlāṇāṃ kleśādimalairanāliptā vimalā cittasantatiranuvartata eveti nānaikāntikapralaṅga iti /
analyzed: vastutas teṣām api vīta rāgāṇām vyapeta sakala avidyā mūlāṇām kleśa ādi malaiḥ an āliptā vimalā citta santatiḥ anuvartate eva iti na anaikāntika pralaṅgaḥ iti
translated: But in reality, even for those free from passion, whose root of ignorance is completely removed, their mind-stream continues pure, unstained by the defilements of afflictions and so on. Therefore, it is not a case of inconclusive evidence.

analyzed: uktam ca śāntarakṣitena
translated: And it has been said by Santarakṣita:

analyzed: kṣīṇa āsravasya vijñānam asandhānam kutas bhavet
translated: How can the consciousness of one whose defilements are exhausted be non-continuous?

analyzed: parakīya kṛtāntāt ced na
translated: If it is from the end made by others, then not.

analyzed: prāmāṇya a parigrahat
translated: Because of not accepting validity.

analyzed: ye ca iha sudhiyaḥ kecid apratiṣṭhita nirvṛtīn
translated: And those who are wise here, some say that the non-abiding nirvāṇa

original: jināṃ stadyānaniṣṭatvaṃ yānayośca pracakṣate //🔽tān pratyayamasiddhaśca sādhyadharmasamanvitaḥ /
analyzed: yānayoḥ ca pracakṣate  tān pratyayam asiddhaḥ ca sādhya dharma samanvitaḥ
translated: Of the victors is not the ultimate, and that the two vehicles are taught for those who are not fit for that.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntaḥ prativādi iṣṭa siddhānta āśrayaṇe pi te
translated: For them, even if they rely on the established doctrine of the opponent, the example is not established, and is endowed with the property to be proven.

analyzed: iti tattvasam
translated: Thus it is in the Tattva-sam.

original: kamalaśīlena cetthaṃ vyākhyātam'kutaḥ prasiddhamarhatāṃ na cittāntaraṃ pratisandhatte maraṇacittamiti /
analyzed: kamalaśīlena ca ittham vyākhyātam kutas prasiddham arhatām na citta antaram pratisandhatte maraṇa cittam iti
translated: And it has been explained by Kamalaśīla in this way: 'How is it well-known that the mind of death of the arhats does not connect to another mind?'

original: athā'pi syāt parakīye bauddhasiddhānte paṭhyate kṣīṇā me jātiruṣitaṃ brahmacaryaṃ kṛtaṃ karaṇīyaṃ nāparamasmāt bhavaṃ prajānāmīti /
analyzed: atha api syāt parakīye bauddha siddhānte paṭhyate kṣīṇā me jātiḥ uṣitam brahmacaryam kṛtam karaṇīyam na aparam asmāt bhavam prajānāmi iti
translated: But even if it is said that in the Buddhist doctrine of others it is recited: My birth is exhausted, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, I do not perceive any further existence after this,

analyzed: atas siddham asādhanam iti
translated: therefore it is established that it is not a means of knowledge.

analyzed: tat etat ayuktam parakīyasya siddhāntasya prāmāṇyena aparigrahāt
translated: This is not correct, because the doctrine of others is not accepted as authoritative.

analyzed: katham tathā prāmāṇyena parigṛhītāt niścayaḥ
translated: How can there be certainty based on what is accepted as unauthoritative in that way?

analyzed: para lokasya api niścaya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the other world would also be ascertained.

original: x x x x parasiddhāntāśrayaṇenāpi kāṃścid bauddhān prati sādhyadharmasamanvito na siddho dṛṣṭānta iti darśayannāhayeceha sudhiya itī'ti tattvasaṃ / pañci /
analyzed: para siddhānta āśrayaṇena api kāṃścid bauddhān prati sādhya dharma samanvitaḥ na siddhaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ iti darśayan āha ye ca iha sudhiyaḥ iti iti tattvasam
translated: Even by relying on the doctrine of others, in order to show that the example is not established as possessing the property to be proved for some Buddhists, he says If the wise ones here... This is the conclusion of the Tattva-Samīkṣā.

analyzed: tuṣyatu iti nāyena āha hetoḥ vā kleśe sati iti viśeṣaṇa apekṣaṇāt iti
translated: Let them be satisfied means by what. He says because the reason requires a qualification, such as 'when there is affliction'.

analyzed: rāga ādi mala kaluṣita citta tvasya hetutā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the state of having a mind polluted by the stains of passion etc. is the reason.

original: arhanmaraṇacittaṃ tu na tathāvidhamiti nānaikāntikateti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: arhat maraṇa cittam tu na tathāvidham iti na anaikāntika tā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the mind of an arhat at the time of death is not of that kind, so it is not inconclusive, this is the idea.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam śāntarakṣitena
translated: And thus it is said by Śāntarakṣita:

analyzed: maraṇa kṣaṇa vijñānam sva upādeya udaya kṣamam
translated: The consciousness at the moment of death is capable of producing its own effect.

analyzed: rāgiṇaḥ hīna saṅga tvāt pūrva vijñāna vat tathā
translated: Because the passionate one is attached to the inferior, like the previous consciousness.

analyzed: iti tattvasam
translated: Thus it is explained in the Tattva-samgraha.

analyzed: vyākhyātam ca etat yat sa rāgam cittam tat sva upādeya citta antara udaya samartham
translated: And this is explained: 'That mind which is with passion is capable of producing another mind that it has taken up.

analyzed: sa rāga tvāt pūrma citta vat sa rāgam ca idam maraṇa cittam iti
translated: Because it is with passion, like the previous mind. And this mind at death is with passion.'

original: maraṇakālabhāvicittasya cittāntarotpādatvaṃ prasādhya janmakālabhāvinaścittasya svodayahetubhūtacittapūrvakatvaṃ prasādhayannāhaihetyādinā pūrvottarabhavadvayasamarthanena anekabhavānvayo dṛḍhīkṛto bhavati /
analyzed: maraṇa kāla bhāvi cittasya citta antara utpāda tvam prasādhya janma kāla bhāvinaḥ cittasya sva udaya hetu bhūta citta pūrvakatvam prasādhayan āha aiha ityādinā pūrva uttara bhava dvaya samarthanena aneka bhava anvayaḥ dṛḍhīkṛtaḥ bhavati
translated: Having established that the mind occurring at the time of death is the production of another mind, he establishes that the mind occurring at the time of birth has a previous mind as its cause for arising. By affirming the two states of existence, past and future, with the words 'not so' and so on, the continuity of many existences is made firm.
The cause of the existence that is to be is the natural cause.

analyzed: bhūta bhava sādhakaḥ tu ayam kāryaṃhetuḥ iti āi kārya hetuḥ iti
translated: But this one that establishes the past existence is the effect-cause, therefore it is the effect-cause.

analyzed: nanu pratisattvam vijñāna dhārā pravahati sācā aneka bhava anuvartinī
translated: Now, the stream of consciousness flows for each being, and that continues through many existences.

original: sarvajñāśca bahavo buddhāḥ ityādibhedavarṇanaṃ kathaṃ ghaṭate /
analyzed: sarvajñāḥ ca bahavaḥ buddhāḥ iti ādi bheda varṇanam katham ghaṭate
translated: And many omniscient Buddhas, etc., how is the description of the differences possible?

analyzed: śūnyam eva tu tattvam iṣṭam
translated: But the truth is accepted as empty only.

original: śūnyatādṛṣṭireva tu muktiriti ca tāttvikī sthitirityāśayena śaṅkatenanuceti /
analyzed: śūnyatā dṛṣṭiḥ eva tu muktiḥ iti ca tāttvikī sthitiḥ iti āśayena śaṅkate nanu ca iti
translated: But the view of emptiness alone is liberation. This is the true state of affairs. With this intention, he raises the doubt: But is it not so?

analyzed: śaṅkā tad nirasana mukhena vaibhāṣika ādi mata bhedam avatārayati nāma
translated: In order to refute the doubt, he introduces the different opinions of the Vaibhāṣikas and others.

analyzed: sattvān lokān
translated: From sentient beings, from the world.

original: sarvaṃ evāvidyāvaśāt sthiravividhabhāvavāsanākaluṣitacetasaḥ sapadi śreyaḥpathe nāvatārayituṃ śakyante /
analyzed: sarvam eva avidyā vaśāt sthira vividha bhāva vāsanā kaluṣita cetasaḥ sapadi śreyaḥ pathe na avatārayitum śakyante
translated: All of them, their minds defiled by the latent tendencies of stable and various existences due to ignorance, cannot be immediately led onto the path of liberation.

original: tānetānadvaye naiḥśrayasapathe'vatārayatā bhagavatā karuṇārdracittena bhūtārthatayedamuktamiti /🔽ayamāśayaḥavidyayā''veṣṭitān dṛṣtamātreṣu avicārya tattattvamidamidamiti dhāvato'narthaṃ nipatato lokān śūnyatādṛṣṭau sapadyāvatārayitumaśakyatayā yadidaṃdṛśyate tadetat skandhāyatanādi /
analyzed: tān etān advaye naiḥśrayasa pathā ivatārayatā bhagavatā karuṇā ārdra cittena bhūta artha tayā idam uktam iti  ayam āśayaḥ avidyayā āveṣṭitān dṛṣta mātreṣu a vicārya tat tattvam idam idam iti dhāvataḥ anartham nipatataḥ lokān śūnyatā dṛṣṭau sapadya avatārayitum aśakya tayā yat idam dṛśyate tat etat skandha āyatana ādi
translated: The Blessed One, with a mind moist with compassion, in order to lead them onto the path of non-duality, spoke this with reference to the ultimate truth.🔽The intention is this: The world, enveloped by ignorance, runs towards this and that, without examining the truth of what is merely seen, and falls into misfortune. Since it is impossible to immediately lead them to the view of emptiness, the Blessed One first set forth the teaching of momentariness, that all this which is seen, the aggregates, sense bases, etc.,

original: sarvaṃ kṣaṇikaṃ na sthiramekamiti kṣaṇikatvopadeśaḥ prathamataḥ pravṛtto bhagavanaḥ /
analyzed: sarvam kṣaṇikam na sthiram ekam iti kṣaṇika tva upadeśaḥ prathamatas pravṛttaḥ bhagavanaḥ
translated: is momentary, not stable and one.

analyzed: tatas ca tān jñāna jñeya bheda vāsanā kaluṣpitān tatas vatārayitum vijñāna mātra upadeśaḥ
translated: Then, in order to lead them who are defiled by the impressions of the distinction between knower and known, the teaching of consciousness-only.

original: tato vijñānādvaitatadṛṣṭeravatārya śūnyatādṛṣṭau naiḥśreyasaikāntāyāṃ lokānvartayituṃ sarvaṃ śūnyamiti sarvaṃśūnyatopadeśaḥ /
analyzed: tatas vijñāna advaita tad dṛṣṭeḥ avatārya śūnyatā dṛṣṭau naiḥśreyasa ekāntāyām lokān vartayitum sarvam śūnyam iti sarvaṃśūnyatā upadeśaḥ
translated: Then, having led them who see the non-duality of consciousness to the view of emptiness, the sole cause of the highest good, the teaching that everything is empty.

original: tadevaṃ sāṃvṛtāsāṃvṛtabhedamāśritya kṣaṇikaṃ kṣaṇikaṃ vijñānaṃ vijñānaṃ śūnyaṃ śūnyamiticopadeśabhedaḥ pravṛtta iti /
analyzed: tat evam sāṃvṛta asāṃvṛta bhedam āśritya kṣaṇikam kṣaṇikam vijñānam vijñānam śūnyam śūnyam iti ca upadeśa bhedaḥ pravṛttaḥ iti
translated: Thus, relying on the distinction between conventional and ultimate, the teaching is divided into momentary consciousness, momentary consciousness is empty, empty, and so on.

original: tathācoktamlokāvataraṇārthaṃ ca bhāvā nāthena deśitāḥ / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca uktam loka avataraṇa artham ca bhāvāḥ nāthena deśitāḥ iti
translated: And thus it is said: And the existences were taught by the Lord for the descent into the world.

original: vineyajanāvataraṇāya pravṛttamupadeśabhedamavalabhya saugateṣu matabhedaḥ pravṛttaḥ sa ca vaibhāṣikādibhedādbhinnaḥ /
analyzed: vineya jana avataraṇāya pravṛttam upadeśa bhedam avalabhya saugateṣu mata bhedaḥ pravṛttaḥ sa ca vaibhāṣika ādi bhedāt bhinnaḥ
translated: The division of teachings arose for the descent of the disciples, and that is divided by the division of Vaibhāṣika and so on.

analyzed: tān bhedān nirūpan āha tathā hi ityādinā
translated: He describes those divisions beginning with Thus, indeed, and so on.

analyzed: ākāśam dvau nirodhau ca iti
translated: Space and the two cessations.

analyzed: dividham vastu saṃskṛtam asaṃskṛtam ca
translated: The conditioned and the unconditioned are the two kinds of things.

analyzed: tatra asaṃskṛtam ākāśam dvau ca nirodhau pratisaṅkhya nirodha uprisaṅkhyā nirodhaḥ ca iti
translated: Among them, the unconditioned is space and the two cessations, namely, cessation through deliberation and cessation not through deliberation.

analyzed: saṃskritam sarvam tu kṣaṇikam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that all that is conditioned is momentary.

analyzed: atha sautrāntikānām matam āha sautrāntikānām matam iti
translated: Now, regarding the Sautrāntika view, he says The view of the Sautrāntikas.

analyzed: na bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ iti
translated: The external object does not exist.

analyzed: nīla ādiḥ bāhyaḥ arthaḥ na pratibhāti
translated: The external object such as blue does not appear.

analyzed: asti tu bāhyaḥ arthaḥ
translated: However, there is an external object.

analyzed: sa ca na dṛś gocaraḥ
translated: And that is not the object of seeing.

analyzed: yat idam nīlam iti bhāsate
translated: What appears as blue

analyzed: saṅkrānta bāhya ākāram jñānam eva tu tat iti bhāvaḥ
translated: is the cognition itself, which has taken on the form of the external object. This is the meaning.

analyzed: jñāna anumeya bāhya artha vādinaḥ ete
translated: These [Sautrāntikas] are proponents of an external object that is to be inferred from cognition.

analyzed: su ākāra buddhi janakāḥ iti
translated: They are producers of a cognition with their own form.

analyzed: dṛśyāḥ dṛśya tayā abhimātāḥ bāhyāḥ
translated: They are considered external because they are seen as visible.

original: nīlādayo bāhyārthaḥ svākāraṃ buddhau samarpya svayaṃ najyanti /
analyzed: nīla ādayaḥ bāhya arthaḥ sva ākāram buddhau samarpya svayam najyanti
translated: The external object such as blue, having presented its own form in the cognition, itself does not appear.

analyzed: prakāśate tu jñānam eva  jaḍasya prakāśa ayogāt iti
translated: But the cognition itself appears.🔽Because the insentient cannot appear.

analyzed: yadi saṃvedyate iti
translated: If it is cognized,

analyzed: nīla ādi yadi prakāśate
translated: if blue etc. is cognized, it appears in the cognition.

original: tarhi prakāśasvabhāvatayā tadapi cittavadābhyantarameveti kathaṃ tad bāhyamucyate /
analyzed: tarhi prakāśa svabhāva tayā tat api citta vat ābhyantaram eva iti katham tat bāhyam ucyate
translated: Then, because it has the nature of appearance, it too is internal like the mind. How can it be said to be external?

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ nīlam iti yat prakāśate vaktavyam
translated: The meaning is this: What appears as blue must be said to be the cognition itself.

original: cakṣuḥpathe yannipatitaṃ tasya ca cittasya ca kaḥ saṃbandhaḥ yaccittena gṛhyeta /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ pathe yat nipatitam tasya ca cittasya ca kaḥ saṃbandhaḥ yat cittena gṛhyeta
translated: What connection is there between the object that falls within the range of the eye and the mind, that it should be apprehended by the mind?

analyzed: vastuni nayana patham upagata mātre bhavati nīlam iti avabhāsaḥ
translated: When the object merely comes within the range of the eye, there is the appearance it is blue.

analyzed: sa ca cittasya eva prakāśaḥ
translated: And that is the manifestation of the mind itself.

analyzed: atas gamyate nīla ākāra avabhāsaḥ cittasya eva iti
translated: Therefore it is understood that the appearance in the form of blue belongs to the mind itself.

original: na cet saṃvedyateyadā ca na saṃvedyate /
analyzed: na ced saṃvedyate yadā ca na saṃvedyate
translated: If it is not cognized, when it is not cognized,

analyzed: nayana patha saṃnikṛṣṭam anu jāyamānena na viṣayī kriyate
translated: it is not made an object by what arises in proximity to the range of the eye.

analyzed: atha katham tasya bāhya tā bahis indriya janya pratyakṣa gocara tā
translated: Then how is it external, the object of perception produced by an external sense faculty?

analyzed: tathā ca bāhyānām apratyakṣa tvam siddham iti
translated: And thus it is established that external things are not perceived.

original: yadi bāhyo'rthaḥ pratyakṣapramāṇena na gṛhyate tarhi tasmin pramāṇābhāvād vijñānamātrameva vastvitīṣyatām /
analyzed: yadi bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ pratyakṣa pramāṇena na gṛhyate tarhi tasmin pramāṇa abhāvāt vijñāna mātram eva vastu iti iṣyatām
translated: If an external object is not apprehended by the means of direct perception, then since there is no means of knowing it, it should be accepted that consciousness alone is the reality.

analyzed: iti āśayena śaṅkate nanu yadi iti
translated: With this in mind, he raises the doubt: But if...

analyzed: pariharati vyatirekataḥ iti
translated: He replies: By exclusion...

analyzed: jñānāt arthasya nīla ādeḥ vyatirekāt
translated: Because the object, such as blue, is excluded from consciousness.

analyzed: vyatireke kāraṇam āha nahi ityādinā
translated: He gives the reason for the exclusion, saying For... and so on.

analyzed: na ca etat iti
translated: And this is not so, he says.

original: etat uttarottaracitte pūrvapūrvacittato nirantaramanuvartamāne'pi kvacideva deśe kvacideva samaye nīlāvabhāso nānyadā nānyatretyetat /
analyzed: etat uttara uttara citte pūrva pūrva cittataḥ nirantaram anuvartamāne api kvacid eva deśe kvacid eva samaye nīla avabhāsaḥ na anyadā na anyatra iti etat
translated: This is because even when the subsequent mind continues uninterruptedly from the preceding mind in some place and at some time, the appearance of blue occurs only at that time and place, not at any other time or place.

analyzed: sva upādāna pūrva pūrva citta bala mātra bhāvitye na yujyate  samanantara pratyaya vyatiriktam iti
translated: It is not reasonable that it arises merely by the power of its own immediately preceding mind.🔽Apart from the immediately preceding condition.

analyzed: samanantara pūrva pratyaya vyatiriktam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is apart from the immediately preceding preceding condition.

analyzed: evam vaibhāṣika sautrāntika ābhittam bāhya astitva pakṣam nirūpya
translated: Having thus described the external existence theory of the Vaibhāṣikas and Sautrāntikas,

original: atha yogācāramataṃ vijñānamātrāstitvapakṣaṃ nirūpayan bāhyastitvavādaṃ vikalpya dūṣayatikaḥ punarasāṃ bāhyo'rthaṃ iti /
analyzed: atha yoga ācāra matam vijñānamātra astitva pakṣam nirūpayan bāhya astitva vādam vikalpya dūṣayati kaḥ punar asām iti
translated: then, in order to describe the Vijñānavāda theory of the existence of consciousness only, he criticizes the external existence theory by raising objections. The question is again, What is this external object?

analyzed: kim avayavī
translated: Is it the whole?

analyzed: kim vā paraiḥ dravya āśri tvena abhimatāḥ guṇa ādayaḥ
translated: Or are the qualities etc. that are accepted as depending on other substances?

original: kiṃ vā navavidhaṃ dravyaṃ kiṃ vā paramāṇava iti vikalpārthaḥ /
analyzed: kim vā navavidham dravyam kim vā paramāṇavaḥ iti vikalpa arthaḥ
translated: Or is it the nine kinds of substance? Or are the atoms? This is the meaning of the question.

original: yadyapyavayavyādivibhāgo vaibhāṣikasautrāntikāmyāṃ nādriyate athāpi vijñānamātrastitvavādanā bāhyārthamātrasya nirasanīyatayā teṣāmapyupādānam
analyzed: yadi api avayavi ādi vibhāgaḥ vaibhāṣika sautrāntikāmyām na ādriyate atha api vijñānamātra stitva vādanā bāhya artha mātrasya nirasanīya tayā teṣām api upādānam
translated: Although the Vaibhāṣikas and Sautrāntikas do not accept the distinction of wholes, etc., still, in order to refute the doctrine of the existence of consciousness alone, they are mentioned in order to refute external objects alone.

original: ante paramāṇūnāṃ niveśaḥ avayavinirasanapūrvakaṃ paramāṇumātrābhyupagamaṃ vaibhāṣikasautrāntikayorviśeṣamabhipretya /
analyzed: ante paramāṇūnām niveśaḥ avayavi nirasana pūrvakam paramāṇu mātra abhyupagamam vaibhāṣika sautrāntikayoḥ viśeṣam abhipretya
translated: At the end, the existence of atoms is mentioned, with the intention of showing the difference between the Vaibhāṣikas and Sautrāntikas, who, after refuting wholes, accept only atoms.

analyzed: prathamam nirdiṣṭaḥ api avayavī atas eva ante nirasyate
translated: Although the whole was indicated first, it is refuted at the end for this very reason.

analyzed: tad nirasana samantaram paramāṇu vāde samavataraṇam samucitam iti
translated: Immediately after refuting that, it is appropriate to introduce the doctrine of atoms.

analyzed: tatra na tāvat guṇa ādayaḥ iti
translated: Among them, first of all, qualities, etc. are not [real].

original: ādiśabdāt kriyādeḥ parigrahaḥ dravaniṣedhanava teṣāṃ niṣiddhatvāditi /
analyzed: ādi śabdāt kriyā ādeḥ parigrahaḥ teṣām niṣiddha tvāt iti
translated: The word etc. includes action, etc. They are refuted by the refutation of substance, because they are included in substance.

original: kathaṃ dravyaniṣedhenaiva tanniṣedhaḥ āhana cāsati samavāyini dravye iti /🔽ataeva satyāpi dūṣaṇāntare tannādṛtamatrāsmābhirityāhadūṣaṇamapi nādrīyata iti /
analyzed: katham dravya niṣedhena eva tad niṣedhaḥ āha na ca asati samavāyini dravye iti  ataeva satyā api dūṣaṇa antare tat na ādṛtam atra asmābhiḥ iti āha dūṣaṇam api na ādrīyate iti
translated: How is their refutation by the mere refutation of substance? It is said: And when there is no inhering substance...🔽For this very reason, although there are other faults, we do not consider them here. Therefore, it is said: The fault is also not considered.

analyzed: pṛthak dūṣaṇam sat api na ādrīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even though there is a separate fault, it is not considered.

analyzed: dravyasya katham niṣedhaḥ tatra āha dravyam ca ityādinā
translated: How can a substance be negated? He says this and so on.

analyzed: tatra ātma niṣedhāya adam api sādhanam iti pūrvam eva ātma nirasanam kṛtam
translated: There, this is also a proof for the negation of the self. The negation of the self has already been done before.

analyzed: idam api tat nirasana sādhanam iti apiśabdena gamyate
translated: This is also a proof for its negation. This is understood by the word api (also).

analyzed: yat kādācika jñānam iti
translated: That which is occasional knowledge -

analyzed: idam ca vyāpti nidarśakam udāharaṇa vākyam
translated: This is an example sentence that illustrates the pervasion.

analyzed: kādācitka jñāna tvam hetuḥ
translated: The reason is being occasional knowledge.

analyzed: kādācitka kāraṇa pūrvakatvam sādhyam
translated: The probandum is having an occasional cause as a prior condition.

analyzed: vyāptau udāharaṇam saudāminī jñāna vat iti
translated: The example in the pervasion is like the knowledge of lightning.

analyzed: kādācitkam ca idam ahaṅkāra jñānam iti pakṣa dharma tā upapādakam upanaya vākyam
translated: And this knowledge of 'I' is occasional - this is the conclusion sentence that establishes the property of the subject.

original: anenāhaṃgrahahetubhūtasyāhamarthasya kādācitkatvasiddhyā ātmā nityo'stītyetannirastaṃ bhavatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: anena ahaṃgraha hetu bhūtasya ahamarthasya kādācitkatva siddhyā ātmā nityaḥ asti iti etat nirastam bhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: By establishing the occasional nature of the object of I, which is the cause of the apprehension of I, it is implied that the idea that the self is permanent is refuted.

analyzed: asiddhi ādi doṣa traya rahita tām hetoḥ nirūpayati na ayam asiddhaḥ ityādinā  ahaṅkāre dharmiṇi iti
translated: He examines the reason to be free from the three faults of being unestablished and so on, starting with This is not unestablished.🔽In the cognition of 'I', which is the subject -

analyzed: ahaṅkāre ahaṃgrahe dharmiṇi pakṣe
translated: In the cognition of I, in the subject I,

analyzed: hetoḥ viśeṣya aṃśa asiddhim vāriyitvā viśeṣaṇa aṃśa asiddhim vārayati na api kādācitkā iti
translated: Having refuted the non-establishment of the qualified part of the reason, he refutes the non-establishment of the specifying part, saying Nor is it that which is occasional.

analyzed: sa pakṣe saudāminī jñāne
translated: In the case of the knowledge of lightning.

analyzed: pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām vyāpti siddheḥ iti
translated: Because the pervasion is established by perception and non-apprehension.

original: saudāminī kṣaṇamāvirbhūya tiṃrobhavati tāmanu tadjñānamapīti pratyakṣam /
analyzed: saudāminī kṣaṇam āvirbhūya tiṃrobhavati tām anu tat jñānam api iti pratyakṣam
translated: Lightning appears for a moment and then disappears, and that knowledge of it also disappears, this is perception.

original: saudāminyāḥ prāk paścācca na tajjñānopalambha ityanupalambhaḥ /🔽kādācitkajñānasyacākādacitkakāraṇādutpattāvityādi /
analyzed: saudāminyāḥ prāk paścāt ca na tad jñāna upalambhaḥ iti anupalambhaḥ  kādācitka jñānasya ca akādacitka kāraṇāt utpattau ityādi
translated: The knowledge of lightning is not apprehended before or after, this is non-apprehension.🔽And the occasional knowledge arises from an occasional cause, etc.

analyzed: kādācitkasya api jñānasya syāt akādācitkaḥ api arthaḥ kāraṇam  iti ced
translated: Even if the occasional knowledge has an occasional object as its cause, etc.

analyzed: tathā asati kadāpi kādācitkāt arthāt na syāt
translated: If it is so, then it would never arise from an occasional object.
