analyzed: kāraṇasya a kādācika tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because the occasional nature of the cause is accepted.

original: nanu akādacitkādapi syāt kādācitkādapīti cet tarhi aniyatakāraṇatāpatteṃrahetukataivāpataditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nanu akādacitkāt api syāt kādācitkāt api iti ced tarhi aniyata kāraṇatā āpatteḥ ahetuka tā eva apatat iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But if it is said that it may arise even from a non-occasional cause, then it follows that it is without a cause, because the cause is not determined, this is the point.

analyzed: tathā api anaikāntika tve iti
translated: Even so, it is inconclusive.

original: saudāminyāṃ tadjñāne ca pratyakṣānupalambhābhyāṃ sādhyahetvoḥ sāhacaryaniyame satyapyanyatrānaikāntikataivetyāśayaḥ /
analyzed: saudāminyām tad jñāne ca pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām sādhya hetvoḥ sāhacarya niyame sati api anyatra anaikāntika tā eva iti āśayaḥ
translated: The idea is that even when the concomitance of the probandum and probans is ascertained through perception and non-apprehension in the case of lightning and its cognition, it is still inconclusive elsewhere.

analyzed: prasiddha dhūmāḍhiḥ api iti
translated: Even in the case of well-known smoke and fire,

analyzed: mahānasa ādau vahni dhūmayoḥ sāhacarya niyame sati api
translated: even when there is a rule of concomitance between fire and smoke in a kitchen,

original: anyatra vinaiva vahniṃ dhūmaḥ kiṃ na svādityanaikāntikatāśaṅkā tatrāpi prasajediti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: anyatra vinā eva vahnim dhūmaḥ kim na svāt iti anaikāntika tā āśaṅkā tatra api prasajet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the doubt of non-conclusiveness arises there too, thinking why should there be smoke without fire elsewhere. This is the idea.

analyzed: apica ityādi
translated: Moreover, etc.

original: kāraṇamamartho'kācitkaḥ /🔽kāryastvahaṃgrahaḥ kādācitka ityetannopapadyate /🔽kāraṇasya kāryajanasamartharaya nityātvena sarvadaivāhaṃgraho'pyutpadyeti /
analyzed: kāraṇam amarthā ukācitkaḥ  kāryaḥ tu ahaṃgrahaḥ kādācitkaḥ iti etat na upapadyate  kāraṇasya nitya tvena sarvadā eva ahaṃgrahaḥ upi utpadyeti
translated: The cause is always existent, while the effect is occasional.🔽This is not reasonable.🔽Because the cause is always capable of producing its effect, the cognition of the self would arise at all times.

original: kāraṇasya kuvadrapatvātkāryaniṣpādanasāmarthyena kāraṇaṃ kāryarupaṃ kurvadeva syāt /
analyzed: kāraṇasya kuvat rapa tvāt kārya niṣpādana sāmarthyena kāraṇam kārya rupam kurvat eva syāt
translated: Because the cause is always existent, it would be the cause only by producing the effect in the form of the effect.

analyzed: akarot kāryam kariṣyati iti vā iti nā evā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it cannot be said that it did not produce the effect, will produce the effect, or does not produce the effect.

analyzed: kāryam akurvataḥ api tiṣṭhataḥ tu kāraṇa tvam aupacārikam evā āpatet
translated: Even for one who does not produce the effect, the state of being a cause would be only figurative, while remaining as it is.

analyzed: ekam eva kurvat api bhavet
translated: It would be one who produces only one,

analyzed: akurvat api bhavet iti vyāhatam
translated: and it would be one who does not produce at all. This is contradictory.

original: tayorbhedaniyamāt abhede tu svabhāvaikyena kurvato'pyakurvato'pi syādeva kāryotpattiritiṃ bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tayoḥ bheda niyamāt abhede tu svabhāva aikyena kurvataḥ upi akurvataḥ api syāt eva kārya utpattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that if there were no difference between them, then even if one were to act, since there would be identity of nature, the effect would arise even if one did not act.

analyzed: kiñca ahaṅkārasya iti
translated: Moreover, of the ego, etc.

original: akādācitkasyaivātmanaḥ kādācitkāhaṃgrahotpādakatve ekena tena kramādyāvanto'haṃgrahā utpādyante te sarve yugapadutpadyeran /
analyzed: akādācitkasya eva ātmanaḥ kādācitka ahaṃgraha utpādaka tve ekena tena kramāt yāvantaḥ uhaṃgrahāḥ utpādyante te sarve yugapad utpadyeran
translated: If the non-accidental self were the producer of the accidental ego-grasping, then all those ego-graspings that are to be produced by that one [self] would arise simultaneously.

analyzed: karaṇasya jāgarūka tvāt na ca sāmagrī vaikalyam
translated: Because the instrument [i.e., the self] is alert, and there is no deficiency in the assemblage [of causes].

analyzed: sāmarthye katham sāmagrī vaikalyam
translated: And how can there be a deficiency in the assemblage [of causes] if there is [the self's] capacity?

analyzed: kāraṇa antara sāpekṣa itve tu na eva sāmarthyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that if [the self] requires another cause, then it does not have the capacity [to produce the ego-graspings].

analyzed: nanu ātma ahaṃgraha hasya ālambana mātram
translated: But isn't the self merely the object of the ego-grasping?

analyzed: anyat eva tu kāraṇam iti āśaṅkām anūdya nirasyati nanu ahaṃkārasya ityādinā
translated: But isn't the cause something else? Anticipating this doubt, he refutes it with But if the ego-grasping... and so on.

analyzed: ālaṃbana tā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that it does not go beyond being the object.

analyzed: evam para abhimataḥ ātmā nirastaḥ
translated: Thus the self accepted by others is refuted.

analyzed: atha ākāśam nirasyati atha kim ākāśam ityādinā
translated: Now he refutes space with But what is space? and so on.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ saugata ekadeśinaḥ vaibhāṣikāḥ ākāśam vastu iti manyate
translated: The idea is this: The Vaibhāṣikas, who are followers of the Buddha, think that space is a substance.

original: vastu vā tadavastu veti vicārayanto vayamavastveveti brūmaḥvastunā hyarthakriyāsamarthena bhāvyam /
analyzed: vastu vā tat avastu vā iti vicārayantaḥ vayam avastu eva iti brūmaḥ vastunā hi arthakriyā samarthena bhāvyam
translated: We say that it is indeed non-existent, for an existent must be capable of effective action.

analyzed: anyathātva vastu eva tat
translated: Otherwise, it would be an existent.

analyzed: na ca ākāśena bhavati kā api arthakriyā
translated: And no effective action is performed by space.

analyzed: nanu avakāśa pradāna lakṣaṇa artha kriyā sāmarthyam asti tasya iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it has the capacity for effective action in the form of providing space, that is not so.

analyzed: yatra sa pratigham vastu ghaṭa paṭa ādi asti
translated: Where there are obstructing objects like pots, cloth, etc.,

original: tatra sadapyākāśaṃ nāvakāśādhāne prabhavati /🔽atha teṣu sapratigheṣvasatsu teṣāmabhāvādevāvakāśaḥ siddha iti kimākāśena /🔽sapratighavastuvirahānnacātiricyate kaścidavakāśa iti /
analyzed: tatra sat api ākāśam na avakāśa ādhāne prabhavati  atha teṣu sa pratigheṣu asatsu teṣām abhāvāt eva avakāśaḥ siddhaḥ iti kim ākāśena  sa pratigha vastu virahāt na ca atiricyate kaścid avakāśaḥ iti
translated: even though space exists there, it is not able to provide space.🔽If it is argued that when those obstructing objects are absent, space is established as the mere absence of those, what is the use of space?🔽And space does not exceed the mere absence of obstructing objects.

analyzed: tat ekam bibhuḥ nityam ākāśam iti anupapannam
translated: Therefore, it is not tenable that space is one and all-pervading.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādi vat apasaraṇa upasaraṇ abhyupagame pariccheda āpattiḥ
translated: If it is accepted that space moves away and comes near like a pot, etc., it would be limited.

analyzed: sa pratigha vastu saṃnidhāna asannidhānābhyām nāśa utpāda abhyupagame tu nitya ekatā vyāhanyeta iti
translated: But if it is accepted that space is destroyed and produced by the presence and absence of obstructing objects, its eternality and oneness are contradicted.

analyzed: atha vaiśeṣika abhimata ākāśa samarthana prakāram nirasyati paraiḥ tu ityādinā
translated: Now, to refute the mode of establishing space as conceived by the Vaiśeṣikas, he says But others and so on.

original: samānadaśatvāt sarvaśabdānāmiti /🔽nityamekaṃ vibhumākāśamicchatāṃ śabdasya tadāśrayatāṃ ca svīkurvatāṃ jāyamānasya sarvasya śabdasyākāśa eva deśa iti asya śabdasyāyaṃ deśaḥ tasya tu sa deśa iti deśavibhāgasya vaktumaśakyatayā deśavibhāgena śabdaśravaṇaṃ nopapadyeta /
analyzed: samāna daśa tvāt sarva śabdānām iti  nityam ekam vibhum ākāśam icchatām śabdasya tad āśraya tām ca svīkurvatām jāyamānasya sarvasya śabdasya ākāśaḥ eva deśaḥ iti asya śabdasya ayam deśaḥ tasya tu sa deśaḥ iti deśa vibhāgasya vaktum aśakya tayā deśa vibhāgena śabda śravaṇam na upapadyeta
translated: Because all words are in the same state.🔽For those who desire that space is eternal, one, and all-pervading, and accept that sound has it as its substratum, since all sound that arises has space alone as its locus, it would be impossible to state a division of space by saying this is the locus of this sound, but that is the locus of that sound.

original: yaḥ śrotrākāśa ucyate sa cākāśānnatiricyate iti nāyaṃ śrotrākāśasya saṃnihitaḥ śabdaḥ ayameva tu sannihita ityāśrayākāśe pradeśabhedakalpanasyānupapannatvāt sarva eva śabdāḥ śrūyeran /
analyzed: yaḥ śrotra ākāśaḥ ucyate sa ca ākāśāt na atiricyate iti na ayam śrotra ākāśasya saṃnihitaḥ śabdaḥ ayam eva tu sannihitaḥ iti āśraya ākāśe pradeśa bheda kalpanasya anupapanna tvāt sarve eva śabdāḥ śrūyeran
translated: And since the space of the ear is not different from space, this sound is not near to the space of the ear, but that very [space] is near. Therefore, since it is impossible to conceive of a division of space in the substratum space, all sounds would be heard.

analyzed: yadi vyavahitaḥ na śrūyeta
translated: If an obstructed [sound] is not heard,

original: tarhi tadanyaḥ sannihitoṃ ya ucyate so'pi na śrūyeta /
analyzed: tarhi tad anyaḥ sannihita ūm yaḥ ucyate saḥ upi na śrūyeta
translated: then the other one that is said to be near would also not be heard.

analyzed: deśa bhedasya durvaca tvāt
translated: Because a division of space is impossible to state.

original: yadi śrūyeran sarvaṃ eva śrūyeran na cennaikopīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yadi śrūyeran sarvam eva śrūyeran na ced na ekaḥ upi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If [sounds] were heard, all of them would be heard. If not, then not even one would be heard. This is the idea.

analyzed: tat idam dūṣaṇam śabdasya krama utpatti anupapatteḥ api upalakṣakam
translated: This criticism also indicates the impossibility of the gradual production of sound.

original: uktaṃ ca kamalaśīlena 'yadi hi nityaikanabhodravyasamavetā amī syuḥ /
analyzed: uktam ca kamalaśīlena yadi hi nitya eka nabhaḥ dravya samavetāḥ amī syuḥ
translated: And it has been said by Kamalaśīla: 'If these were inherent in the eternal, single substance of space,

original: tadā sakṛdutpannānekaśabdavat atatkālā api śabdā abhimatakāla eva syuḥ /
analyzed: tadā sakṛt utpanna aneka śabda vat atatkālāḥ api śabdāḥ abhimata kāle eva syuḥ
translated: then, like the many sounds produced simultaneously, the sounds would exist at the intended time, even when not present.

analyzed: avikala kāraṇa tvāt
translated: Because the cause is not deficient.

analyzed: eka āśraya tvāt ca
translated: And because they have a single basis.

analyzed: na ca nityasya para apekṣā ati iti
translated: And because the eternal does not depend on another.'

analyzed: tatvasam pam pa  diś kālayoḥ ca ka tvāt iti
translated: Tattva-sam- pa. pa.🔽And because space and time are one.

analyzed: diśaḥ ekatva abhyupagamāt kālasya ca ekatva abhyupagamāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because space is accepted as one and time is accepted as one.

analyzed: nitya tva vibhu tva abhyupagamasya upalakṣakam
translated: This is an indication of the acceptance of eternality and omnipresence.

analyzed: etena iti  ākāśa kāla diśām nirasanena eva iti arthaḥ
translated: By this,🔽the meaning is: by the very refutation of space, time and direction.

analyzed: nirasana yukteḥ eka prakāra tvāt iti yāvat
translated: The refutation is of one kind, this is the meaning.

original: yā tu manaḥsādhane parairyuktirnirūpitā tāmanudya nirasyatiyugapadjñānānutpattyetyādinā /
analyzed: yā tu manaḥ sādhane paraiḥ yuktiḥ nirūpitā tām anudya nirasyati yugapad jñāna anutpattyā ityādinā
translated: But the reasoning presented by others in the proof of the mind is raised and refuted by 'the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions' and so on.

original: ayamāśayaḥ yadi mano neṣyeta jñānāṃ cākṣuṣādīnāṃ yaugapadyamāpadyeta /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ yadi manaḥ neṣyeta jñānām cākṣuṣa ādīnām yaugapadyam āpadyeta
translated: The idea is this: if the mind were not accepted, the visual and other cognitions would occur simultaneously.

original: ātmano vibhoścakṣurādīndriyaiḥ saha sadaiva saṃbhavāt karatalasannihitasya kusumādeścakṣuḥspārśanādīndriyasaṃprayogasya yugapat saṃbhavāt /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ vibhoḥ cakṣuḥ ādi indriyaiḥ saha sadā eva saṃbhavāt kara tala sannihitasya kusuma ādeḥ cakṣuḥ spārśana ādi indriya saṃprayogasya yugapad saṃbhavāt
translated: Because the soul and the all-pervading senses like the eye are always present together, and because the contact of the eye, touch, etc. with the flower, etc. present in the palm of the hand can occur simultaneously.

original: manasi cendriye'bhyupagamyamāne'ṇostasya yugapadanekendriyasaṃyogasyāsaṃbhavād indriyamanaḥsaṃyogasyāpi pratyakṣe hetutayā na jñānānāṃ yaugapadyaprasaṅga iti vaiśeṣikā manyante /
analyzed: manasi ca indriya abhyupagamyamāna iṇoḥ tasya yugapad aneka indriya saṃyogasya asaṃbhavāt indriya manaḥ saṃyogasya api pratyakṣe hetu tayā na jñānānām yaugapadya prasaṅgaḥ iti vaiśeṣikāḥ manyante
translated: If the mind is accepted as a sense organ, then the simultaneous contact of that atomic mind with many sense organs is impossible. Even the contact of the sense organ with the mind is not the cause of perception, so the simultaneity of cognitions is not entailed, thus the Vaiśeṣikas think.

analyzed: atrā ucyate iha jñānānām yaugapadyam na iti etat loka anubhava viruddham
translated: To this it is said: The contradiction of the simultaneity of cognitions is contrary to worldly experience.

original: nartakīṃ paśyanto hi tasyā rūpaṃ gānaṃ ca yugapadeva sākṣātkurvantaḥ kamapyahlādamanubhavanti /
analyzed: nartakīm paśyantaḥ hi tasyāḥ rūpam gānam ca yugapad eva sākṣātkurvantaḥ kam api ahlādam anubhavanti
translated: For those who see a dancing girl experience a certain delight by directly perceiving her beauty and singing simultaneously.

analyzed: manaḥ vā aṇu kim api indriyam iṣyeta
translated: And the mind is accepted as an atom-sized sense organ.

original: lokānubhavasiddhasya jñānayaugapadyasya vyāvatireva syāttannāstyeva parābhimataṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: loka anubhava siddhasya jñāna yaugapadyasya syāt tat na asti eva para abhimatam manaḥ
translated: The simultaneity of cognitions, which is established by worldly experience, would be contradicted. Therefore the mind accepted by others does not exist at all.

analyzed: iti manaḥ na jñānāt anyat
translated: Thus the mind is not different from cognition.

analyzed: cittam jñānam iti anartha antaram iti asakṛt uktam
translated: It has been said many times that mind, thought, and cognition are not different in meaning.

analyzed: kiñca
translated: Moreover,

analyzed: jñānānām yaugapadye api loka siddhe dviṣan ayam
translated: Even though simultaneity of cognitions is well-established in the world, this man, denying it,

analyzed: prakalpayan manaḥ nityam iṣṭa hānim na paśyati
translated: imagining the mind to be eternal, does not see the loss of what is desired.

original: kāraṇasya tu nityatve kārye kramikatā katham /
analyzed: kāraṇasya tu nitya tve kārye kramika tā katham
translated: But if the cause is eternal, how can the effect be sequential?

analyzed: na anya apekṣā samarthasya na asamarthasya hetu tā
translated: The capable one does not need anything else, and the incapable one cannot be a cause.

analyzed: ayaugapadyam jñānānām nā eva siddhyet abhīpsitam
translated: The desired non-simultaneity of cognitions would not be established at all.

analyzed: uktam ca śāntarakṣitena
translated: And it has been said by Śāntarakṣita:

analyzed: nitye tu manasi prāptāḥ pratyayāḥ yaugapadyataḥ
translated: But if the mind is impermanent, the conditions, due to simultaneity,

analyzed: tena heruḥ iha proktaḥ bhavati iṣṭa vighāta kṛt
translated: are obtained. Therefore, the fallacy is stated here, causing the desired result to be obstructed.

analyzed: iti tattva
translated: Thus it is the truth.

analyzed: pṛthivī ādayaḥ uvaśiṣyante iti
translated: Earth and so on remain,

analyzed: nirasanīyāḥ iti yāvat  avayavi paramāṇu bhedena dvividhāḥ iti
translated: that is, they are to be refuted.🔽They are of two kinds, as wholes and atoms.

analyzed: dvi aṇuka ādayaḥ va vinaḥ
translated: The wholes are dyads and so on.

analyzed: tad ārambhakāḥ ca paramāṇavaḥ
translated: And the atoms that compose them.

analyzed: anupalambhaḥ bādhakaḥ iti
translated: Non-apprehension is the refuting evidence.

analyzed: avayavebhyaḥ utiriktasya avayavinaḥ paṭa ādeḥ anupalambhaḥ tad aṅgīkāre bādhakam pramāṇam
translated: The non-apprehension of a whole, such as a cloth, which is separate from its parts, is the refuting evidence if one accepts it.

original: yadi syādupalabhyeta nopalabhyatetu paṭo nāma kaścittaṃttubhyonyaḥ /
analyzed: yadi syāt upalabhyeta na upalabhyate tu paṭaḥ nāma kaścid taṃ tubhyaḥ nyaḥ
translated: If it existed, it would be apprehended, but a certain cloth is not apprehended as different from its threads.

analyzed: tathā kapālābhyam bhinnaḥ ghaṭaḥ
translated: Similarly, a pot is different from its parts like the potsherds.

analyzed: evam tantu kapāla ādayaḥ api iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the threads, potsherds, etc. are also like that.

original: atrāyaṃ prayogaḥyadupalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptaṃ sadyatra nopalabhyate na tattatrāsti /
analyzed: atra ayam prayogaḥ yat upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptam sat yatra na upalabhyate na tat tatra asti
translated: Here is the argument: What is perceptible is not perceived there, it does not exist there.

analyzed: yathā kvacid pradeśa viśeṣe ghaṭadiḥ anupalabhyamānaḥ
translated: Like a pot, etc. not perceived in a particular place.

analyzed: na upalabhyate ca avayavebhyaḥ ṛtha antara bhūtaḥ tatra eva deśe  upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptaḥ ca abhimataḥ avayavī iti  nanu upalabhyate ghaṭaḥ yam ekaḥ iti iti āśaṅkate yadi avayavī na asti iti
translated: And the thing different from the parts is not perceived in that very place.🔽And the intended whole is perceptible.🔽He doubts that the pot is perceived as one, thinking if the whole does not exist.

analyzed: eka tvena iti eka tvam hi bhāsamānam avayavinam atiriktam eva gamayati
translated: By oneness: for oneness, when appearing, conveys the whole as something additional.

original: anyathā'ṇuṣu pratīyamāneṣu tadananvayāt /🔽āptavacanopanyāsamukhena śaṅkāṃ pariharatibhāgā eva hīti /
analyzed: anyathā aṇuṣu pratīyamāneṣu tad ananvayāt  āpta vacana upanyāsa mukhena śaṅkām pariharati bhāgāḥ eva hi iti
translated: Otherwise, when atoms are cognized, that would not be connected with it.🔽He removes the doubt by introducing the words of a trustworthy person, saying parts alone.

analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam atirikta avayavi vādinām vyavahāraḥ ayam avayavī paṭaḥ
translated: And this usage of those who assert the additional whole: This is the whole cloth.

analyzed: asya bhāgāḥ aṃśāḥ ime tantavaḥ
translated: These are its parts, the threads.

analyzed: taiḥ ca ayam bhāgavān iti  nad anurodhena nirdeśaḥ bhāgāḥ iti
translated: And it possesses those parts.🔽The designation is not in accordance with that, saying parts.

analyzed: bhāgāḥ eva bhāsante cākṣuṣe
translated: Only the parts appear in the visual [perception].

analyzed: na tu bhāgavān bhāgaiḥ ārabdhaḥ
translated: But there is no Lord composed of parts, different from them.

analyzed: nirbhāgaḥ akhaṇḍaḥ pratīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that something indivisible, without parts, is perceived.

original: bhāgā eva hi bhāsanta ityetat praśnaprativacanamukhena vyācaṣṭe nanu ko'yamityadinā /🔽sañcitaparamāṇupratibhāsaeveti /
analyzed: bhāgāḥ eva hi bhāsante iti etat praśna prativacana mukhena vyācaṣṭe nanu kaḥ yam ityadinā  sañcita paramāṇu pratibhāsaḥ eva iti
translated: For only the parts appear. This is explained through the question and answer, beginning with But what is this..., etc.🔽It is only the appearance of accumulated atoms.

analyzed: puñjībhūta paramāṇu pratibhāsaḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is only the appearance of aggregated atoms.

original: nānādigdeśāvaṣṭambhena bahavaḥ paramāṇavaḥ ekasmin sthale pūrvapaścimadakṣiṇottarordhvādholakṣaṇanānādigdeśāvaṣṭambhena sthitāḥ puṃjībhūtā ucyante
analyzed: nānā diś deśa avaṣṭambhena bahavaḥ paramāṇavaḥ ekasmin sthale pūrva paścima dakṣiṇa uttara ūrdhva adhas lakṣaṇa nānā diś deśa avaṣṭambhena sthitāḥ puṃjībhūtāḥ ucyante
translated: Many atoms occupying different directions are said to be aggregated when they are located in one place, occupying different directions such as east, west, south, north, above, and below.

analyzed: śaṅkate yadi evam iti
translated: He raises an objection, saying If this is so...

original: vacanasya hārdamajānataḥ śaṅkeyam /🔽ajñānamevopapādayatiarthasya svarūpeṇa nāsti vedanamityādinā /
analyzed: vacanasya hārdam a jānataḥ śaṅkeyam  ajñānam eva upapādayati arthasya svarūpeṇa na asti vedanam ityādinā
translated: This doubt is due to not knowing the meaning of the statement.🔽He himself explains the ignorance, beginning with There is no cognition of the object in its own form...🔽There is no cognition of the object such as the gross one in its own form, i.e., in the form of the object.

original: arthasyasthūlādeḥ svarūpeṇaarthātmanā nāsti vedanam /🔽kintu vittirevārthātmanā bhāsate iti /
analyzed: arthasya sthūla ādeḥ svarūpeṇa artha ātmanā na asti vedanam  kintu vittiḥ eva artha ātmanā bhāsate iti
translated: But only the experience appears in the form of the object.

analyzed: tatra vacanam āha bhāktam syāt artha vedanam iti
translated: There, he states the statement, The cognition of the object may be figurative.

analyzed: arthasya vedanam iti etat bhāktam syāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this [statement] would be figurative, referring to the cognition of an object.

analyzed: sthūla pratibhāsasya anyathā asiddhim āha tasmāt iti
translated: He says that the appearance of the gross is otherwise established: therefore.

analyzed: sthūla avabhāsaḥ bhramaḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: It is said that the appearance of the gross is an error.

analyzed: evam eva tu bhadanta śubhaguptaḥ manyate
translated: But the Venerable Śubhagupta thinks it is just like this.

analyzed: anūdyate ca śānta rakṣitena  tulya apara kṣaṇa utpādāt ayathā nitya tva vibhramaḥ
translated: And it is repeated by Śāntarakṣita:🔽Just as there is no confusion about permanence due to the arising of similar moments,

analyzed: avicchinna sajātīya grahe ced sthūla vibhramaḥ
translated: if there is confusion about the gross in the apprehension of an uninterrupted homogeneous [series], that is the truth.

analyzed: iti tattva
translated: Thus it is.

original: nanuavayavino'nabhyupagame sthūlo'yaṃ nīlo'yamiti cākṣuṣaṃ kathamupapadyate /🔽tatrāhaye'pi tadārambhakāḥ paramāṇo vaiśeṣikāṇāmiti /
analyzed: nanu avayavinaḥ an abhyupagame sthūlaḥ yam nīlaḥ yam iti cākṣuṣam katham upapadyate  tatra aha ye api tad ārambhakāḥ paramāṇaḥ vaiśeṣikāṇām iti
translated: But if the whole is not accepted, how is it possible to have visual perception like this is gross and this is blue?🔽There, he says: even for those who are composed of atoms, according to the Vaiśeṣikas.

analyzed: tad ārambhaka tvena vaiśeṣikaiḥ abhimatāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are accepted by the Vaiśeṣikas as being composed of atoms.

analyzed: vaibhāṣikāṇām darśane iti
translated: According to the Vaibhāṣikas, they are directly the object of perception.

analyzed: bāhya artha mātra nirasane pravṛttānām paraṃāṇūnām dṛśya tva samarthanam sākṣāt na atyantam apekṣitam
translated: For those who are engaged in refuting external objects alone, the establishment of the perceptibility of atoms is not directly and absolutely necessary.

original: avayavisamarthanāya pravṛttaṃ prati prativaktavye sayūthyānāṃ matenedamucyate iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: avayavi samarthanāya pravṛttam prati prativaktavye sa yūthyānām matena idam ucyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that this is said according to the opinion of the companions in reply to the one who has undertaken to prove the existence of the whole.

analyzed: vaibhāṣikebhyaḥ sautrāntikānām viśeṣam āha su ākāra samarpaṇa iti
translated: He states the difference between the Sautrāntikas and the Vaibhāṣikas, saying in the presentation of their own aspects.

original: atha bāhyārthānnirasyannāhate'pi yogācārāṇāṃ mate na santīti /
analyzed: atha bāhya arthān nirasyan āhata ipi yoga ācārāṇām mate na santi iti
translated: Now, when refuting external objects, he says that even in the Yogācāra view, they do not exist.

analyzed: na khalu ekaḥ iti
translated: For indeed, there is not one.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ pratyekam bhinna bhinnāḥ paramāṇavaḥ osaṅkhyātāḥ puñja ātmanā
translated: The idea is this: The individual atoms, which are different from each other, are innumerable, and exist in the form of a mass.

analyzed: vasthitāḥ dṛśyante
translated: They are seen.

analyzed: pratyekam svātantryeṇa na eṣām kadācid api sthitiḥ
translated: They never exist independently, each by itself.

analyzed: saṃhatāḥ eva utpadyante saṃhatāḥ eva naśyanti
translated: They arise only when combined, and they perish only when combined.

original: ataeva puñjāvasthāyāṃ dṛśyamānānāṃ pratyekamavasthitau kuto'dṛśyateti śaṅkāyā nāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: ataeva puñja avasthāyām dṛśyamānānām pratyekam avasthitau kutas dṛśya tā iti śaṅkāyāḥ na avakāśaḥ
translated: For this very reason, there is no opportunity for the doubt How is it that each one is seen to exist individually when seen in the state of a mass?

analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And thus it is said:

analyzed: pratyeka paramāṇūnām svātantrye na asti saṃbhavaḥ  atas api paramāṇūnām a ekaika a pratibhāsanam
translated: The individual atoms have no existence independently.🔽Therefore, the individual atoms are not perceived.

analyzed: iti tattva saṃ paṃ pa
translated: Thus it is in the Tattvasaṃgrahapañjikā.

analyzed: iti bāhya astitva vādinaḥ manyante
translated: This is what the proponents of external existence think.

original: atredaṃ vimṛśyatesamuditā eva jāyantāṃ samuditā eva naśyantu /
analyzed: atra idam vimṛśyate samuditāḥ eva jāyantām samuditāḥ eva naśyantu
translated: Here this should be considered: Let them be born only when combined, let them perish only when combined.

analyzed: param atra evam khalu vaktavyam
translated: But here this should indeed be said:

analyzed: ayam ekaḥ paramāṇuḥ ayam ekaḥ ayam ekaḥ samuditāḥ ca ete iti
translated: This is one atom, this is one, this is one, and these are combined.

analyzed: tatra idam pṛccāmaḥ ayam ekaḥ paramāṇuḥ iti katham siddhayet
translated: There we ask this: How is it established that this is one atom?

analyzed: saḥ api vicāryamāṇaḥ na ekaḥ bhavitum arhati kasmāt
translated: That one, when examined, should not be one. Why?

original: ucyateyo hi paramāṇuḥ paramāṇumadhyamadhyāste sa caturṣu pārśveṣu adharottaraṃ ca paramāṇubhiḥ sasṛṣṭa iti digbhāgabhedena ṣaḍaṃśatāpattyā naikatāpattiranatilaṅghanīyaiva /
analyzed: ucyate yaḥ hi paramāṇuḥ paramāṇu madhyam adhyāste sa caturṣu pārśveṣu adhara uttaram ca paramāṇubhiḥ sasṛṣṭaḥ iti diś bhāga bhedena ṣaṣ aṃśa tā āpattyā na ekatā āpattiḥ an atilaṅghanīyā eva
translated: It is said: That atom which occupies the middle of another atom, that is mixed with atoms below and above in the four sides, thus falling into six parts by the division of directions, it does not fall into oneness. That cannot be transgressed.

original: sa hi madhyagataḥ paramāṇuḥ pārśve paramāṇau yena svabhāvena saṃsṛjate /
analyzed: sa hi madhya gataḥ paramāṇuḥ pārśve paramāṇau yena svabhāvena saṃsṛjate
translated: For that atom in the middle, which is mixed with atoms on the sides by a certain nature,

analyzed: na tena svabhāvena ūrdhva adhas paramāṇunā saṃsṛjyate
translated: it is not mixed with the upper and lower atoms by that same nature.

original: yena svabhāvena ūrdhādhaḥparamaṇubhyāṃ saṃyujyate na tena pārśvaparamāṇau /
analyzed: yena svabhāvena ūrdhva adhas param aṇubhyām saṃyujyate na tena pārśva paramāṇau
translated: By what nature it is connected with the upper and lower atoms, by that it is not mixed with the side atoms.

analyzed: yadi vinā svabhāva bhedam saṃsṛjyeta
translated: If it were mixed without a difference in nature,

original: digbhedakṛtabhedasya durnirūpatayā ekadeśatāpatteḥ pracayo na siddhayet /
analyzed: diś bheda kṛta bhedasya durnirūpa tayā eka deśa tā āpatteḥ pracayaḥ na
translated: Because it is difficult to determine the difference made by the directions, the attainment of a part would not establish accumulation.

analyzed: tathā ca madhya avasthita paramāṇu mātram piṇḍaḥ syāt
translated: And thus the lump would be just the atom located in the middle.

analyzed: paramāṇūnām mithas saṃyoga upapādana kleśāt ābhimukhya mātram ced madhyastha paramāṇunām iṣyeta
translated: If mere facing is accepted for the atoms located in the middle, if it is argued that the connection between atoms is merely facing.

analyzed: tadā api asmāt doṣāt anirmokṣāḥ vā iti
translated: Then also, we are not released from this fault.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa dūṣayan āha atha ca ayam vicāraḥ iti
translated: Refuting in another way, he says But this consideration...

analyzed: na api anekaḥ paramāṇuḥ iti
translated: Nor is it many, an atom.

original: ayamāśayaḥ nanu naikasvabhāvo'yamaṇuḥ /🔽ato naika ityeva brūmaḥ na paramāṇurathāpyaneka iti tryāha tam /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ nanu na eka svabhāvaḥ yam aṇuḥ  atas na ekaḥ iti eva brūmaḥ na paramāṇuḥ atha api anekaḥ iti tri āha tam
translated: The intention is this: Surely this atom is not of one nature.🔽Therefore we say it is not one, not even many atoms. Why is that?

original: kasmāt / / paramāṇoḥparamāṇutayā'bhimatasyānaiḥ saha paramāṇubhiḥ paramāṇuśaḥatyantāṇuśaḥ sayogasyāsaṃbhavāt /
analyzed: kasmāt paramāṇoḥ parama aṇu tayā abhimatasya anaiḥ saha paramāṇubhiḥ paramāṇuśaḥ atyanta aṇuśas sayogasya asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because the connection of the atom, considered as an atom, with other atoms, by atoms, is not possible.

analyzed: paramāṇu tayā abhimatasya katham tatas api aṇuśas saṃyogaḥ syāt
translated: How could there be a connection even smaller than that of what is considered as an atom?

analyzed: saṃyogaḥ ca saṃyujyatām aṃśataḥ eva bhavati
translated: And the connection occurs only by part of what is connected.

analyzed: tasmāt yadi asau sa aṃśaḥ katham paramāṇuḥ ucyate
translated: Therefore, if it has parts, how can it be called an atom?

original: atha cenniraṃśaḥ saṃyujyate ityutyucyeta sarvataḥ saṃyogāt parasparamabhinnadeśatayā piṇḍaḥ paramāṇūmātra eva syāt /
analyzed: atha ced niraṃśaḥ saṃyujyate sarvatas saṃyogāt parasparam abhinna deśa tayā piṇḍaḥ paramāṇu mātraḥ eva syāt
translated: If, on the other hand, it is said that the partless [atom] is in conjunction, then due to conjunction from all sides, the aggregate would be no different in location from the atoms themselves, and would be just as small as an atom.

analyzed: parvataḥ kṣiti mātraḥ ca syāt iti
translated: And the mountain and the earth would be just as small.

analyzed: tayoḥ iti piṇḍa paramāṇvoḥ iti arthaḥ  svabhāvānām iti
translated: The word their means the aggregate and the atom.🔽The word natures means the natures of the atoms.

analyzed: paramāṇu svabhāvānām iti arthaḥ
translated: The word own means the own natures of the atoms.

analyzed: sva ukta dūṣane āpta vacanam saṃvādayati ṣaṭkena yugapad yogāt iti
translated: He corroborates the statement of the trustworthy person with the six, saying because of simultaneous conjunction.

analyzed: vyākhyāta prāyam etat
translated: This has been explained for the most part.

analyzed: āha ca idam śāntarakṣitaḥ
translated: And this is said by Śāntarakṣita:

analyzed: saṃyuktam dūra deśa stham nairantarya vyavasthitam
translated: The conjoined [atom], located far away, is established without interruption.

analyzed: eka aṇu abhimukham rūpam yat akṣṇoḥ madhya vartinaḥ
translated: The form facing one atom, which is in the middle of the eyes,

analyzed: aṇu antara ābhimukhyena tat eva yadi kalpyate
translated: if that very [form] is imagined to be facing another atom,

analyzed: pracayaḥ bhūdhara ādīnām evam sati na yujyate
translated: then the accumulation of mountains and so on is not tenable in this way.

analyzed: aṇu antara ābhimukhyena rūpam ced anyat iṣyate
translated: If it is said that the form facing another atom is different,

analyzed: katham nāṃa bhavet ekaḥ paramāṇuḥ tathā asati
translated: how could the atom not be one in that case?

analyzed: iti  nanu katham asati ālambane nīla pīta ādi avabhāsaḥ
translated: Thus it is.🔽But how is there the appearance of blue, yellow, etc. without an object?

analyzed: katham asati arthe svāpna avabhāsaḥ
translated: How is there the appearance in a dream without a real object?

analyzed: nanu vāsanayā
translated: But [it is argued] by the impression [that the dream cognition is valid].

analyzed: tayā eva atra api
translated: By that very [impression, the waking cognition is also valid].

analyzed: nanu
translated: But [it is argued] in a dream there is the impossibility of an external object.

analyzed: iha api tat samānam
translated: Here also that is the same.

analyzed: a vicārayatām tu artha saulabhyam  vicārayatām tu daurghaṭyam eva
translated: But for those who do not reflect, there is the possibility of an object.🔽But for those who reflect, there is only the impossibility [of an external object].

original: daurghaṭyaṃ ca nirūpitamityāśayenāha yadi bāhyo'rtha ityādinā /
analyzed: daurghaṭyam ca nirūpitam iti āśayena āha yadi bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ ityādinā
translated: And the impossibility has been determined - with this idea he says If the external object and so on.

analyzed: nanu hanta svāpna jāgarayoḥ aviśeṣa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: But [it is argued] then there would be the undesirable consequence of the non-distinction between sleep and waking.

analyzed: kaḥ viśeṣam ācaṣṭe
translated: Who says there is a distinction?

analyzed: doṣe syāt nāma
translated: There may be a fault [in the argument].

analyzed: svāpnāt a viśiṣṭam eva tu jāgrat jñānam api
translated: But even the waking cognition is not distinguished from the dream cognition.

original: bhavati cātra prayoga ityāśayenāha na ca svāpnajāgradanubhavayorityādinā anālambanādanavāptarūpaviśeṣamiti /
analyzed: bhavati ca atra prayogaḥ iti āśayena āha na ca svāpna jāgrat anubhavayoḥ ityādinā anālambanāt anavāpta rūpa viśeṣam iti
translated: And the argument is applicable here - with this idea he says And there is no distinction between the experience in a dream and in the waking state and so on. The form is not obtained due to the absence of an object.

analyzed: anālambana tayā anavāpta rūpa viśeṣam iti arthaḥ  yathā ekasmāt ākāśa keśa darśanāt iti  cākṣuṣa doṣa vaśāt dṛśyate nabhasi keśaḥ iva bhraman
translated: The meaning is: the form is not obtained due to the absence of an object.🔽As from the seeing of a hair in the sky.🔽A hair appears to be seen in the sky due to a defect in the eye.

analyzed: tat idam ākāśa keśa darśanam
translated: This is the seeing of a hair in the sky.

analyzed: na ca ākāśam vastu
translated: And the sky is not a real object.

analyzed: na vā tatra keśaḥ
translated: Nor is there a hair in it.

analyzed: tat bāhya ālambana nirapekṣaḥ kaḥ api ayam vijñāna vilāsaḥ eva ābhāsaḥ
translated: This is an appearance of consciousness itself, independent of an external object, some kind of play of consciousness.

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ ca ayam anyatas bhramāt an apohyaḥ anyaiḥ api
translated: And this distinction is not to be removed from error by others.

analyzed: ataeva idam udāharaṇam ādṛtam
translated: For this very reason, this example is respected.

analyzed: dvitīyam iti
translated: The second.

analyzed: yat nabhasi keśa darśanam tasmāt anyat dvitīyam
translated: What is different from the appearance of hair in the sky is the second.

original: nanuasati bāhye'rthe kiṃ tarhi sat bhavataḥ /
analyzed: nanu asati bāhya īrthe kim tarhi sat bhavataḥ
translated: But if there is no external object, then what is real for you?

analyzed: vijñāna mātram tu paramārtha sat
translated: Consciousness alone is ultimately real.

analyzed: iti āha yadi ityādinā
translated: Thus he says if and so on.

analyzed: atra prācām saṃvādam āha yathoktam ityādinā
translated: Here he quotes the ancients, beginning with as stated.

analyzed: grāhya grāhaka nirmuktam grahya grāhaka bhāva nirmuktam
translated: Free from the grasped and grasper - free from the state of grasped and grasper.

analyzed: nanu asati grāhya grāhaka bhāve
translated: But if there is no state of grasped and grasper,

analyzed: jñānam kena prakāśyeta
translated: by what would knowledge be manifested?

analyzed: svena eva prakāśate
translated: It manifests by itself.

analyzed: atas na asya grāhya bhāvaḥ api iti āha na anyonubhāvyaḥ buddhayā asti ityādi
translated: Therefore, it has no state of being grasped either. He says there is nothing else to be experienced by consciousness and so on.

analyzed: atra ayam saṅgrahaḥ nirūpitaḥ ca asmābhiḥ anyatra
translated: Here is the summary: and it has been determined by us elsewhere

analyzed: sā iyam vijñāna dhārā gagana tala gata āloka vat sva prakāśā
translated: This stream of consciousness, like light in the sky, is self-luminous,

analyzed: nānā ākāra avabhāsā sphurati bahuvidhā svāpna vat vāsanātaḥ
translated: manifesting various forms, shining in many ways due to latent impressions, like a dream. It is mere cognition, without a second,

analyzed: grāhya tva grāha tva dvaya rahita tayā
translated: free from the duality of the graspable and grasper.

analyzed: sūte sā eva iyam aikā vyavahṛtim akhilām sva anya bāhya anapekṣā
translated: This very [consciousness] alone, not depending on external objects, grasps all this manifold [world].

analyzed: gṛhṇāti jñānam arthān iti jagati mataḥ grāhaka tva svabhāvaḥ
translated: It is considered in the world to have the nature of a cognizer, grasping objects through knowledge.

original: saṃvṛttyaiva pravṛtto natu viṣayitayā vastutastena śūnyam /
analyzed: saṃvṛttyā eva pravṛttaḥ na tu viṣayi tayā vastutas tena śūnyam
translated: It functions only conventionally, not as a subject in reality, therefore it is empty.

analyzed: nā api ātma grāhakam tat parama jāḍa tayā sva prakāśa ekarūpam
translated: Nor does it grasp the self, being supremely inert, of the nature of self-luminous consciousness alone.

analyzed: tat ca avicchinna dhāram pravahati satatam sattva bheda anantam iti
translated: And that flows on with an uninterrupted current, always infinite due to the variety of beings.

original: vijānānamātravādiṣu kecana vijñānameva vāsanāvaicitryeṇa nīlapītādivividhākāraṃ bhūtvā bhāsate iti /
analyzed: vijānānamātra vādiṣu kecana vijñānam eva vāsanā vaicitryeṇa nīla pīta ādi vividha ākāram bhūtvā bhāsate iti
translated: Among those who say it is mere cognition, some say that consciousness itself, through the variety of latent impressions, appears in various forms such as blue, yellow, etc.

original: apare tu vastuto nirākārameva tu tat /🔽avidyayā nīlapītādidivividhākāramiva bhāsate /
analyzed: apare tu vastutas nirākāram eva tu tat  avidyayā nīla pīta ādi di vividha ākāram iva bhāsate
translated: But others say that in reality it is formless.🔽It appears as if it has various forms such as blue, yellow, etc. due to ignorance.

analyzed: tad vāsanā vaśāt avabhāsamānaḥ api nīla apīta ādi ākāraḥ sāṃvṛtaḥ eva iti
translated: Although appearing due to the power of its latent impressions, the forms such as blue, yellow, etc. are only conventional.

original: pakṣadvaye'pyasmin grāhyagrāhakabhāvarāhityaṃ vijñānasya saṃpratipannameveti vijñānasvabhāvaparyālocanayā bāhyārthagrāhakatā vijñānasyetyetaddarotsāritamityāhatatra kecidityādinā /
analyzed: pakṣa dvaye api asmin grāhya grāhaka bhāva rāhityam vijñānasya saṃpratipannam eva iti vijñāna svabhāva paryālocanayā bāhya artha grāhaka tā vijñānasya iti etat dara utsāritam iti āha tatra kecid ityādinā
translated: In both cases, the absence of the relation of the grasped and the grasper in consciousness is well-known. Therefore, by examining the nature of consciousness, the grasping of external objects by consciousness is completely refuted. To this, he says In this regard, some... and so on.

analyzed: atha mādhyamikānām matam āha mādhyamikānām tu ityādinā
translated: Now, to state the view of the Mādhyamikas, he says But for the Mādhyamikas... and so on.

original: na cāsya vicārataḥ kaścit svabhāvo ghaṭate eko vā'neko veti /
analyzed: na ca asya vicārataḥ kaścid svabhāvaḥ ghaṭate ekaḥ vā anekaḥ vā iti
translated: And no nature of it whatsoever is tenable upon examination, whether one or many.

original: vijñānamātravādīnā paramāṇau bāhyatayā parairabhimate kimayamekasvabhāvaḥuta naikasvabhāvaḥ ekarūpa uta naikarūpaḥ
analyzed: vijñānamātra vādīnā paramāṇau bāhya tayā paraiḥ abhimate kim ayam eka svabhāvaḥ uta na eka svabhāvaḥ eka rūpaḥ uta na eka rūpaḥ
translated: For the proponents of consciousness-only, what is intended by others as external in the atom, is it of one nature or not of one nature, of one form or not of one form?

analyzed: iti ubhayatra api anupapattiḥ uktā sā iyam anupapattiḥ vijñāna mātra vāde pi tulyā eva iti āśayaḥ
translated: Thus, the impossibility in both cases is stated. The intention is that this impossibility is equally applicable to the doctrine of consciousness-only as well.

analyzed: tat idam upapādayiṣyati
translated: This he will explain.

analyzed: prathamam vijñānasya api avāstava tve āpta vacanāni saṃvādayati yathā uktam ityādinā  eka aneka svabhāvena iti
translated: First, in the non-reality of consciousness, he reconciles the statements of the trustworthy with the statement As it is said... and so on.🔽By the nature of one or many.

analyzed: vastunā hi eka svabhāvena aneka svabhāvena vā bhāvyam
translated: For a thing must exist by the nature of one or many.

analyzed: atathābhūtasya tu vyoma aravinda vat asattvatā eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But for what is not so, like a sky-lotus, it is simply non-existent, this is the idea.

original: bhāvā yena nirūpyante iti bhāvāḥbāhyā ābhyantaraśca /
analyzed: bhāvāḥ yena nirūpyante iti bhāvāḥ bāhyāḥ ābhyantaraḥ ca
translated: The entities by which [the world] is determined are the external and internal entities.

analyzed: yadā tu iti vikalpasya a sa vikalpasya niścaya ātmakasya
translated: When, [i.e.,] of the conceptual, which is determinate,

analyzed: pratyakṣasya yadā pramāṇa tā na asti
translated: when there is no validity of the other, i.e., of perception free from conceptualization such as universals, etc.,

analyzed: prāmāṇyam hi tasya vastu tve
translated: for its validity is in the case of reality.

analyzed: eka aneka svabhāva rāhityena avastu tvāt kva prāmāṇya avasaraḥ
translated: How can there be an occasion for validity when it is unreal due to being devoid of the nature of one or many?

original: atha pramāṇameva yadā vicāryamāṇaṃ viśīryate tadadhīnasadgāvasya sarvaṃsyānyasya kva vastutā /
analyzed: atha pramāṇam eva yadā vicāryamāṇam viśīryate tad adhīna sat gāvasya kva vastu tā
translated: Or, when the very means of valid knowledge, when examined, dissolves away, where is the reality of anything else, whose existence depends on that?

analyzed: tat evam sarvasmin viśīryamāṇe kā uparādhyatu
translated: Thus, when everything dissolves away in this way, who is to blame?

analyzed: bhāvānām śūnyatā eva svabhāvaḥ iti taulyāt na ekasya apekṣā apāvasaraḥ
translated: The emptiness itself of entities is their nature. Since they are equal, there is no occasion for one to depend on the other.

original: nanu ayaṃ baddho'yaṃ mukta iti vyavasthā'pi vyāhanyeta /
analyzed: nanu ayam baddhaḥ iyam muktaḥ iti vyavasthā api vyāhanyeta
translated: But even the distinction this one is bound, this one is liberated would be contradicted.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True,

original: iyaṃ vyavasthā'pi saṃvṛttyaiva na paramārthata iti /
analyzed: iyam vyavasthā api saṃvṛttyā eva na paramārthataḥ iti
translated: this distinction also is [made] only conventionally, not ultimately.

analyzed: niḥsvabhāva tā eva ca śūnyatā
translated: And emptiness is indeed the absence of intrinsic nature.

analyzed: uktam ca etat anyatra api
translated: And this has been stated elsewhere as well:

analyzed: niḥsvabhāvāḥ amī bhāvāḥ tattvataḥ sva para uditāḥ
translated: The things that are taught by ourselves and others are really without own-being,

analyzed: eka aneka svabhāvena viyogāt pratibimba vat
translated: Because of the absence of a single or a manifold nature, like a reflected image.

analyzed: iti tarhi kim tattvam
translated: Then what is reality?

analyzed: na sat na asat na sat asat na ca api anubhaya ātmakam
translated: It is neither existent, nor non-existent, nor existent and non-existent, nor even of the nature of both not existent and not non-existent,

analyzed: catuṣkoṭi vinirmuktam tattvam mādhyamikāḥ jaguḥ
translated: The Mādhyamikas declare reality to be free from the four alternatives.

original: svabhāvarāhityādbhāvānāmapāramārthye prayogaṃ pradarśayatiprayogaḥ punarevamiti ekānekasvabhāvaṃ na bhavatīti /
analyzed: svabhāva rāhityāt bhāvānām apāramārthye prayogam pradarśayati prayogaḥ punar evam iti eka aneka svabhāvam na bhavati iti
translated: He shows the application to the non-ultimate reality of things because of the absence of own-being. The application is as follows: It is not of a single or manifold nature.

analyzed: eka svabhāvam aneka svabhāvam vā yat na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not of a single nature or of a manifold nature.

analyzed: vyāpaka anupalabdhiḥ iti
translated: The non-apprehension of the pervader.

analyzed: paramārtha sattvasya vyāpakam eka svabhāva aneka svabhāva anyatara tvam
translated: Being ultimately existent is pervaded by being either of a single nature or of a manifold nature.

analyzed: tasya anupalabdhiḥ  vyāpaka anupalbdhyā vyāpyasya paramārtha sattvasya nivṛttiḥ siddhi ati
translated: There is the non-apprehension of that.🔽By the non-apprehension of the pervader, the cessation of the pervaded, being ultimately existent, is established.

original: hetoḥ pakṣe sattvamupapādayannasiddhiśaṅkāṃ vārayatina tāvada siddho hetuṃriti /
analyzed: hetoḥ pakṣe sattvam upapādayan asiddhi śaṅkām vārayati na tāvat a siddhaḥ hetuḥ iti
translated: Establishing the existence of the reason in the subject, he removes the doubt of non-establishment. The reason is not, to begin with, unestablished.

original: sākāre vijñāne bahirartha eva ekānekasvabhāvāyogyatvasya parispuṭatvāditi /
analyzed: sa ākāre vijñāne bahis arthe eva eka aneka svabhāva ayogya tvasya parispuṭa tvāt iti
translated: Because in the case of cognition with an image, the impossibility of being of a single or manifold nature with regard to the external object is quite clear.

original: nīlapītādāvaṇusamudāye bāhyārthatayā iṣyamāṇe aṇurayamekasvabhāvo vā naikasvabhāvo vā ubhayathā'pi nopapadyata iti yo doṣa udbhāvitaḥ /
analyzed: nīla pīta ādau aṇu samudāye bāhya artha tayā iṣyamāṇe aṇuḥ ayam eka svabhāvaḥ vā na eka svabhāvaḥ vā ubhayathā api na upapadyate iti yaḥ doṣaḥ udbhāvitaḥ
translated: The fault that has been pointed out, that when the aggregate of atoms in blue, yellow, etc. is accepted as an external object, whether that atom is of one nature or not of one nature, in both cases it is not tenable,

analyzed: sa vijñāna vādinaḥ vijñānam eva
translated: that same fault is equally applicable even to the Vijñānavādin who says that consciousness itself,

original: nīlapītadyākāraṃ sadvabhāsate iti vadato'pi samāna eveti sphuṭameveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nīla pīta di ākāram sat avabhāsate iti vadataḥ api samānaḥ eva iti sphuṭam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: in the form of blue, yellow, etc., appears as if it were external. The meaning is that this is clear.

analyzed: sphuṭa tām eva upapādayati yatra hi ityādinā
translated: To explain this clarity, he says For where... and so on.

original: idaṃ nīlamidaṃ pītamiti idantayā loke vyavahriyamāṇo nīlapītādiraṇusamudāyo bāhyo'rtha iti sarvāstitvavādinā iṣyate /
analyzed: idam nīlam idam pītam iti idantayā loke vyavahriyamāṇaḥ nīla pīta ādiḥ aṇu samudāyaḥ bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ iti sarva astitva vādinā iṣyate
translated: The Vaibhāṣika, who asserts the existence of everything, accepts that the aggregate of atoms such as blue and yellow, which is designated as this and is conventionally used in the world as this is blue, this is yellow, is an external object.

original: vijñānavādinā tu vijñānameva ttattadākāraṃ bahirvadavabhāsata iti vadatā vijñānākāratayā nīlapītādyabhyugataṃ bhavatīti nīlapitādi tu na sarvathā'pohyate /
analyzed: vijñāna vādinā tu vijñānam eva ttat tad ākāram bahis vat avabhāsate iti vadatā vijñāna ākāra tayā nīla pīta ādi abhyugatam bhavati iti nīla pita ādi tu na sarvathā apohyate
translated: But the Vijñānavādin, who says that consciousness itself appears as if it were external in that and that form, accepts that blue, yellow, etc. are cognized as the form of consciousness. Thus blue, yellow, etc. are not entirely denied.
There is a dispute only about the highest internal and external [nature].

original: tathāca bāhyatve ya ākṣepaḥ sa āntaratve'pi samāna eveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathāca bāhya tve yaḥ ākṣepaḥ saḥ āntara tve pi samānaḥ eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the meaning is that the objection that applies to external [nature] is the same even in internal [nature].

analyzed: nahi tad bahirbhāva nibandhanam dūṣaṇam iti  nīla pīta ādeḥ vijñānāt bahirbhāve na tat dūṣaṇatayā upanyastam
translated: For that is not a fault based on external existence.🔽If external existence of blue, yellow, etc. were established, it would not be presented as a fault.

analyzed: kintu nīla pīta ādi abhyugama mātre
translated: But it is merely in accepting blue, yellow, etc.

original: tathāca bāhyaṃ vā bhavatu āntaraṃ vā /
analyzed: tathā ca bāhyam vā bhavatu āntaram vā
translated: And so, whether it is external or internal,

analyzed: samānaḥ eva ayam doṣaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the fault is the same, this is the idea.

original: nanu bāhyaṃ nīlapītādyabhyupagacchatā mūrtaṃ taditi svīkṛtaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: nanu bāhyam nīla pīta ādi abhyupagacchatā mūrtam tat iti svīkṛtam bhavati
translated: But one who accepts external blue, yellow, etc. must admit that it is material.

original: vijñānamātraṃ taditi vadatāṃ tu tadamūrtaṃ bhavatīti neyaṃ śaṅkā'mūte prasaredityāśaṅkā paraharannāhamūrtanimittamityādinā /
analyzed: vijñāna mātram tat iti vadatām tu tat amūrtam bhavati iti na iyam śaṅkā mūte prasaret iti āśaṅkā
translated: But one who says it is mere consciousness admits that it is immaterial. So this doubt does not spread to the immaterial, thinking this, I, the author, remove the doubt with the fault based on materiality, etc.

analyzed: sa ākāra tāyām jñānasya api mūrta tvāt iti
translated: Because even consciousness has materiality if it has aspects.

original: sākāratve mūrtatā katha mityatrāhaayameva hi cittānāmākāro mūrtiriti /
analyzed: sa ākāra tve mūrtatā katham iti atra āha ayam eva hi cittānām ākāraḥ mūrtiḥ iti
translated: Here, in this is indeed the materiality of consciousnesses, their aspect, he says how materiality is if there are aspects.

analyzed: iṣyamāṇaḥ ayam ākāraḥ eva bhavati cittasya mūrttiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this accepted aspect itself becomes the materiality of consciousness.

original: nirākārajñānamātrapāramārthyavāde tu prakārāntareṇa bhāvamātrasādhāraṇo doṣo vistaraśo nirūpito'nyatra
analyzed: nirākāra jñāna mātra pāramārthya vāde tu prakāra antareṇa bhāva mātra sādhāraṇaḥ doṣaḥ vistaraśaḥ nirūpitaḥ anyatra
translated: But in the doctrine of the ultimate reality of mere consciousness without aspects, the fault common to all entities is shown in a different way in detail elsewhere.

original: 'na svato nāpi parato na dvābhyāṃ nāpyahetutaḥ /
analyzed: na svatas nā api paratas na dvābhyām nā api ahetutaḥ
translated: Not from self, not from other, not from both, nor without cause,

original: utpannā jātu vidyante bhāvāḥ kvacana kecana /
analyzed: utpannāḥ jātu vidyante bhāvāḥ kvacana kecana
translated: Are any beings, anywhere, ever produced.
Madhyamaka Kārikā

analyzed: ityādinā
translated: The details should be understood from there.

analyzed: diṅnāga ādi nibandha anavahita dṛṣṭyā muhur vibhāvayatā
translated: Having repeatedly contemplated with an undistracted gaze the treatises of Dignāga and others,

analyzed: parimita matinā api mayā vyākhyeyam vyaraci tarkabhāṣāyāḥ
translated: Even by me, of limited intellect, this commentary on the Tarkabhāṣā has been composed.

analyzed: nindantu vā abhinandantu kṛtim enām vipaścitaḥ
translated: Let the wise either criticize or praise this work.

analyzed: a doṣa darśī kaḥ nu syāt kṛtiḥ vā doṣa varjitā
translated: Who sees no faults? Or let the work be faultless.

analyzed: gurjareṣu vasan yoṣā ādṛta aneka bhūmikaḥ
translated: He who resided in Gujarat, having attained many stages,

analyzed: nānā ākṛtikam ātmānam parebhyaḥ naṭa vat vyadhāt
translated: Displayed his many-formed self to others like an actor.

analyzed: padmanābha pada ambhoja saurabha ullāsa vāsite
translated: Perfumed by the fragrance of the lotus feet of Padmanābha,

analyzed: viṣaye api vasan eṣa tāthāgata kṛtim vyadhāt
translated: Residing even in that land, he composed this Tathāgata work.

analyzed: aneka tantra kāntāre viśataḥ bahuśas mama
translated: Many times, entering the forest of many treatises,

analyzed: viṣṇuḥ avyāhataḥ panthāḥ hṛdayām āpasarpatāt
translated: May Viṣṇu, the unobstructed path, depart from my heart.

analyzed: iti tarkabhāṣā vyākhyā samāptā
translated: Thus ends the commentary on the Tarkabhāṣā.
